title: Eckartz v. Stone Creek Cove Homeowners Association
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Charles L. Eckartz, Claimant, Appellant,
v.
Stone Creek Cove Homeowners Association, Inc., Employer, and Cincinnati Insurance Companies, Carrier,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-339
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 3, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Larry A. Welborn, of Anderson, for Appellant.
William R. Harbison, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Charles Eckartz appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision affirming the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s (Commission) order finding Stone Creek Cove Homeowners Association, Inc., and Cincinnati Insurance Companies (hereinafter referred to jointly as â€œStone Creekâ€) are entitled to stop paying disability benefits related to Eckartzâ€™s headaches.
FACTS
On July 4, 2001, while working at a restaurant owned by Stone Creek, Eckartz slipped and fell sustaining injuries to his right and left elbows.Â  Stone Creek agreed to pay Eckartz temporary disability benefits for the elbow injuries.Â  The single commissioner found Eckartzâ€™s elbows reached maximum medical improvement by November 11, 2001.Â  This finding was based on medical records from two treating physicians and Eckartzâ€™s own testimony.Â  
On January 10, 2002, Eckartz began experiencing severe headaches, which he attributed to a reaction to pain medication prescribed to treat his elbows.
Eckartz contends Stone Creek should continue paying disability benefits to treat his headache problems.Â  
On April 16, 2003, the single commissioner ordered Stone Creek to provide an independent medical examination to discern whether Eckartzâ€™s headaches were causally related to his work injury.Â  The commissioner also ordered Stone Creek to continue paying temporary benefits pending her determination as to whether Eckartzâ€™s headaches were casually related to his work injury.Â  
Dr. Paul Brill performed an independent medical exam of Eckartz.Â  Among other things, he administered a CT scan to determine the cause of Eckartzâ€™s headaches.Â  Unfortunately, this scan was not optimal because the images it produced were degraded due to Eckartzâ€™s movement during the procedure.Â  Apparently, Eckartz had a kidney stone that caused him too much discomfort to remain still.Â  On August 27, 2002, Dr. Brill stated he could â€œnot say with any degree of certainty that [Eckartzâ€™s] headaches are causally related to his work injury.â€Â  Dr. Brill recommended an MRI of the brain, an MRA of the Circle of Willis, and a complete ophthalmologic exam.[1]Â  As of September 4, 2003, after an MRI and an MRA exam, Dr. Brill was unable to give a decisive medical opinion as to the cause of Eckartzâ€™s headaches and reiterated his recommendation for a complete ophthalmologic exam. 
Eckartz subsequently moved to southern Florida where he was scheduled for an eye exam in Fort Myers, Florida on December 23, 2003. Eckertz called the ophthalmologistâ€™s office on December 17, 2003 to reschedule that appointment for January 22, 2004.Â  Eckartz did not attend the appointment.Â  
Eckartz wrote a letter to the commissioner explaining he rescheduled due to a conflicting medical appointment.Â  He also claimed he did not know about the December 23, 2003 appointment until the day before.Â  Further, Eckartz asserted he did not go to the January 22, 2004 appointment because he was informed the commissioner stopped the test, and he could not personally afford the appointment.Â  Eckartz claimed part of his difficulties was due to his lack of transportation and his mail coming to him in â€œconvoluted ways.â€ 
On October 28, 2003, the single commissioner found Dr. Brillâ€™s statements regarding causation to be incomplete and asked for a more complete analysis by Dr. Brill once the eye exam was performed.Â  The commissioner then found Eckartzâ€™s reasons for missing his eye appointments were not credible. Â The commissioner concluded Stone Creek was entitled to stop paying benefits as of September 26, 2002, because Eckartz refused treatment, and Stone Creek was entitled to a credit for any overpayment of disability benefits.Â  
Eckartz timely appealed the single commissionerâ€™s ruling to an appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  The appellate panel affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s ruling.Â  Eckartz appealed that decision to the circuit court, which affirmed the panel.Â  Eckartz now appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In an appeal from the Commission, neither this Court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œAny review of the [C]ommissionâ€™s factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Accordingly, we limit review to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Corbin, 351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.Â  Substantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the full commission reached.Â  Lockridge, 344 S.C. at 515, 544 S.E.2d at 844.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Eckartz argues the circuit court erred in affirming the commissionâ€™s finding that he failed to provide substantial evidence causally relating his headaches to his work injuries and that he failed to provide a credible reason for not attending his medical appointments.Â  We disagree.
The Commissionâ€™s appellate panel relied, in part, upon reports from Dr. Brill, who performed an independent medical evaluation on Eckartz.Â  Dr. Brill noted that Eckartzâ€™s MRI and MRA were normal and showed no evidence of an intracranial aneurysm.Â  Dr. Brill further opined that: 

[i]t would be somewhat atypical to develop sudden and such severe and persistent migraine headaches without some provoking factor . . . [but despite the normal MRI and MRA] his headaches could, in part, be due to his hypertension, and again, I feel it is important that we rule out any orbital pathology and assess his intra-ocular pressures with a complete ophthalmologic evaluation.

As of August 27, 2002, Dr. Brill could â€œnot say with any degree of certainty that [Eckartzâ€™s] headaches [were] causedly (sic) related to his work injury from 7-4-01.â€Â  
On Dr. Brillâ€™s recommendation and upon the commissionerâ€™s order, Stone Creek set up a complete ophthalmologic exam for Eckartz near his new home in Florida.Â  The Commissionâ€™s appellate panel found Eckartz rescheduled this eye exam and failed to appear for his rescheduled appointment.Â  The panel based its finding on Eckartzâ€™s own statements and on the records provided by the ophthalmologistâ€™s office.Â  
Finally, the panel found Eckartzâ€™s reasons for missing the rescheduled eye exam appointment were not credible.Â  It based its decision on records from the doctorâ€™s office along with Eckartzâ€™s own testimony. Â The record and testimony showed Eckartz knew about the appointments and simply failed to keep them.Â  
Eckartz failed to provide any evidence that his headaches were a result of either his injuries or a reaction to pain medication.Â  Further, Dr. Brillâ€™s report found no evidence causally relating Eckartzâ€™s current condition to his work injury.Â  Therefore, the circuit court was correct in finding a lack of causal connection.Â  In addition, the record contains ample evidence, as noted above, to support the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that Eckartzâ€™s reasons for missing his doctorâ€™s appointments were not credible.
Eckartz also argues the circuit court misapplied South Carolina Code Ann. Section 42-15-60 (1985) in holding Eckartz must show he was justified in refusing treatment.Â  We disagree.
S.C. Code Ann. Section 42-15-60 states in pertinent part:

In case of a controversy arising between employer and employee, the Commission may order such further medical, surgical, hospital or other treatment as may in the discretion of the Commission be necessary. . . . The refusal of an employee to accept any medical, hospital, surgical or other treatment when provided by the employer or ordered by the Commission shall bar such employee from further compensation until such refusal ceases. . . .

Eckartz now claims he ceased his refusal and would like to be examined by the ophthalmologist and continue receiving temporary disability benefits.Â  However, a workersâ€™ compensation award must not be based on surmise, conjecture, or speculation.Â  Lee v. Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 81, 564 S.E.2d 354, 358 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  We find neither Eckartzâ€™s fall, nor a bad reaction to pain medication, could cause his alleged eye problem.Â  Dr. Brillâ€™s report merely speculated that Eckartzâ€™s condition could be caused by hypertension or optical problems.Â  In fact, Dr. Brillâ€™s September 4, 2003 report shows the results of the MRI and MRA were normal.
On September 4, 2003, Eckartzâ€™s condition was shown to be unrelated to his work injury of July 4, 2001.Â  The circuit court was justified in affirming the commissionâ€™s finding that based on Dr. Brillâ€™s opinion after the MRI and MRA, Eckartzâ€™s benefits should be terminated.Â  No evidence exists to the contrary. Â Therefore, the circuit court did not err in affirming the commissionerâ€™s decision to stop Eckartzâ€™s benefit payments.Â Â Â  
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is
 AFFIRMED. [2]
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] A CT scan, also known as a Cat scan, is a sectional view of the body constructed by computerized tomography.Â  MRI stands for magnetic resonance imaging.Â  An MRI produces computerized images of internal body tissues and is based on nuclear magnetic resonance of atoms within the body.Â  An MRA, or magnetic resonance angiography, is used to visualize the heart, blood vessels, or blood flow in the circulatory system.Â  The Circle of Willis is the complete ring of arteries at the base of the brain that is formed by the cerebral and communicating arteries.Â  See Medline Plus, at http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/mplusdictionary.html.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Tillman v. Grant
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Wheeler M. Tillman, Appellant,
v.
Joe L. Grant, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-340
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 5, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Wheeler M. Tillman, of North Charleston, Pro Se.
Michael A. Jones, of Durham, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Wheeler Tillman brought suit against his former client, Joe Grant, to recover attorneyâ€™s fees under a fee agreement.Â  The agreement provided if Grant fired Tillman before settlement or a verdict, Tillman would receive a contingency percentage of the settlement or an hourly fee, whichever was more.Â  The trial court found the amount due under the hourly rate was unreasonable and awarded Tillman attorneyâ€™s fees equal to the contingency percentage.Â  Tillman appeals arguing he is entitled to the hourly rate.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On February 3, 1998, Grant, his sister, and his brother-in-law were involved in a motor vehicle collision with a tractor-trailer. Â Grant[1] hired Tillman to represent him in a personal injury action he brought against the trucking company.[2] Â On April 1, 1999, Grant and Tillman signed an attorney/client contract.Â  The relevant portion of the contract provided:

In the event that I fire my Attorney before settlement or verdict, then I agree to pay my Attorney at the rate of $175.00 per chargeable hour for the work which he has performed in my case, or an amount equal to the contingent percentage set forth in this Contract multiplied by the highest offer made, whichever amount is greater.

The contingency percentage was set at forty percent.Â  
On March 26, 2003, near the end of the first day of trial in the personal injury action, Grant agreed in court to settle the case for $90,000.Â  The trial court declared that the â€œterms of the settlement were placed on the record and the parties acknowledged their consent to settle.â€Â  The trucking company issued a settlement check and prepared a general release, which it delivered to Tillman.[3]Â  
On numerous occasions, Tillman attempted to contact Grant to have him sign the release.Â  However, Grant did not respond to any of his phone calls or letters.Â  Eventually, the trucking company made a motion to compel settlement.Â  On June 6, 2003, the trial court granted the motion.Â  Tillman still attempted to contact Grant to no avail.Â  Approximately one month after the trial court granted the motion to compel settlement, Grant called Tillman and agreed to meet the following day.Â  At the meeting, Grant requested copies of deposition transcripts and refused to sign the release.Â  Â Â 
On July 8, 2003, the trial court issued a rule to show cause against Grant for his failure to sign the release.Â  At the rule to show cause hearing on July 21, 2003, Grant again refused to sign the release and fired Tillman.Â  The trial court allowed Grant a continuance in order for Grant to obtain new counsel.Â  
On November 18, 2003, Tillman filed suit against Grant for breach of contract.Â  Tillman alleged he spent 353.8 hours on Grantâ€™s case and Grant owed him $61,915 in attorneyâ€™s fees under the hourly rate and $8,320.12 in costs.Â  Additionally, Tillman requested reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in bringing the collection action.Â  After Grant failed to serve an answer, Tillman filed an application for default judgment against Grant.Â  The trial court found Grant in default.Â  Further, the trial court found the amount Tillman would be entitled to under the hourly rate was excessive, unreasonable, and unconscionable.Â  In determining the amount was unreasonable, the trial court applied the following factors: â€œ(1) nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency and compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.â€Â  The court awarded Tillman the amount he would have received under the contingency agreement, $36,000. Â The court also awarded Tillman the costs he incurred in the personal injury matter as well as the attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in bringing the collection action.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A suit to recover attorneyâ€™s fees is an action at law. Â Weatherford v. Price, 340 S.C. 572, 578, 532 S.E.2d 310, 313 (Ct. App. 2000). Â 

An action by an attorney for compensation, whether on a written contingency agreement or on a quasi-contractual obligation to pay the reasonable value of services prior to its breach, sounds in contract.Â  The proper form of action by which to enforce payment, generally, is by an action at law on the contract . . . .

Lester v. Dawson, 327 S.C. 263, 268, 491 S.E.2d 240, 242 (1997).Â  On appeal of an action at law tried without a jury, the factual findings of the trial court will not be disturbed unless found to be without any evidence which reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s findings.Â 
Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976). Â Additionally, the appellate court can correct errors of law.Â  Okatie River, L.L.C. v. S.E. Site Prep,
L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 S.E.2d 468, 472 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Tillman claims the trial court abused its discretion in failing to determine the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees according to the hourly rate and in failing to make specific findings of fact. Â We disagree.
The relationship between an attorney and client is by nature a fiduciary one. Â Hotz v. Minyard, 304 S.C. 225, 230, 403 S.E.2d 634, 637 (1991); see also 
Weatherford v. Price, 340 S.C. 572, 582, 532 S.E.2d 310, 315 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œThe relationship of an attorney with his or her client is highly fiduciary in its nature and of a very delicate, exacting and confidential character, requiring a high degree of fidelity and good faith.â€). Â The courts examine agreements between attorneys and clients with the utmost care to avoid any improper advantage to the attorney.Â 
Royal Crown Bottling Co. v. Chandler, 226 S.C. 94, 105, 83 S.E.2d 745, 750 (1954).Â  In the interest of the profession, the court has the jurisdiction â€œto see that an attorney will not lower his profession by cheapness, nor promote his own interest by extortion, as well as to the safeguarding of the trust relation which an attorney bears to the public.â€Â 
Bank of Enoree v. Yarborough, 120 S.C. 385, 393, 113 S.E. 313, 315 (1922).Â  Therefore, the court will not allow attorneys to impose excessive charges on their clients because attorneys owe the public a duty of trust.Â 
Coley v. Coley, 94 S.C. 383, 386, 77 S.E. 49, 50 (1913).Â  The factors a trial court should consider in determining reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees are:


  (1) nature, extent, and difficulty of the legal services rendered; (2) time and labor devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of compensation; (5) fee customarily charged in the locality for similar services; and (6) beneficial results obtained.

Blumberg v. Nealco Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 494, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993).
We have reviewed the record, including Tillmanâ€™s time sheets from the personal injury action, and in light of the Blumberg factors listed above, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding the contingency fee.  In comparing the contingency fee to the hourly fees, we find the hourly fees were excessive because they nearly doubled the amount due under the contingency agreement.  Further, the hourly fees would have nearly exhausted Grantâ€™s settlement of $90,000. Â In our view, the contingency fee provided Tillman with just compensation for his services.  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s award of the contingency fee instead of the hourly rate was not an abuse of discretion. [4]
Tillman claims the trial court abused its discretion by not awarding him attorneyâ€™s fees for his services rendered to Grant after he agreed to settle in court until he fired Tillman.Â  We disagree.
The contingency fee encompasses all fees owed to Tillman in the underlying personal injury suit.Â  Therefore, it would have been improper for the trial court to award Tillman additional fees in the same action when it determined that awarding Tillman more than the contingency clause would be unreasonable.Â  However, it was proper for the trial court to award Tillman costs for his time spent attempting to collect his fees.Â  The current collection action is distinctly different from the personal injury action.Â  Because Grantâ€™s behavior caused Tillman to spend time collecting a fee that was rightfully his, the court was justified in awarding Tillman reasonable damages.
CONCLUSION
The trial court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Tillman the contingency fee instead of a fee based on an hourly rate.Â  It is incumbent on the trial court to examine attorneyâ€™s fees to ensure they are not unreasonable.Â  The trial court found that the fee would be unreasonable and excessive, if it was determined by the hourly rate.Â  Evidence in the record supports such a finding.Â  Therefore, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.[5]Â 
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Grantâ€™s sister and brother-in-law brought suit with Tillman as their attorney as well.Â  They behaved in the same manner as Grant: agreeing to settle, not responding to Tillmanâ€™s attempts at contact, and firing the attorneys just before settling.Â  This suit involves only the attorneyâ€™s fees for Grantâ€™s case.
[2] Before Grant hired Tillman, he hired other attorneys to represent him in the personal injury action.Â  He fired the first attorney, and the second one withdrew.Â  Grant then hired Michael Rose, who associated Tillman to be lead counsel in the case.Â  Rose and Tillman also associated Tom Johnson for the case.Â  Rose and Johnson are not involved in Tillmanâ€™s lawsuit.
[3] Some confusion exists regarding the settlement draft or check.Â  Grant claims he never saw the settlement draft while Tillman claims he asked Grant to sign it, but it eventually expired and had to be returned to the trucking company.Â  
[4] Further, we note Tillman originally sought only the contingency fee.Â  It was not until Grant refused to release Tillmanâ€™s payment from the settlement that Tillman sought the hourly fees.Â  It is apparent from the record that Tillman grew frustrated with Grant, and this suit arose out of that frustration.
[5] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Rouse
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Tyrone Rouse, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-341
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 5, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, South Carolina Commission, of Columbia, for Appellant,
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, Cecil Kelly Jackson, Third Circuit Solicitor's Office, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tyrone Rouse appeals his convictions for armed robbery, kidnapping, and possessing a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Rouse argues the trial court should have directed a verdict of not guilty based on insufficient evidence.
FACTS
On November 5, 2001, four or five masked men entered a Burger King Restaurant in Sumter, South Carolina.Â  After closing time, the men entered through the restaurantâ€™s back door as one employee attempted to exit to take out the trash.Â  Once inside, the men held that employee on the floor, forced another employee inside the walk-in freezer, and held the manager at gunpoint while they stole over $4000. 
After the men left, the manager reported the robbery to the police. Â One patrol officer heard the call and drove around the area looking for any suspicious cars.Â  After a few minutes, he spotted a car with five occupants and began to follow the car.Â  He noticed that once his patrol car pulled up behind the car, all of the passengers appeared to slump down in their seats so as to not be seen. Â The car obeyed all traffic laws and stopped for over thirty seconds at stop signs, despite a lack of traffic.Â  Eventually, the car pulled into a driveway and as the officer stopped behind it, all of the carâ€™s occupants exited the vehicle and fled.Â  The patrol officer found, among other things, masks, a gun, and a cell phone in the car. Â During the ensuing investigation, police officers discovered a bank deposit bag, a Burger King deposit slip, some rolled quarters, and fingerprints on the carâ€™s interior and exterior.Â  
Months later, Marcus Wright, the employee who attempted to take the trash out during the Burger King robbery, was fired for stealing from the register.Â  That attempted theft apparently raised suspicion that Marcus was involved in the earlier robbery.Â  Two days later, the police arrested Marcus for his involvement as an accessory in the Burger King robbery.Â  After his arrest, Marcus gave a statement to police implicating Quinton Weldon, Samuel Dinkins, Aaron Rouse, and Tyrone Rouse in the Burger King robbery.Â  
At trial, Marcus Wright and Aaron Rouse, Tyrone Rouseâ€™s brother, testified that Tyrone participated in the robbery. Â Also at trial, Officer Brett Baker testified the police lifted Tyrone Rouseâ€™s fingerprints from the driverâ€™s side, side-view mirror of the get-away car.Â  
DISCUSSION
Tyrone Rouse argues the trial court erred in denying a motion for a directed verdict of not guilty based on insufficient evidence.Â  We disagree.
When analyzing the denial of a directed verdict motion, this Court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  â€œThe trial court, in a directed verdict motion, is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not with its weight.â€Â  State v. Elmore, 368 S.C. 230, 234, 628 S.E.2d 271, 273 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The trial court must be affirmed if the record contains any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Avery, 333 S.C. 284, 509 S.E.2d 476 (1998); State v. Williams, 303 S.C. 274, 400 S.E.2d 131 (1991).
â€œUnder the â€˜hand of one is the hand of allâ€™ theory of accomplice liability, one who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is criminally liable for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of the common design and purpose.â€Â  State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 194, 562 S.E.2d 320, 324 (Ct. App. 2002).
A.   Armed Robbery 
Tyrone Rouse was convicted of armed robbery, kidnapping, and possessing a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Armed robbery is a â€œrobbery while armed with a pistol, dirk, slingshot, metal knuckles, razor or other deadly weapon.â€Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330 (2003).Â  In addition, armed robbery is defined as a violent crime.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-60 (2006).Â  Burger Kingâ€™s manager, Robert Horton, as well as Amy Fullard, the employee who was trapped in the freezer, along with Marcus Wright and Aaron Rouse testified as eye witnesses that at least one gun was used in the robbery.Â  Police provided evidence at trial which tends to link Tyrone to this crime.Â  The officers found Tyroneâ€™s fingerprints on the outside of the get-away car as well as a gun and masks inside the car.Â  The subsequent investigation revealed a bank deposit slip, rolls of quarters similar to the ones stolen from the Burger King, and a bank deposit bag.Â  The trial court found a combination of direct evidence and substantial circumstantial evidence linking Tyrone Rouse to the robbery.
B. Kidnapping
Kidnapping is defined as a violent crime pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. Section 16-1-60 (2006).Â  A person is guilty of kidnapping if he unlawfully seizes, confines, inveigles, decoys, kidnaps, abducts, or carries away any other person by any means whatsoever without authority of law.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â  16-3-910 (2003).Â  Kidnapping â€œcommences when one is wrongfully deprived of freedom and continues until freedom is restored.â€Â  State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 13, 512 S.E.2d 99, 105 (1999); See State v. Vazsquez, 364 S.C. 293, 613 S.E.2d 359 (2005) (Vazsquez was found guilty of kidnapping after he forced two restaurant employees into the restaurantâ€™s freezer and closed the door).Â  At trial, Robert Horton, Amy Fullard, Marcus Wright, and Aaron Rouse testified that Amy was placed in the walk-in freezer with the door closed.Â  Thus, the trial court found direct evidence linking Tyrone Rouse to the kidnapping.
C. Possessing a Firearm During the Commission of a Violent Crime
Armed robbery and kidnapping are violent crimes pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. Section 16-1-60 (2006).Â  Because at least one gun was used to rob Burger King, the elements of possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime are satisfied.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490 (2003).Â  Robert Horton, Amy Fullard, Marcus Wright, and Aaron Rouse testified that a gun was used during the Burger King robbery. Â In addition, police found a gun, ski masks, and other evidence in the car used by the assailants after the robbery.Â  Again, the trial court found direct and substantial circumstantial evidence linking Tyrone Rouse to the crime of possessing a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.
CONCLUSION
The State presented direct evidence that Tyrone Rouse and his accomplices committed the crimes charged.Â  Under the â€œhand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory of accomplice liability, it makes no difference whether Tyrone Rouse was the person who actually held a gun or forced Amy Fullard into the freezer, as long as it is proven that one of his accomplices committed the act according to their common purpose. As to the armed robbery and possessing a firearm during the commission of a violent crime charges, the State provided circumstantial evidence in addition to direct evidence implicating Tyrone Rouse in the crimes.Â  Therefore, the trial court was justified in denying Rouseâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.Â  
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[1]Â 
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: SCDSS v. Doe and Roe
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Jane Doe, Richard Roe, and John Doe, Monte [DOB: 08/21/97], Adam [DOB: 03/23/99, David [DOB: 03/03/00], and Jordan [DOB: 05/01/01], minors under the age of 18,
Defendants,
Of whom Jane Doe and Richard Roe are Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
R. Wright Turbeville, Family Court Judge

AFFIRMED

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-342
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 11, 2006


  
    
      
Charles T. Brooks, III, of Sumter, for Appellant Jennifer Emelander.
William M. Oâ€™Bryan, Jr., of Kingstree, for Appellant Benjamin Mitchell.
Deborah T. Nielsen and Dwight C. Moore, of Sumter, for Respondent.
Eugene P. Corrigan, III, of Charleston, for Guardian Ad
Litem.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Â Jane Doe (Mother) and Richard Roe (Father) appeal the termination of their parental rights (TPR) to their minor children.[1]Â  We affirm.[2]  
FACTS
Mother and Father are the biological parents of three minor children.Â  Mother is also the parent of a fourth minor child, whose father is unknown and identified in these proceedings as John Doe.[3]Â  
On September 12, 2002, the parentsâ€™ two-year old son cut his arm on broken glass while playing unattended in the familyâ€™s yard.Â  The child received emergency treatment at a local hospital, which notified the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) that a possible child neglect situation existed.Â  DSS immediately investigated the family residence, where it discovered generally squalid and unsafe conditions.Â  DSS also found Mother was unable to control the children and was rearing them alone while Father remained incarcerated on pending charges related to his alleged rape of an eighty-year old woman. 
The family court held a removal hearing on September 13, 2002. Mother voluntarily placed the children in DSS custody and admitted exposing them to â€œa threat of harm of physical neglect.â€ The family court ordered a treatment plan requiring, among other things, that Mother provide a safe and stable home for the children, undergo a mental health assessment, secure stable employment, and complete anger management counseling.Â  The plan required both parents to undergo psychological evaluations to assess their parenting abilities, submit to substance abuse assessments, and repair and clean the family residence.Â  Additionally, the plan required the parents to successfully complete domestic violence counseling if they resumed cohabitation.Â  This order was not appealed.
In July 2003, Father was released from jail after his alleged victim died and the charges against him were subsequently dismissed.Â  He then moved back into the family residence, returned to work, and began participating in his treatment plan. Â In particular, he made improvements to the family residence to make it safer for the children, engaged in the required counseling, and submitted to drug screenings.
The family court returned physical custody of the children to the parents on February 9, 2004.Â  At the time, Mother and Father had made improvements to the family residence to make it safer for the children to inhabit.Â  However, the court found Mother was incapable of caring for the children alone and returned the children on the condition that Father be available to care for the children while at home.Â  Â Â 
On the evening of June 23, 2004, Father was stabbed while shooting pool at a local club. Â Thereafter, he was hospitalized for several days.Â  No other family members appeared genuinely willing to help Mother care for the children, so the parties agreed to return physical custody of the children to foster care.Â  Â Â 
Father tested positive for alcohol use in a September 2004 drug screening.Â  In December 2004, he tested positive for cocaine use in a hair follicle test.Â  He was charged with driving under the influence of alcohol (DUI) that same month and later pled guilty to the charge.Â  Mother abandoned her treatment plan in December 2004 and moved to Dalton, Georgia, where she had previously lived.Â  Father also abandoned his treatment plan.
DSS initiated the present action in February 2005.Â  A merits hearing on the TPR action took place on August 16, 2005.Â  At that hearing, DSS presented testimony from a psychologist, a foster care worker, and counselors familiar with the case.Â  Mother and Father testified.Â  The childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem also testified.
DSS provided the deposition of Dr. Robert W. Noelker, a clinical psychologist who examined Mother and Father shortly after the children were taken into DSS custody.Â  Dr. Noelker diagnosed Mother as a special needs adult with mild mental retardation and brain damage possibly caused by oxygen deprivation suffered when she was in a house fire as a small child.Â  He also diagnosed Mother with depression and anxiety.Â  Dr. Noelker added Mother was functionally and occupationally illiterate, with essentially no reading, spelling, or basic math skills.Â  He opined that, given Motherâ€™s â€œmultiple deficits,â€ she would â€œnever be able to independently parent her minor children,â€ regardless of rehabilitation provided by DSS.Â  Instead, Mother would â€œbe much like another child in home that would need direction and guidanceâ€ from another adult and â€œwould not be capable of providing meaningful daily regulation or interaction for her children.â€ Â Â 
Dr. Noelker diagnosed Father with polysubstance dependence and antisocial personality disorder.Â  He testified that a person with an antisocial personality disorder typically lacks a conscience, tends to be impulsive and self-interested, and tends to â€œrepetitively get into trouble with the law or social entities.â€Â  Dr. Noelker recommended that, at a minimum, Father secure adequate employment and engage in parent effectiveness classes, random drug and alcohol screening, outpatient substance abuse treatment, and outpatient psychotherapy.Â  However, given Fatherâ€™s extensive legal history and the tendency of those with antisocial personality disorder to resist change, Dr. Noelker predicted Father was â€œunlikely to be compliant and that his prognosis would continue to be poor.â€Â  
Janie Snow, a clinical counselor from the Williamsburg County Department on Alcohol and Drug Abuse, testified about treatment her agency provided Mother and Father.Â  According to Snow, her agencyâ€™s initial assessment of Mother indicated she was cocaine dependent.Â  Snow testified Mother successfully completed inpatient drug addiction treatment in the summer of 2003, and had not since tested positive for drug use.Â  However, Snow testified Motherâ€™s efforts at parenting classes, coupleâ€™s counseling, and anger management counseling were unsuccessful.Â  The agency stopped providing services to Mother when she threatened to kill Snow in September 2004.Â  Mother never successfully completed the counseling ordered by her treatment plan, according to Snow. Â Â 
Snow also testified about services Father received from her agency, and primarily chronicled Fatherâ€™s series of approximately forty drug screenings from May 2003 through December 2004.Â  Snow stated Father tested positive for alcohol in at least two screenings, with the most recent positive result occurring on September 24, 2004.Â  According to Snow, Father more often than not tested negatively for drug use.Â  On many occasions, however, the tests would yield a positive result at the screening site, but later yield a negative result when the same samples were tested again at an off-site lab.Â  Snow attributed the disparities to variances in testing techniques used, stating on-site testing would indicate positive results if â€œthere was any cocaine in [the subjectâ€™s] system,â€ but the off-site lab would not indicate a positive result unless the subject had a higher level of drugs in his system.Â  Regardless, off-site lab results from urine samples indicated Father tested positive for cocaine on at least three occasions, and a hair follicle test yielded a positive result for cocaine on December 1, 2004.Â  Snow testified Father stopped attending substance abuse counseling after being charged with DUI in December 2004.Â  Snowâ€™s agency continued to offer substance abuse counseling services to Father and notified him of counseling appointments.Â  However, Father failed to respond to the notices, and the agency consequently closed his file. 
Gloria Davis, the DSS foster care worker who handled the familyâ€™s case, testified that when she first visited the family residence, it smelled of urine and feces and was in a â€œstate of disrepairâ€ with broken windows and rotted flooring.Â  Davis testified the house had a broken toilet, refrigerator, and oven.Â  Flies and roaches crawled over a partially-eaten hamburger left on the kitchen counter, no linens were on the beds, and clothing was strewn on the floor, according to Davis.Â  She found almost no food in the house, although Mother received food stamps.Â  In the yard, Davis found broken glass and a dangerous fence with barbed wire.Â  
According to Davis, Mother â€œyelled and screamed at the children, cried uncontrollably, and had no . . . control over the children.â€Â  Davis testified the minor children knowingly controlled and manipulated Mother.Â  Father was their primary caretaker, Davis opined, because Mother was incapable of caring for them alone due to her mental disabilities and lack of family support.Â  Under the circumstances, returning the children to the parentsâ€™ custody depended on Fatherâ€™s availability to help rear the children.
Davis testified Father was initially unable to participate in his treatment program because he was incarcerated, but after his release he became â€œvigorously involvedâ€ in his treatment plan.Â  Among other things, he made necessary repairs to the family residence, resumed regular employment, submitted to a psychological evaluation, submitted to drug and alcohol abuse assessments, participated in mental health counseling and drug court, and successfully completed inpatient drug and alcohol rehabilitation.Â  However, she stated Father continued to test positive for drug use and failed to complete outpatient drug treatment, drug court, or mental health counseling.Â  In December 2004, Father was incarcerated over Christmas after his arrest for DUI, according to Davis.Â  She added Father had not since participated in the required drug testing or counseling.Â  According to Davis, Father continued to visit the children monthly and sometimes provide meals and entertainment.Â  
Davis indicated the conditions that led to the childrenâ€™s removal would not likely be remedied because Motherâ€™s problems were rooted in mental health issues that limited her ability to care for her children and no compelling evidence suggested her family or anyone else was forthcoming with the support needed.Â  Likewise, Fatherâ€™s condition impeded his ability to provide the support Mother needed to be a reliable parent independently.Â  Moreover, the parties separated and no evidence suggested a likelihood of reconciliation.Â Â  Davis opined terminating the parentsâ€™ rights to the minor children would be in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  
Sarah Reynolds, a registered nurse who served as a case manager and clinical counselor at the Waccamaw Center for Mental Health (Waccamaw), testified about mental health services Waccamaw provided Mother.Â  According to Reynolds, Mother was first referred to Waccamaw by DSS for Family Preservation counseling.Â  Reynolds testified Mother was diagnosed as being mildly mentally retarded, but Motherâ€™s initial treatment was cancelled because of her unwillingness to participate.Â  The drug court later referred Mother for additional counseling and psychiatric treatment.Â  Reynolds characterized Motherâ€™s compliance with Waccamawâ€™s services as â€œunpredictable,â€ noting Mother cancelled appointments and failed to properly take psychiatric medication prescribed under her treatment plan.Â  For example, she once flushed the medicine down a toilet and on another occasion overdosed on the medicine in a failed suicide attempt.Â  Waccamaw stopped treating Mother when she moved to Georgia in December 2004, Reynolds stated.Â  She opined Mother would need mental health treatment â€œindefinitelyâ€ and 24-hour a day help rearing the children, â€œbecause if she has an outburst anything could possibly happen that may be harmful to herself or others.â€Â  
Mother testified on her own behalf.Â  She expressed a love for her children and described their removal as a â€œnightmare.â€Â  She testified that she lived in an apartment in Dalton, Georgia, where she regularly spent time with her parents, siblings, and friends.Â  Mother testified she remained drug free but she had otherwise been unable to get her life back on track. 
Father testified he had taken numerous steps to regain custody of his children, including securing steady employment and repairing the family residence to make it safer for the children.Â  He stated he took the children on outings, provided occasional meals and gifts, and sometimes gave the foster parent money.Â  However, he admittedly stopped complying with his treatment plan in January 2005 based on his belief that DSS had arranged to place the children with Motherâ€™s family in Georgia.Â  
Father admitted he was addicted to drugs and alcohol but denied having used cocaine since approximately December 2004.Â  Father claimed he was attending counseling sessions to help him deal with both problems, but later admitted he had only been to one counseling session in the previous eight months.Â  Father admitted using cocaine shortly after his release from jail on the dismissed rape charges.Â  Father also admitted using cocaine in November or December of 2004, but disputed the results of the hair follicle test that indicated he used cocaine in December 2004.Â  When asked about numerous positive results he received on some of his random drug screenings, Father attempted to excuse the results as a health condition. Â Â 
Father testified regarding his past legal woes, offering excuses for charges he had faced in the past.Â  Among other things, he testified to spending time in jail for rape charges that were dropped, a DUI charge to which he pled guilty, and charges he had stolen approximately $14,000 from his grandfather, which were also dropped.Â  He also admitted he was jailed on a bench warrant for failing to pay court fines related to his DUI.Â  Â Â 
Father also testified about his stabbing, which he claimed occurred at a club where he was playing pool and drinking non-alcoholic beer while waiting to conduct business with the clubâ€™s owner.Â  According to Father, a woman with whom he was playing pool stabbed him.Â  Father indicated the woman harbored anger toward him because on the previous day Father had intervened in an altercation between the woman and her boyfriend.Â  
The childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem, Bennett McCollough, described the children as being â€œa handful,â€ and noted they had been diagnosed with â€œhyperactive attention deficiency.â€Â  He opined that the children loved their parents, but they also loved their foster mother and referred to her as â€œmother.â€Â  McCullough testified the children were â€œsadâ€ for Mother and â€œrecognized that she was not able to control them.â€Â  He added that Father was capable of caring for the children â€œif he would stay out of troubleâ€ and not abuse drugs, but advised he would not recommend giving Father additional time to pursue a treatment plan.Â  McCullough testified he believed the children were better off living with their foster mother, and that neither of their natural parents could provide the stability the children needed.Â  McCullough specifically testified terminating Mother and Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in the best interests of the children. 
On September 9, 2005, the family court issued an order terminating the parental rights of Mother and Father.Â  The court based its termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights on findings of neglect too severe and repetitious to likely be remedied within six months; failure to remedy the conditions leading to the childrenâ€™s removal by successfully completing counseling specified in her treatment plan; and the fact that she had been diagnosed with conditions of mental retardation, adjustment disorder, anxiety, and depression that prevented her from competently parenting her children alone and her diagnosed conditions would not likely change within a reasonable time.Â  The family court terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights on the basis of neglect too severe and repetitious to likely be remedied within six months; failure to remedy the conditions leading to the childrenâ€™s removal by successfully completing counseling specified in his treatment plan; and the fact that he had been diagnosed with conditions of drug dependency and antisocial behavior that rendered him incapable of providing minimally acceptable care for the minor children and his condition was not likely to change within a reasonable time because he had stopped drug counseling months earlier.Â  The family court also terminated their parental rights based on its finding that the minor children had been in foster care under DSS custody for at least fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months.Â  Finally, the court found terminating Mother and Fatherâ€™s parental rights to be in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  These consolidated appeals followed.Â  Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR action, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before parental rights can be forever terminated, the alleged grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v. Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 357, 296 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1982); S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we should not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court, because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony. Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
DISCUSSION
I.  Motherâ€™s Appeal 

A.  Adequacy of Motherâ€™s Treatment Plan

Mother argues the family court erred in finding she failed to complete her treatment plan. Specifically, Mother alleges the plan was â€œinadequate given the circumstancesâ€ because it required her to rely on assistance from third parties. Â She also argues that when DSS learned of her diagnosed conditions it should have modified her treatment plan to enable her to successfully complete the plan.Â  We disagree. 
As an initial matter, we note Mother never made this argument before the family court, so the issue is arguably unpreserved for appellate review. See Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 369, 489 S.E.2d 212, 217 (Ct. App. 1997) (stating an issue must be
raised to and ruled on by the family court to be preserved for appellate review). Instead, the record indicates she continuously agreed to the treatment plan as defined at the initial removal hearing and as later modified.Â  The relevant orders reflect Mother agreed to the treatment planâ€™s terms, found the treatment plan complied with statutory requirements, and was â€œfair, equitable, reasonable, and . . . in the best interests of the minor children.â€Â  Furthermore, the family court consistently used â€œreasonableâ€ to describe DSSâ€™s efforts to help Mother remedy the problems that caused the childrenâ€™s removal.Â  Because Mother agreed to the terms of the treatment plan and never challenged them at the trial level, she consequently waived the right to challenge the planâ€™s terms on appeal. 
Assuming Motherâ€™s issue is preserved, we, nevertheless, find it lacks merit. Â Mother argues the treatment plan was deficient because it made her ability to comply with the plan â€œcontingent upon the actions of third partiesâ€ such as Father and her family. Â Although Motherâ€™s love for her children is beyond question and her circumstances are tragic, the record contains ample evidence supporting the family courtâ€™s finding that Mother could not competently rear the children alone.Â  In particular, Dr. Noelker testified Mother would never be able to provide minimally acceptable care for her minor children without â€œa functional and capable adult to assist her on a daily basis.â€Â  Testimony from Davis and McCullough also support the courtâ€™s finding that Mother could not independently care for the children.Â  Additionally, Father opined at trial that Mother could not care for the children alone. Â Mother did not dispute their testimony at trial, nor does she challenge their veracity on appeal. Â 
We note DSS unsuccessfully attempted to place the children with Motherâ€™s relatives in Georgia, but social services workers there investigated the relativesâ€™ homes and found they had no serious interest in helping Mother care for the children. Â Moreover, the Georgia authorities stated the home of the childrenâ€™s maternal grandparents was not an appropriate place for the children to be placed because a child had previously been removed from their home following abuse and neglect allegations, and the grandparents were unable to make the changes needed to regain custody.
Accordingly, we find Motherâ€™s treatment plan reasonable, and the family court did not err in terminating her parental rights for failing to complete the treatment plan.[4] Â 

 B.  Best Interests of the Children

Mother also alleges the court erred in finding termination of her parental rights was in the minor childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  She generally speculates the termination â€œcould be proved to be very harmful to the childrenâ€ and â€œis the equivalent of â€˜killing the motherâ€™ whom they presumably love and share a bond.â€Â  Without questioning Motherâ€™s love for her children, we find the record includes ample evidence to support the family courtâ€™s finding that terminating her parental rights is in her minor childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  In addition to the recommendations of her DSS counselor and the childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem, we find it clear from the record that Mother is not capable of providing the level of care needed by the children.Â  Their foster mother of three years undisputedly provided the level of care they needed, and testimony shows they have bonded with her and respond more positively to her parenting.Â  The evidentiary record demonstrates that the family court did not err in terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights.
II.  Fatherâ€™s Appeal
Father argues the family court erred in terminating his parental rights on the grounds that (1) he failed to remedy conditions that led to their removal, (2) failed to support the children, (3) had a diagnosable condition that prevented him from providing minimally acceptable care to the children, and that was not likely to change within a reasonable period of time; and (4) the children had been in DSS foster care custody for at least fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months.Â  He does not dispute the courtâ€™s finding that terminating his parental rights is in the best of interests of his minor children.

A.  Failure to Remedy 

Father contends the childrenâ€™s removal was predicated on factors that occurred while he was incarcerated, to wit:Â  the condition of the family residence and physical neglect of the minor children.Â  Father maintains that after he was released, he made necessary repairs to the residence and â€œsubstantially completed other aspects of his treatment plan.â€Â  Consequently, Father argues the family court erred in terminating his parental rights for failing to remedy conditions that led to their removal.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
It is undisputed that Father complied with his treatment plan to the extent he maintained stable employment and made necessary physical repairs and improvements to the family residence.Â  However, the treatment plan also required parent effectiveness classes, negative results on random drug and alcohol screenings, and counseling to address issues related to Fatherâ€™s diagnosed conditions of drug abuse and antisocial personality disorder.Â  Father concedes he ceased all required counseling shortly after testing positive for cocaine use in a hair follicle test and being charged with DUI in December 2004, but argues he â€œsubstantially completedâ€ the counseling components of his treatment plan.Â  We do not find this argument compelling.Â  In particular, we note Dr. Noelker described the treatment plan recommendations as â€œbasically minimum recommendations that would be required in order to consider reunificationâ€ of Father with his minor children.Â  Although Father made progress in many aspects of his treatment plan, he clearly relapsed in December 2004 and essentially abandoned his treatment plan from that time forward.

B.  Failure to Support 

Father maintains the family court erred in terminating his parental rights on the basis that he failed to support his children, because he was never ordered to pay child support, but nevertheless made a material contribution to the children by providing in-kind support of gifts, meals, clothing, money, and entertainment.Â  We disagree.
As an initial matter, it is not clear from the order that the family court terminated Fatherâ€™s grounds on this basis.Â  Â In paragraph fifteen of its order, the family court provided:

The Defendant minor children have been harmed as defined in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490[(2)](c) in that [Father] failed to supply adequate food, clothing, shelter, education, supervision, or health care though financially able to do so or offered financial or other reasonable means to do so, and because of the severity or repetition of the neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve (12) months. 

(Emphasis added).Â  This language suggests the court is terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights under section 20-7-490(1) of the South Carolina Code, which provides for TPR where a child has been neglected, and because of the severity or repetition of the neglect, the court deems it reasonably unlikely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.Â  However, paragraph fifteen concludes with a specific reference to section 20-7-1572(4) of the South Carolina Code, which provides grounds for termination for willful failure to provide material support to oneâ€™s child. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (Supp. 2005). Also, the â€œneglectâ€ referenced by the family court largely related to support issues, such as providing food, clothing, and shelter.
 Regardless, we find the family court properly granted TPR on either basis, both of which were raised in DSSâ€™s pleadings.Â  First, Father does not specifically dispute the family courtâ€™s order that his failure to provide adequate food, clothing, shelter, education, supervision, or health care constituted neglect.Â  Thus, it is the law of the case.Â  See Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 300, 513 S.E.2d 358, 369 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating in TPR action an unchallenged ruling by the family court becomes law of the case).Â  Instead, Father focuses his argument on whether the contributions he made to the children rise to the level of a â€œmaterial contributionâ€ sufficient to overcome TPR under section 20-7-1572(4).Â  
 A â€œmaterial contributionâ€ is defined as â€œeither financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4).Â  â€œToys are not included in this definition and will not be considered by us in concluding whether Appellant made a material contribution to Children.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Seegars, 367 S.C. 623, 630, 627 S.E.2d 718, 722 (2006).Â  Here, the record indicates Father was gainfully employed but at most only occasionally provided the children meals and gave them games and â€œlittle nick nack stuff.â€Â  The record includes no evidence that Father provided clothing or other necessities to the children during their stay in DSS custody, except for Fathersâ€™ testimony that he had sporadically given the foster parent money for the children.Â  However, Father testified that, at the time of the hearing, he had not â€œreally financially [been] contributingâ€ to the children because he was making repairs to his house, which had been damaged by a kitchen fire.Â  He also admitted having recently purchased end tables, lamps, and â€œa new leather setâ€ of furniture for his home.Â  Based on the forgoing evidence, we find Father had the means to make a material contribution to his children but willfully failed to provide such support.

C.  Diagnosable Condition 

Father argues the family court erred in terminating his parental rights on the basis that he had a diagnosable condition that rendered him unable to provide minimally acceptable care for his minor children, and that the condition was unlikely to change in a reasonable period of time.Â  We disagree.
Dr. Noelker diagnosed Father as being drug dependent and having an antisocial personality disorder, and opined both conditions rendered him incapable of providing minimally adequate care to his minor children.Â  The family court subsequently approved a treatment plan based on what Dr. Noelker described as â€œbasically minimum recommendations that would be required to consider reunification.â€Â  Father does not dispute his failure to successfully complete the entire treatment program.Â  Instead, he argues he completed necessary repairs to the family residence and otherwise substantially completed the program.Â  He focuses his argument primarily on drug screenings, arguing the â€œgreat majorityâ€ of his test results were negative or â€œquestionable.â€Â  However, he does not dispute testing positive for cocaine use in a hair follicle test in December 2004, testing positive for alcohol use as late as September 2004, and driving under the influence of alcohol in December 2004.Â  Additionally, we note Father stated at the hearing that he was an â€œaddictâ€ and admitted using cocaine more than two years after the children were removed from the home.Â  Father admittedly, voluntarily discontinued his counseling in December 2004, with the exception of attending one or two counseling sessions between that time and the TPR hearing.
Based on the record, and in particular Fatherâ€™s testimony, we find while he might have initially made progress in his treatment planâ€™s drug counseling provisions, he clearly had a relapse in December 2004 and subsequently stopped attending drug court and engaging in counseling.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court did not err in terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights for having a diagnosable condition not likely to change in a reasonable period of time.

D.  Duration of DSS Foster Care Custody 

Fatherâ€™s final argument alleges the family court erred in terminating his parental rights on the ground that his minor children had been in foster care for at least fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months, as permitted by section 20-7-1572(8) of the South Carolina Code.Â  We disagree.
Father does not dispute that his minor children had been in DSS foster care for at least fifteen of the twenty-two months preceding the TPR hearing in August 2005.Â  Instead, he argues physical custody of the children was resumed by DSS in June 2004 because of circumstances over which he had â€œno controlâ€:Â  his stabbing and subsequent hospitalization that removed him from the home and left the children alone in Motherâ€™s care.Â  But for this unfortunate event, Father speculates the children would have likely remained in the home and DSS involvement would not have continued for a period sufficient to provide a basis for termination under section 20-7-1572(8).Â  We find this argument unavailing.
The record indicates the family court based the February 2004 physical reunification of the children and parents on the strength of Fatherâ€™s parenting abilities and because he was the childrenâ€™s primary caretaker.Â  Among other things, the family court prohibited the parents from allowing Mother to care for the children alone, and conditioned their return on Fatherâ€™s availability to care for the children.Â  Although obviously aware of the importance of being available to care for his children, Father voluntarily exposed himself to potential physical harm by breaking up a bar fight and later socializing with one of the people who had engaged in the fight.Â  Father was not merely a hapless stabbing victim, but instead exercised poor judgment and placed himself in harmâ€™s way.Â  Thus, we find the unfortunate circumstances that resulted in Fatherâ€™s hospitalization, and his childrenâ€™s consequential return to foster care, were substantially within Fatherâ€™s control.Â  Moreover, we note the record indicates DSS regained physical custody of the children with Fatherâ€™s consent after he was hospitalized and left only Mother to care for them.Â  Â 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we find the family court did not err in terminating Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s parental rights to their respective minor children.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]  Mother and Father brought separate appeals, which this court consolidated in October 2005.Â  
[2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]  The family court also terminated John Doeâ€™s parental rights, but that portion of the courtâ€™s order is not a subject of this appeal.
[4]  We also note Mother does not dispute the family courtâ€™s finding that she failed to complete portions of her treatment plan that did not require assistance from a third party in rearing her children, including drug court, drug and alcohol counseling, anger management counseling, and her psychiatric drug regimen.Â  Furthermore, she does not dispute the family courtâ€™s termination of her parental rights on other grounds.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State Respondent,
v.
        Dwight Fitzgerald Jones Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-343
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland; and Solicitor W. Barney Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Â Â Dwight Fitzgerald Jones appeals his conviction for murder and assault and battery with intent to kill.Â  Jones argues the trial judge abused his discretion by disregarding Jonesâ€™ request to proceed pro se.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On February 25, 2001, an altercation at a sports bar in Richland County resulted in gunfire, leaving one dead and three wounded.Â  As a result, Jones was charged with murder and three counts of assault and battery with intent to kill.Â  During an in camera, ex parte hearing at the outset of his trial, Jones expressed dissatisfaction that his counsel had been unable to locate several potential witnesses he believed would be helpful to his case.Â  Jones asked for a continuance so that his family might hire a private investigator or attorney to attempt to track down these potential witnesses.Â  The court denied this request.Â  During this hearing, Jones also verbalized disagreement with his attorneyâ€™s decision not to call a particular witness. Â In response, his lawyer offered strategic reasons why Jonesâ€™ best interest might not be served by bringing this person to the stand.Â  The judge expressed agreement, and Jones indicated that he understood and was satisfied with the explanation.
Later in the trial, another in camera, ex parte discussion was held.Â  Jonesâ€™ counsel informed the court:

My client indicates to me that he continues to have dissatisfaction with the way that the case is proceeding and with me.Â  He indicated a moment ago that he might like to just switch and be the one to ask questions of the witnesses himself.
We had a discussion about the way things are going and he has become increasingly unhappy with me and I â€¦ think he wishes to address the court.

Jones stated discontent with his lawyerâ€™s cross-examination of several witnesses who had identified Jones as the shooter.Â  He presented several specific examples of questions he believed should have been asked and that he had suggested to his attorney during the trial.Â  In response, his counsel elucidated her reasoning and strategy and pointed out that some of the questions Jones mentioned had in fact been asked.Â  The court averred as to the risks presented by many Jonesâ€™ recommendations for cross-examination and noted it is difficult for an attorney to take suggestions from his or her client, when at the same time, he or she is listening to the opposing sideâ€™s direct examination.
The judge went so far as to ask directly, â€œWhat is it that you want me to do?â€ Â Jones gave no answer but merely replied with a continuation of his complaint regarding questions that had not been asked. Â The court then stated, â€œYou certainly have the right to represent yourself â€¦ but I think youâ€™d be ill-served by making that choice.Â  But if you continue to have problems, I certainly will be glad to hear from you if you want to proceed on your own, okay?â€Â  Jonesâ€™ responded, â€œOkay, thank you.â€[2]Â  At no point in this discussion or at any time during the trial did Jones move or even indicate that he wished to appear pro se.
The jury found Jones guilty of all four counts.Â  He was sentenced to thirty years for murder and five years imprisonment for each of the three counts of assault and battery with intent to kill.
DISCUSSION
On appeal, Jones argues the trial court erred by denying his request to proceed pro se.Â  We disagree.Â  
A defendant has a constitutional right to self-representation under the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments.Â  Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806, 807, 95 S.Ct. 2525, 2527 (1975).Â  â€œAlthough a defendantâ€™s decision to proceed pro se may be to the defendantâ€™s own detriment, it â€˜must be honored out of that respect for the individual which is the lifeblood of the law.â€™ â€Â  State v. Brewer, 328 S.C. 117, 492 S.E.2d 97 (1997) (quoting Faretta, 422 U.S. at 834, 95 S.Ct. at 2541).Â  This right, however, is not unfettered.Â  While this court has held that one â€œmay surrender his right to counsel through (1) waiver by affirmative, verbal request; (2) waiver by conduct; and (3) forfeiture,â€Â  State v. Thompson, 355 S.C. 255, 262, 584 S.E.2d 131, 134 (Ct. App. 2003),Â  the right to proceed pro se must be clearly asserted prior to trial.Â  State v. Brewer, 328 SC 117, 492 S.E.2d 97 (1997); United States v. Lorick, 753 F.2d 1295, 1298 (4th Cir. 1985).Â  
There is nothing in the record to indicate that Jones ever requested self-representation, let alone did so in manner that could be interpreted as a clear assertion the right.Â  Jones contends he motioned to appear pro se when his lawyer made the previously quoted statement regarding Jonesâ€™ dissatisfaction with his counsel, which included the remark, â€œhe [Jones] might like to just switch and be the one to ask questions of the witnesses himself.â€Â  
Besides expressing his unhappiness with his attorney, this colloquy merely mentions that Jones â€œmight likeâ€ to represent himself.Â  The circumstances and ensuing inquiry allowed the judge to see that Jones concerns were properly addressed and conclude that he was not requesting to proceed pro se.Â  This query was proper, for the trial judge has the responsibility to ensure that the accused is informed of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation and that he makes a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to counsel.Â  Faretta, 422 U.S. at 835, 95 S.Ct. at 2541; Dixon, 269 S.C. 107 236 S.E.2d 419 (1977).Â  Additionally, the judge was correct in not concluding this statement to be a waiver of the Sixth Amendment right to counsel, as â€œ[t]he courts indulge every reasonable presumption against waiver of fundamental constitutional rights, and do not presume acquiescence in the loss of fundamental rights. Â Thompson, 355 S.C. at 262, 584 S.E.2d at 134 (citing, Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U.S. 458, 464, 58 S.Ct. 1019, 1023 (1938); Pitts v. North Carolina, 395 F.2d 182, 188 (4th Cir. 1968).
Even in the event the conversation at issue amounted to a definite motion to proceed pro se, based on the timing of the issue being raised, denial of the request was not an abuse of discretion by the court.Â  The right to represent oneself must be asserted by the defendant before the trial begins.Â  State v. Sims, 304 S.C. 409, 415, 405 S.E.2d 377, 381 (1991); United States v. Lorick, 753 F.2d 1295, 1298 (4th Cir. 1985).Â  â€œIf the request to proceed pro se is made after the trial has begun, the grant or denial of the right to proceed pro se rests within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  State v. Fuller, 337 S.C. 236, 241, 523 S.E.2d 168, 170 (1999) (citing United States v. Singleton, 107 F.3d 1091 (4th Cir. 1997); United States v. Lawrence, 605 F.2d 1321 (4th Cir. 1979)).Â  As there may be a variety of reasons which might excuse a last minute request by a defendant to proceed pro se, it is thus â€œincumbent upon the trial court to determine whether the request is made for purposes of delay or to gain tactical advantage, and whether the lateness of the request may hinder the administration of justice.â€ Â Fuller, 337 S.C. at 241, 523 S.E.2d at 170-171 (citing and quoting People v. Mogul, 812 P.2d 705 (Colo. Ct. App. 1991) (internal citations omitted).Â  There is nothing in the record to indicate that the judge abused his discretion in refusing any motion to appear pro se that may have been made.
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, Jonesâ€™ convictions are 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The trial record actually stops at the end of the judgeâ€™s question, thus cutting off Jones reply.Â  However, his response is provided in the Stateâ€™s brief to this court.Â  Jones makes no challenge as to the factual accuracy of this information.

The South Carolina Court of Appeals


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Eddie Thomas Jackson, Appellant,
v.
The State of South Carolina,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-344
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Eddie Thomas Jackson, of Bennettsville, pro se Appellant. 
Attorney General Henry McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott and Assistant Attorney General Karen Christine Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Eddie Jackson appeals the dismissal of his petition for a writ of habeas corpus.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 1998, Jackson was indicted for trafficking in cocaine. Â He pled guilty to possession with intent to distribute cocaine. Â In 2004, Jackson filed in the circuit court a petition seeking a writ of habeas corpus arguing that his conviction was the result of police corruption, that he had not been adequately advised of his rights during his guilty plea, and that he was convicted of a crime for which he had not been indicted by a grand jury. Â The circuit court dismissed Jacksonâ€™s petition.Â 



    LAW/ANALYSIS 
The case of Gibson v. State, 329 S.C. 37, 495 S.E.2d 426 (1998), discussed at length the law concerning writs of habeas corpus and when such petitions should be dismissed or granted.Â  

The availability of habeas corpus has been severely limited by the [South Carolina] Uniform Post Conviction Procedure Act (Act).Â  The Act â€œtakes the place of all other common law, statutory or other remedies heretofore available for challenging the validity of the conviction or sentence.â€ Â It shall be used exclusively in place of them.Â  Thus, [the] Act supersedes and encompasses the habeas corpus procedure provided by statute.Â  However, habeas corpus continues to be available as a constitutional remedy
provided a petitioner qualifies for this extraordinary relief and clears the procedural hurdles.

Habeas corpus is available only when other remedies, such as PCR, are inadequate or
unavailable . . . However, a petitioner who does not raise an issue which could have been raised in a prior PCR hearing will waive his right to raise this issue in a subsequent application.Â  Procedurally, a petitioner seeking habeas corpus must first exhaust all available PCR remedies.Â  Exhaustion includes filing of an application, the rendering of an order adjudicating the issues, and petitioning for, or knowingly waiving, appellate review.Â  Further, petitioner must allege sufficient facts to show why other remedies, such as PCR, are unavailable or inadequate.

Id. at 40-42, 495 S.E.2d at 427-28 (citations omitted).Â  â€œA person is procedurally barred from petitioning the circuit court for a writ of habeas corpus where the matter alleged is one which could have been raised in a PCR application.â€Â  Keeler v. Mauney, 330 S.C. 568, 571, 500 S.E.2d 123, 124 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
In the present case, Jackson admits he did not file a direct appeal and does not allege that any prior PCR applications have been filed.Â  Consequently, he has not set forth facts that allow him to overcome the procedural bar providing for dismissal of his writ.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the judgment of the trial court is
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] 
We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
