In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
v.
Ernest J. Alcantara and ABC Bonding Company, Inc.,
Defendants,
of whom ABC Bonding Company, Inc. is the Appellant.
AND
The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
v.
Pablo Alcantara, and ABC Bonding Company, Inc.,
Defendants,
of whom ABC Bonding Company, Inc. is the Appellant.
AND
The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
v.
Jose Hernandez and ABC Bonding Company Inc., Defendants,
of whom ABC Bonding Company Inc. is the Appellant.
AND
The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
v.
Marko Marshall and ABC Bonding Company, Inc., Defendants,
of whom ABC Bonding Company, Inc. is the Appellant.
AND
The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
v.
Nathaniel Stevenson, III, and ABC Bonding Company, Inc.,
Defendants,
of whom ABC Bonding Company, Inc. is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-345
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 16, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrew F. Litvin, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Solicitor Elizabeth O. Levy and Mary Cecelia Robinson, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This case is an appeal from a bond estreatment hearing involving numerous defendants.[1] Â ABC Bonding Company, Inc. (hereinafter ABC) appeals from orders of the circuit court estreating, in whole or in part, one bond each on defendants Ernest Alcantara, Pablo Alcantara, Jose Hernandez, and Marko Marshall, and two separate bonds on Nathaniel Stevenson, III. Â ABC argues, as to each defendantsâ€™ order of estreatment, the circuit court erred in failing to grant the company a continuance.Â  ABC further argues, as to the orders concerning the Alcantaras, Marshall, and Stevenson, the court erred in ordering the amounts estreated on each bond based on the minimal cost to the State of the failure of the defendants to appear. Â We affirm as to each of the bond estreatment orders.[2]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On July 27, 2005, the circuit court held a bond estreatment hearing in
regard to bonds involving the above named defendants. Â Appearing on behalf of ABC Bonding was the companyâ€™s attorney, as well as ABCâ€™s investigator, Mr. Jim Sims.Â  At the start of the hearing, while discussing defendant Ernest Alcantara, ABCâ€™s attorney noted he had previously â€œexplained the circumstancesâ€ to the court, and Mr. Sims was available if the court wished to question him.Â  Thereafter, ABCâ€™s attorney stated, â€œAs I explained earlier, Your Honor, I donâ€™t have the full file on this.â€Â  As the situations involving each of the defendants were discussed, counsel for ABC noted, as he had previously explained, his client was not fully prepared to proceed with the cases.Â  
The matter went forward, and the court ordered the full $55,000 each of Ernest Alcantaraâ€™s and Pablo Alcantaraâ€™s bonds be estreated.Â  He further ordered that $1,000 be estreated on Hernandezâ€™s $2,400 bond, $2,000 be estreated on Marshallâ€™s $25,000 bond, and the full amounts of $5,000 and $3,000 be estreated on Stevensonâ€™s two bonds.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from a decision on the forfeiture or remission of a bail bond, the appellate court reviews the circuit courtâ€™s ruling for an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. McClinton, 369 S.C. 167, 631 S.E.2d 895 (2006).Â  

An abuse of discretion occurs when the circuit courtâ€™s ruling is based upon an error of law, such as application of the wrong legal principle; or, when based upon factual conclusions, the ruling is without evidentiary support; or, when the circuit court is vested with discretion, but the ruling reveals no discretion was exercised; or when the ruling does not fall within the range of permissible decisions applicable in a particular case, such that it may be deemed arbitrary and capricious.Â  

Id. (citing Fontaine v. Peitz, 291 S.C. 536, 539, 354 S.E.2d 565, 566 (1987); S.E.C. v. TheStreet.Com, 273 F.3d 222, 229 n.6 (2d Cir. 2001)). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Continuance
We first address ABCâ€™s contention as to each of the six bond matters, that the circuit court abused its discretion in denying ABCâ€™s request for a continuance.Â  ABC argues the circuit court abused its discretion in refusing to grant ABCâ€™s request for a continuance of the hearing where counsel for ABC informed the court his client was recovering from a kidney transplant.Â  Specifically, ABC contends that, prior to the hearing, counsel requested a continuance based on the fact that the owner of ABC had just undergone a kidney transplant resulting in the ownerâ€™s inability to appear at the hearing and counselâ€™s inability to consult with the owner on the matter.Â  ABC maintains the request was made at a sidebar conference to protect the privacy of the owner of ABC.Â  It further asserts that the court ordered counsel to proceed with the hearing despite the ownerâ€™s absence and, when informed Mr. Sims was present in court but counsel had not had an opportunity to consult with Mr. Sims either, the court again ordered the hearing to proceed.Â  
We find this issue as to all six of the bonds in question is not preserved for our review.Â  While the record shows ABCâ€™s counsel stated he was not ready to proceed and made reference to a previous discussion, nowhere in the transcript does counsel move for a continuance, nor does he state the basis for a request for continuance.Â  Indeed, by way of brief, ABC indicates these matters were addressed in a sidebar and not on the record.Â  Because the motion for continuance was made during an off-the-record conference and was not made part of the record, the matter is not preserved for review.Â  See York v. Conway Ford, Inc., 325 S.C. 170, 173, 480 S.E.2d 726, 728 (1997) (holding an objection made during an off-the-record conference which is not made part of the record will not preserve the issue for review).Â  In addition, the fact that the circuit court may have acknowledged a discussion on the matter was held off-the-record does not preserve the matter for review.Â  See State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 258, 609 S.E.2d 572, 591(Ct. App. 2005) (noting an issue is not preserved for appeal merely because the trial judge mentions it).
II.Â  Failure to consider costs to the StateÂ Â  
ABC next contends the circuit court abused its discretion in ordering estreatment of the full $55,000 on each of the Alcantarasâ€™s bonds, $2,000 on Marshallâ€™s $25,000 bond, and the full amounts of $5,000 and $3,000 on Stevensonâ€™s two bonds.Â  ABC asserts the circuit court erred in failing to consider the costs to the State in reaching its decision as to estreatment on these bonds. [3]Â  
The record shows, in addressing some of the bonds, counsel for ABC requested the circuit court consider costs expended by the State in attempting to recover the defendants, as costs was one of the factors the court should consider in determining remission of the bond. Â Counsel argued that, in a forfeiture matter, the court should take into consideration the economic loss to the State.Â  The trial judge replied that economic loss was â€œnot the only factorâ€ to consider.
The issue of whether a bond forfeiture should be remitted, and if so, to what extent, is vested in the discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Workman, 274 S.C. 341, 343, 263 S.E.2d 865, 866 (1980);Â  State v. Holloway, 262 S.C. 552, 557, 206 S.E.2d 822, 824 (1974).Â  In determining whether and to what extent a bond should be remitted, the trial court should at least consider the following factors:Â  (1) the purpose of the bond;Â  (2) the nature and willfulness of the default;Â  (3) any prejudice or additional expense resulting to the State.Â  State v. Boatwright, 310 S.C. 281, 287, 423 S.E.2d 139, 142-43 (1992) (Toal, J., dissenting).Â  In making a determination as to remission of the judgment on a forfeited bond, â€œthe court shall consider the costs to the State or any county or municipality resulting from the necessity to continue or terminate the defendantâ€™s trial and the efforts of law enforcement officers or agencies to locate the defendant.â€Â  S. C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-70 (Supp. 2005).Â  
In Ex Parte Polk, 354 S.C. 8, 11-12, 579 S.E.2d 329, 330-31 (Ct. App. 2003), this court held, because section 38-53-70 unambiguously provides that the trial court must consider the costs to the State in determining remission of the judgment on a forfeited bond, the circuit courtâ€™s refusal to consider costs as requested amounted to an abuse of discretion.Â  In the matters at hand, however, the circuit court did not refuse to consider costs to the State.Â  Rather, the court specifically acknowledged it was to consider costs as well as other factors in determining possible remission of the Alcantarasâ€™ bonds.Â  Under the facts of this case, we cannot say the circuit court abused its discretion by refusing to consider costs to the State in ordering the amounts estreated on each of the bonds in question.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
In conclusion, we hold, because ABC failed to place a motion for continuance on the record, this issue is procedurally barred as to all of the named defendantsâ€™ bonds.Â  We further find no abuse of discretion in the orders of estreatment as to the Ernest and Pablo Alcantara, Marko Marshall, and Nathaniel Stevenson bonds.Â  Accordingly, the orders below are
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Because these matters were heard at the same time, in the same hearing, resulting in the same transcript, and involve the same issues, we have consolidated these cases on appeal.Â  See Rule 214, SCACR (â€œWhere there is more than one appeal from the same order, judgment, or decree, or where the same question is involved in two or more appeals in different cases, the appellate court may, in its discretion, order the appeal to be consolidated.â€).
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] ABC does not challenge the $1,000 estreated on the $2,400 Hernandez bond, but only challenges the courtâ€™s failure to grant a continuance in that matter.Â

title: Nash v. Wright
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Mary Ann B. Nash and Nancy B. Clifford, Respondents,
v.
Lynette B. Wright, individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of
R.B. Brunson, Deceased, Appellant.
In Re:Â  Estate of R.B. Brunson, Deceased.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-346
Submitted October 10, 2006 â€“ Filed October 16, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Gary W. Crawford, of Florence, for Appellant.
David W. Keller, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this will contest action, Lynette Wright, individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of her father R.B. Brunson, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order remanding the case to the probate court for further consideration of the issue of Wrightâ€™s fiduciary relationship with her father as it applies to her sistersâ€™ claim of undue influence.Â  We reverse and remand.[1]  
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Brunson passed away on December 22, 2002, at the age of 91.Â  He was survived by his three daughters, Wright and the plaintiffs in this case, Mary Ann B. Nash and Nancy B. Clifford.Â  In 1998, Wright had moved from Hawaii back to Darlington County to live with and take care of her parents.Â  Brunson executed a general durable power of attorney naming Wright as his attorney in fact in June of 1999.Â  On September 18, 2002, Brunson executed the will that is the subject of this action.Â  In the will, he devised a beach house in Horry County to Wright.Â  In addition, he devised a life estate in his residence in Darlington County to Wright with a one-third remainder interest each to Nash, Clifford, and Wrightâ€™s heirs.Â  Both of these devises to Wright were made â€œin consideration of her dedicated assistance to [Brunson] and [his] wife for many years.â€Â  The remainder of the estate was left to the three daughters equally.Â  Wright was named as the personal representative of the estate.Â  
Following Brunsonâ€™s death, Wright commenced an informal probate of her fatherâ€™s estate and was appointed as personal representative.Â  Nash and Clifford filed an action against Wright and the estate contesting the will.Â  They alleged the will was procured by â€œfraud, coercion, duress, undue influence and/or mistakeâ€ and that at the time of the execution of the will, Brunson lacked testamentary capacity.Â  
As a threshold question, the probate court considered Nash and Cliffordâ€™s contention that Wright, who held durable power of attorney and had a fiduciary relationship with Brunson, had the burden of demonstrating that Brunson had the requisite testamentary capacity and that the will was not procured as a result of undue influence.Â  Â Â The court concluded that under the unambiguous language of the South Carolina Probate Code, Nash and Clifford had both the burden of proof and the burden of persuasion on both the issues of lack of testamentary capacity and undue influence.Â  In considering the totality of the evidence, the court concluded Brunson had the requisite mental capacity to execute his will and the will was not the result of undue influence.Â  
Nash and Clifford appealed the circuit court.Â  The court ruled that despite the provisions of the probate code, â€œwhen a fiduciary relationship exists between the testator and the primary beneficiary under the testatorâ€™s will, the burden then shifts to the beneficiary to prove the absence of undue influence by clear and convincing evidence.â€Â  The court found it was not clear whether the probate court had made any specific determination as to whether a fiduciary relationship existed between Wright and her father.Â  It held without this specific conclusion, it could not rule upon the various other grounds for appeal.Â  Accordingly, it remanded the case to the probate court to make appropriate findings and conclusions as to whether a fiduciary relationship existed.Â  It allowed for the parties to present additional evidence on this issue.Â  Wright appealed to this court.Â  
DISCUSSION
Wright argues the circuit court erred in ruling that when a fiduciary relationship exists between the testator and the primary beneficiary, the burden of persuasion shifts to the beneficiary to prove the absence of undue influence by clear and convincing evidence.Â  We agree.Â Â  
The probate court relied on section 62-3-407 of the South Carolina Code of Laws, which sets forth the burden of proof and burden of persuasion in contested will cases.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-407 (Supp. 2005).Â  This section provides in pertinent part:

In contested cases, petitioners who seek to establish intestacy have the burden of establishing prima facie proof of death, venue, and heirship.Â  Proponents of a will have the burden of establishing prima facie proof of due execution in all cases and, if they are also petitioners, prima facie proof of death and venue.Â  Contestants of a will have the burden of establishing undue influence, fraud, duress, mistake, revocation, or lack of testamentary intent or capacity.Â  Parties have the ultimate burden of persuasion as to matters with respect to which they have the initial burden of proof.Â  

Id.Â  
When a confidential relationship exists, a presumption of invalidity of the will on the basis of undue influence arises.Â  Howard v. Nasser, 364 S.C. 279, 286-88, 613 S.E.2d 64, 67-68 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In Nasser, this court considered section 62-3-407 and the presumption of invalidity and determined: 

[I]f the contestants of a duly executed will provide evidence that a confidential/fiduciary relationship existed sufficient to raise the presumption, the proponents of the will must offer evidence in rebuttal.Â  We emphasize that although the proponents of the will must present evidence in rebuttal, they do not have to affirmatively disprove the existence of undue influence.Â  Instead, the contestants of the will still retain the ultimate burden of proof to invalidate the will.Â  

Id. at 288, 613 S.E.2d at 68-69. Â The court summarized:

Â [W]here the contestants introduce testimony raising a presumption of undue influence by a beneficiary sustaining a confidential or fiduciary relation toward the testator, the issue should be submitted to the jury, as where, in addition to the factor of confidential relations, there also appear the further facts of an unnatural disposition making the person charged with the undue influence chief beneficiary, and that such person generally dominated the testatrix.

Id.Â  (quoting Moorer v. Bull, 212 S.C. 146, 149, 46 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1948) (citations omitted)). 
Although made without the benefit of this courtâ€™s opinion in Nasser, the probate courtâ€™s ruling on the issue of the burden of proof is in line with this courtâ€™s decision.Â Â Â  Accordingly, we hold the circuit court erred in ruling that upon a showing of a fiduciary relationship, the burden of proof shifts to the beneficiary.
Wright argues the circuit court erred in remanding the case to the probate court to determine whether or not a fiduciary relationship existed.Â  We agree.Â  
Wright concedes that she was in a fiduciary relationship with her father.Â  The probate court recognized, â€œMs. Wright was also a power of attorney holder and owed a fiduciary duty to the testator.â€Â  The probate court did not specifically articulate that this relationship raised the presumption of invalidity.Â  However, even with the presumption, the burden merely shifted to Wright to present evidence in rebuttal, not to affirmatively disprove the existence of undue influence.Â  See Nasser, 364 S.C. at 288, 613 S.E.2d at 68 (stating that if the will contestants provide evidence that a confidential/fiduciary relationship existed sufficient to raise the presumption, the proponents of the will must offer evidence in rebuttal). The probate court considered Wrightâ€™s fiduciary relationship, in addition to Nash and Cliffordâ€™s other contentions, as well as Wrightâ€™s rebuttal evidence that the testamentary dispositions were not the result of undue influence.Â  It then concluded, â€œThe court finds that the level of evidence required for a finding of undue influence was not attained.â€Â  We find the probate courtâ€™s deliberation in this case was consistent with this courtâ€™s ruling in Nasser.Â Â  Accordingly, we hold the circuit court erred in remanding the case to the probate court for further proceedings.[2]Â Â 

Thus we remand to the circuit court for consideration of Nash and Cliffordâ€™s remaining issues on appeal.Â Â  Â Â Â 
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.Â  
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ. concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] We take no position as to the existence of undue influence as this issue is not presently before the court.Â

Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 16, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Bradley B. Hansen, of Lexington, for Appellant.
        Montford S. Caughman, of Lexington, for Respondent.
        Howard A. Van Dine, III and Paul T. Collins, both of Columbia, for Guardian Ad Litem
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Roger B. (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s termination of his parental rights to B.B., A.B., and D.B..Â  Father contends the family court erred in (1) terminating his parental rights on the bases that he abandoned and willfully failed to visit his minor children, (2) failing to make a specific finding regarding whether termination of his parental rights was in the childrenâ€™s best interests, and (3) denying his motion for a continuance.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On December 20, 2001, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) took the minor children into emergency protective custody after Father was charged with murder in connection with the death of the childrenâ€™s mother, Jenny B. (Mother). Â Father allegedly murdered Mother in the presence of the children, two of whom actually witnessed the incident.Â  Father then drove all three children to a wooded area where he abandoned them.Â  He subsequently picked the children up from the wooded area and later abandoned them in a car, where authorities found the children sleeping. Â Although the weather was â€œvery cold,â€ Father allegedly left the children without warm clothing.Â  Â Â 
DSS initiated the present termination of parental rights (TPR) action against Father on May 29, 2003.Â  It alleged multiple bases for termination, including abandonment of the children and the childrenâ€™s placement in foster care under DSS custody for at least fifteen of the preceding twenty-four months.Â  Father declined representation, and filed a pro se answer specifically denying all bases for termination of his parental rights except the allegation as to the time the children had been in the custody of DSS.[2]Â  
The family court conducted a merits hearing on February 12, 2004.Â  As a preliminary matter, Father asked the court to rule on a motion for continuance he previously filed but admittedly failed to serve on opposing counsel.Â  Father argued he was entitled to a continuance because his appointed â€œstandby counsel,â€[3] Ronald R. Hall, had not responded to his requests for assistance and, consequently, he was unable to have subpoenas served on his witnesses.Â  Father argued he was therefore unprepared to proceed with the hearing.Â  He maintained he wanted to call as witnesses a member of the local solicitorâ€™s office and his former appointed trial counsel.Â  Father failed to articulate the testimony he sought to elicit from the member of the solicitorâ€™s office, but stated this solicitor had indicated his criminal trial would take place before Fatherâ€™s parents attempted to obtain custody of the children. He stated he wished to question his former appointed counsel to preserve a claim for ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  The court denied Fatherâ€™s motion, finding (1) it was not properly before the court because he had not properly served the motion on opposing counsel, and (2) Father failed to demonstrate that the witnesses he planned to subpoena would offer any relevant testimony in this termination of parental rights action.Â  
At the hearing, the childrenâ€™s DSS foster care worker testified the children had continuously been in foster care since they were taken into emergency protective custody approximately twenty-six months earlier.Â  She testified placement with the Father was not likely in the foreseeable future, and that efforts to place the children with family members proved unsuccessful.Â  According to the foster care worker, the only remaining option was to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights and make the children available for adoption.Â  A DSS foster care supervisor also testified placement of the children with relatives had been explored, but no suitable placement was found.Â  The supervisor also testified terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in the childrenâ€™s best interests, primarily because of the allegations Father killed their Mother, who the supervisor described as â€œthe one stable force in their life . . . .â€Â  The childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem opined the childrenâ€™s grandparents loved them, but they were not a suitable option for the childrenâ€™s placement.Â  She testified â€œtheir father had demonstrated, through the childrenâ€™s interaction with [her], a disregard for their well-beingâ€ and that she consequently did not find interviewing him necessary. Â The guardian ad litem also testified she believed the childrenâ€™s best interests would be served by terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights and placing them for adoption.Â  DSS sought termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights based on the two statutory grounds of Fatherâ€™s abandonment of the children and the childrenâ€™s placement in DSS custody for fifteen of the past twenty-two months.Â  
The court terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights orally at the conclusion of the hearing noting, in spite of attempts to find family members with whom to place the children, no suitable placement was found.Â  The court found the children had been in foster care for the preceding twenty-six months, and that time was of the essence such that it was in the childrenâ€™s best interest that the matter not be delayed.Â  The court later reduced its findings and conclusions to a written order dated March 5, 2004.[4]Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR action, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before parental rights can be forever terminated, the grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608-09, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we are not required to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact the trial judge was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony. Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 345 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œFurther, this broad scope of review does not relieve the appellant of the burden of convincing this Court that the family court committed error.â€Â  Id.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Termination of Parental Rights
Father first argues the court erred in terminating his parental rights because, under the circumstances, his imprisonment precluded a finding that he willfully abandoned or failed to visit his minor children.Â Â  We note the family court did not terminate fatherâ€™s parental rights on the basis of willful failure to visit, but we decline to otherwise address these issues because Father does not dispute the termination of his parental rights on the alternate basis that the minor children had been in foster care fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months at the time of the hearing.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005) (permitting TPR where a child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months). Â Because Father does not refute this finding, the courtâ€™s determination that Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated under section 20-7-1572(8) is the law of the case.[5]Â  See Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (holding an unappealed ruling is the law of the case); Â S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Seegars, 367 S.C. 623, 628, n. 3, 627 S.E.2d 718, 721, n.3 (2006) (ruling unappealed grounds for TPR are law of the case). Further, our courts have held that a finding pursuant to section 20-7-1572(8) alone is sufficient to support a termination of parental rights. Â S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 608, 598 S.E.2d 303, 307 (Ct. App. 2004).
II.Â Â Â Â  Best Interests of the Children
Because one statutory ground for TPR has been met, the only issue remaining for us to consider is whether termination is in the best interest of the children.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005) (providing family court may terminate parental rights if it finds at least one of the eleven statutory grounds for termination has been met and that termination is in the best interest of the child).Â  See also Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. King, 369 S.C. 96, ____, 631 S.E.2d 239, 241 (2006) (holding, where parent failed to appeal ruling that child had been in foster care for fifteen of most recent twenty-two months, one statutory ground for TPR had been met and the appellate court need only consider whether termination of parental rights was in the best interest of the child).
Father contends the family court failed to make a specific finding that it was in the best interests of the children to terminate his parental rights.Â  Here, the family courtâ€™s order did not explicitly state that terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  However, in its oral order, the court did find that time was of the essence in securing permanent placement for these children, that it was in the childrenâ€™s best interest that there be no further delay, and that Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated.Â  Furthermore, the family courtâ€™s written order notes the importance of freeing abused and/or neglected children for adoption, but recognizes that paramount to this view is the principle that the best interests of the minor children prevail if their interests vary from that of the parent.Â  The written order also emphasizes the importance of focusing on the childrenâ€™s best interests by stating â€œtime is of the essence in the lives of these minors, that they are each developing by the minute, and that there can be no further delay in the attempt to secure permanency for them.â€Â  Thus, based on our view of the record, we find the family court considered the childrenâ€™s best interests when reaching its decision.Â  At any rate, we find clear and convincing evidence overwhelmingly indicates it was in the childrenâ€™s best interests that Fatherâ€™s parental rights be terminated.Â  In particular, both the childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem and DSS foster care supervisor emphatically opined that terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights served the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  Also, their DSS foster care worker testified attempts to place the children with family members was not successful, and that making them available for adoption was the only option. Â See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. V. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding, in a termination of parental rights case, the appellate court has jurisdiction to review the entire record to determine the facts in accordance with its view of the evidence; Â the appellate court may review the record and make its own findings as to whether clear and convincing evidence supports termination). 
III.Â Â Â  Motion for Continuance
Father contends the family courtâ€™s denial of his motion for a continuance violated his constitutional due process rights because it deprived him of additional time needed to subpoena witnesses he had previously been unable to subpoena due to his standby counselâ€™s failure to assist him.Â  We disagree.
As an initial matter, Fatherâ€™s claim that the courtâ€™s ruling violated his constitutional due process rights was never raised to or ruled upon by the family court.Â  Thus, it is not preserved for our review.Â  See Durlach v. Durlach, 359 S.C. 64, 76, 596 S.E.2d 908, 915 (2004) (holding due process claim not raised in the family court but raised for the first time on appeal is not preserved for review).Â  Further, Father has failed to challenge on appeal the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the motion for continuance was not properly before the court because Father had not properly served the motion on opposing counsel.Â  This alternate basis for denying the motion for continuance is therefore the law of the case.Â  See Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 65, 624 S.E.2d 649, 653-54 (2006) (holding unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
At any rate, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Fatherâ€™s motion for continuance.Â  Father did not indicate the precise testimony he sought to elicit from the solicitor, but stated the solicitor had indicated his criminal trial would take place prior to the hearing regarding the paternal grandparentsâ€™ attempt to obtain custody of the children. As to his former attorney, Father sought to subpoena him as a witness in order to preserve a legal malpractice claim.Â  We agree with the trial court that the testimony of these witnesses was irrelevant.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 51, 413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992) (â€œThe granting or denial of a continuance is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and is reviewable on appeal only when an abuse of discretion appears from the record.â€).
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] His pleadingsâ€™ caption indicates he also brought a cross-claim, although the pleadings are unclear about the subject of the cross-claim.Â  Paragraph â€œGâ€ of Fatherâ€™s pleadings allege prejudice and a lack of partiality by the guardian ad litem, which appears to constitute the cross-claim. Â 
[3] Although Father insisted on representing himself at the trial level, he asked the court to appoint â€œstandby counselâ€ to assist him.Â  The court granted his motion.Â  
[4] The order erroneously states the order was signed on March 5, 2003.Â  However, this is clearly a typographical error in light of the undisputed fact that the hearing occurred in February 2004 and the order was filed March 10, 2004. 
[5] Father attempts to raise by way of his reply brief that he has not abandoned this issue because he has maintained he was denied visitation with the children.Â  Father fails, however, to refute the factual basis for termination on the ground that the children have been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months, nor does he challenge the validity of this statutory ground.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS Â Â PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Dale Owen Shaffer, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Adam Bacot, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-348Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ 
Filed October 18, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Dale Shaffer, of Greenwood, Pro Se, for Appellant.
        Andrew E. Haselden and R. Davis Howser, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this legal malpractice case, Dale Shaffer contends the trial court erred in denying his motions for continuance and in denying his motion to amend his complaint.Â  Shaffer also contends the process for litigating legal malpractice cases in South Carolina is unconstitutional.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
This legal malpractice action stems from a previous action in which Adam Bacot represented Shaffer in his divorce.Â  Shaffer, acting pro se, alleges Bacot was negligent in not acting on â€œthe many warning signs that [Shafferâ€™s ex-wifeâ€™s divorce attorney] was not performing in a manner consistent with [Bacotâ€™s] view of what constitutes the proper operation of a domestic relations suit.â€Â  Shaffer also contends Bacot failed to carefully review certain documents produced through discovery.Â  Specifically, Shaffer alleges Bacot failed to timely identify a second appraisal of the marital home which valued the home at a substantially lower value than previously believed.Â Â  
Bacot answered, asserting a general denial of most of the factual allegations, numerous defenses, and filed a motion to strike pursuant to Rule 12(f), SCRCP, which was granted.Â  Shaffer appealed that order asserting the motion to strike should not have been granted and raising numerous constitutional issues.Â  On May 18, 2004, this court issued an unpublished opinion affirming the order granting Bacotâ€™s motion to strike and noted the constitutional issues were not properly before the court.Â  See Shaffer v. Bacot, No. 2004-UP-339 (S.C. Ct. App. filed May 18, 2004).Â Â  
Prior to trial, Shaffer made numerous motions for continuance, all of which were denied.Â  Shaffer also made a motion to amend his complaint just before trial which was also denied.Â  In his motion to amend, Shaffer sought to include the following:Â  

  
    D. 
    Failure to identify the possible civil conspiracy on the part of Attorney Jon Newlon and Ackerman Appraisal Service in producing and using an appraisal that may have been designed to be artificially low.  
  
  
    E.
    Failure to secure a third appraisal on the property in question. 
  
  
    F. 
    Failure to identify the possibility and consider the legal ramifications of the Plaintiff converting money from the 401K account into retirement years with the State of South Carolina, with or without the advance knowledge of opposing counsel in the underlying case.  
  

Prior to trial, Shaffer also moved the trial court for a ruling that the process for trying legal malpractice cases in South Carolina violated his constitutional rights.Â  The trial court denied the motion and stated that Shafferâ€™s arguments concerning these issues would be preserved for appeal.Â Â Â  
At the close of the trial, Bacot moved for a directed verdict.Â  The trial court granted the directed verdict on all grounds except comparative negligence, in essence resolving all the issues in the case.Â  Shaffer renewed his argument concerning the violation of constitutional rights, of which the trial court took note.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Motions for Continuance 
Shaffer contends the trial court erred in denying his motions for continuance.Â  We disagree.Â  
Deciding whether to grant or deny a motion for continuance rests within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 309, 486 S.E.2d 750, 760 (1997).Â  We will not reverse the trial court without a clear showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  â€œTo justify a continuance, the moving party must show not only the absence of some material evidence but also due diligence on his part to obtain it.â€Â  Hudson v. Blanton, 282 S.C. 70, 74, 316 S.E.2d 432, 434 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  â€œReversals of refusals of continuances are about as rare as the proverbial hens [sic] teeth.â€Â  State v. Yarborough, 363 S.C. 260, 266, 609 S.E.2d 592, 595 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
The action was initially filed on April 18, 2002.Â  Shaffer made motions for continuances on May 9, 19, and 23, 2005, all of which were denied.Â  The reasons given for the requests were to secure additional discovery materials as well as an expert witness.Â  The discovery materials were obtained in March 2005, thereby making his motion for a continuance on this basis moot.Â  As for the issue of obtaining an expert witness, Shaffer contends he exercised due diligence in attempting to obtain one.Â  However, Shaffer admits he did not begin his search until January of 2005, only four months before trial was set to begin.Â  Shafferâ€™s assertion that he was out of the country and unable to start the search is unavailing as, by his own admission, he began his search by sending letters to potential lawyers, which could have easily been done while out of the country.Â Â  
Further, this is not a case where an expert witness has been identified and for some reason is unable to be at trial.Â  See Yarborough, 363 S.C. at 266, 609 S.E.2d at 595 (finding in case where two witnesses failed to appear at hearing that the party asking for the continuance â€œ[m]ust show due diligence was used in trying to procure the testimony of an absent witness as well as set forth what the party believes the absent witness will testify to and the grounds for that beliefâ€); Logan v. Gatti, 289 S.C. 546, 547-49, 347 S.E.2d 506, 507-8 (Ct. App. 1986) (finding where plaintiffâ€™s expert witness was unexpectedly recalled to active duty with the Navy a few weeks before trial, the failure to grant a motion for a continuance was an abuse of discretion).Â  As such, Shaffer cannot show what the testimony of the absent witness would have been.Â  Nor can Shaffer point to any circumstances, such as those in Logan, where his witness could not attend trial unexpectedly.Â Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in failing to grant Shafferâ€™s motions for continuance as Shaffer has failed to show not only the absence of some material evidence but also due diligence on his part to obtain it.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â  Motion to Amend Complaint 
Shaffer argues the trial court erred in denying his motion to amend his complaint.Â  We disagree.Â  
Rule 15, SCRCP, provides that the complaint may be amended by leave of the court and â€œleave shall be freely given when justice requires and does not prejudice any other party.â€ A motion to amend is within the sound discretion of the trial court and the opposing party has the burden of establishing prejudice.Â  Foggie v. CSX Transp., Inc., 315 S.C. 17, 22, 431 S.E.2d 587, 590 (1993).Â  The â€œprejudiceâ€ in question is lack of notice that a new issue is going to be tried and lack of opportunity to refute it.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 413, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000).
Shaffer made the motion to amend his complaint on May 19, 2005, only one business day prior to the scheduled commencement of trial.Â  Granting the motion would have given Bacot virtually no time to prepare a defense to the new allegations.Â  Shaffer provided no reason why such a motion could not have been made earlier.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in refusing to allow Shaffer to amend his complaint one business day prior to the trialâ€™s commencement.Â  
III.Â Â Â  Constitutional ArgumentsÂ  
Shaffer contends the process for litigating legal malpractice cases in South Carolina does not protect the plaintiffâ€™s due process or equal protection rights provided by both the United States Constitution and the South Carolina Constitution.Â  We disagree.Â  
Initially, Shaffer makes a general statement that the process for litigating legal malpractice cases in South Carolina violates the Due Process Clause.Â  The Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution provides, â€œnor shall any State deprive any person of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law.â€ â€œ[D]ue process is flexible and calls for such procedural protections as the particular situation demands.â€ Morrissey v. Brewer, 408 U.S. 471, 481 (1972).Â  The requirements in a particular case are dependent upon the importance of the interest involved and the circumstances under which the deprivation may occur.Â  See Mathews v. Eldridge, 424 U.S. 319, 335 (1976) (holding that in determining the process which is due, courts will consider the private interest affected by the proceeding, the risk of error created by the chosen procedure, and the countervailing governmental interest supporting challenged procedure). â€œThe fundamental requirement of due process is the opportunity to be heard at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Beeks, 325 S.C. 243, 246, 481 S.E.2d 703, 705 (1997).
Shaffer appears to argue that the legal malpractice system in South Carolina is not easily navigated by a non-lawyer and thus violates his due process rights.Â  This argument, however, does not constitute a denial of due process.Â  Shaffer, like any other pro se litigant, has the same opportunity for his day in court, notice of proceedings, and most importantly the opportunity to be heard.Â  He makes no argument that he was denied these rights, and specifically does not argue he was denied these rights due to his status as a pro se litigant.Â  Accordingly, we find Shafferâ€™s right to due process has not been violated.Â  
Shaffer also asserts his equal protection rights were violated stemming from the availability of attorneys willing to represent plaintiffs in legal malpractice cases.Â  Equal protection, as provided by the United States Constitution, means that â€œno person, or class of persons, shall be denied the same protection of the laws which is enjoyed by other persons or other classes in the same place and under similar circumstances.â€Â  U.S. Const. art. 1; U.S. Const. amend. XIV.Â  Equal protection guarantees only protection enjoyed by other persons in the same place and under like circumstances.Â  Harrison v. Caudle, 141 S.C. 407, 407, 139 S.E.2d 842, 845 (1927).Â  To establish an equal protection violation, plaintiffs must demonstrate they were intentionally and purposely subjected to treatment different from others similarly situated.Â  Sylvia Dev. Corp. v. Calvert County, Md., 48 F.3d 810, 818 (4th Cir. 1995).
However, Shaffer offers no evidence that he or other legal malpractice litigants are treated differently than other malpractice litigants.Â  There is no evidence that Shaffer has been treated any differently in this case than he would have been if he had been representing himself in a medical malpractice case.Â  Shaffer makes no argument concerning the inability of his being able to find a lawyer to represent him in this case.Â  His only arguments concern his inability to find an expert to testify on his behalf, which may very well have been an indication of the strength of his case and not the legal malpractice process.Â  As such, Shaffer has failed to establish an equal protection violation based on the inability to find a legal representative in this legal malpractice case.Â  
Additionally, Shaffer asserts that plaintiffs in legal malpractice cases are deprived of their constitutional right to an impartial tribunal.Â  Specifically, Shaffer contends the legal malpractice process in South Carolina violates both the Due Process Clause and Equal Protection Clause: â€œWhen comparing plaintiffs in legal malpractice cases to plaintiffs in other cases, plaintiffs in legal malpractice cases are often faced with a judicial tribunal with close professional associations to defendants.â€Â  However, Shaffer does not point to any particular judge or any particular wrong.Â  Instead, he attacks the entire process for adjudicating legal malpractice claims in South Carolina.Â  He offers no evidence to support his contention.Â  
South Carolina has enacted numerous ethical guidelines to ensure that every litigant receives a fair trial.Â  Rule 501, SCACR, establishes guidelines for judicial conduct.Â  For example, Canon 3(B)(5) provides as follows:Â  

  A judge shall perform judicial duties without bias or prejudice. A judge shall not, in the performance of judicial duties, by words or conduct manifest bias or prejudice, including but not limited to bias or prejudice based upon race, sex, religion, national origin, disability or age, and shall not permit staff, court officials and others subject to the judgeâ€™s direction and control to do so.

As such, rules are in place to protect litigants such as Shaffer from disparate treatment by the courts, and because Shaffer can point to no specific injury he has suffered, this court cannot find that the process for litigating legal malpractice claims in South Carolina denies the plaintiff an impartial tribunal.Â  
Finally, Shaffer provides several remedies for the alleged constitutional violations.Â  These remedies include, but are not limited to, a panel of individuals to assist the court in its decision making; the creation of a state office to provide legal assistance to legal malpractice pro se plaintiffs; and a call for a revision of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure to make them understandable to anyone â€œwith a high school education.â€Â  However, these are not remedies that could be implemented without legislative action and, therefore, we cannot properly rule on these suggestions.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, HUFF and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Cathy T. Sanders, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Charles N. Sanders, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Paul W. Garfinkel, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-351
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jessie J. Glenn, of North Charleston, for Appellant.
        Cathy T. Sanders, of Hollywood, Respondent Pro Se.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this domestic action, Charles Sanders (Husband) appeals the order of the family court awarding Cathy Sanders (Wife) alimony.Â  Husband also contends the family court erred by imputing an excessive amount of income to him.Â Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Husband and Wife married in 1965 and separated in 2000 after thirty-five years of marriage.Â  They have two children, both of whom are emancipated.Â  
Wife has a two-year college degree and worked part-time during the marriage as a medical secretary.Â  During the marriage, Wifeâ€™s primary role was that of homemaker, taking care of the majority of the household duties, including cooking, cleaning, and caring for the partiesâ€™ children. 
Husband worked as a management consultant in the apparel industry and earned $100,000 a year.Â  Both children attended private schools and the parties took numerous vacations.Â  In 1976, Husband and Wife built a house on Youngâ€™s Island on land Wife inherited.Â  The parties also had a home in North Carolina in which they lived when Husbandâ€™s employer transferred him there.Â  In addition, Husband and Wife purchased two condominiums in Myrtle Beach for investment purposes.Â  Â 
The parties maintained a high standard of living until 1996, when they filed for bankruptcy.Â  Husband claims he lost his job because the enactment of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) in the early 1990s caused his employment opportunities to move overseas.Â  Although he received numerous job offers, he did not accept any of the offers because he did not want to live abroad.Â  Husband is currently employed as a starter ranger on a golf course and makes six dollars an hour. Â Â 
The parties separated in May 2000, after Husband confessed he was having an adulterous affair.Â  On June 29, 2004, Wife instituted this action against Husband.Â  By order dated March 15, 2005, the family court granted Wife a divorce based on Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  Further, the family court found Husband was currently â€œwoefully under employedâ€ and found Husband had the ability to earn a substantial income.Â  Accordingly, the family court ordered him to pay Wife two thousand dollars a month in alimony.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002); Lanier v. Lanier, 364 S.C. 211, 215, 612 S.E.2d 456, 458 (Ct. App. 2005); Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005); Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992)).Â  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings, and we remain mindful of the fact that the family court, who saw and heard the parties, is in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981); Holler v. Holler, 364 S.C. 256, 261, 612 S.E.2d 469, 472 (Ct. App. 2005); see Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating that because the appellate court lacks the opportunity to directly observe the witnesses, it should accord great deference to the family courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved).
ISSUES

  
    I.
    Did the family court err by failing to review the applicable statutory factors before awarding Wife alimony of two thousand dollars?  
  
  
    II.
    Did the family court err by imputing an excessive amount of income to Husband?
  

DISCUSSION
I.  Alimony Award
Husband argues the family court erred in ordering him to pay Wife alimony in the amount of two thousand dollars per month without considering the applicable statutory factors.Â  We disagree.
We hold this argument is not preserved for our review.Â  To preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the family court.Â  Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson  368 S.C. 87, 104-05, 627 S.E.2d 765, 775 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€)); Jones v. Daley, 363 S.C. 310, 315, 609 S.E.2d 597, 599 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Husband did not raise this argument to the family court.Â  Additionally, Husband failed to make a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion seeking judicial determination of this issue.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved.Â  See Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (holding when an appellant neither raises an issue at trial nor through a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to amend, the issue is not properly presented to an appellate court for review).Â  
II.Â Amount of Imputed Income
Husband argues the family court erred by failing to include a specified amount of income imputed to him in the divorce decree before awarding Wife alimony.Â  Husband maintains the divorce decree is devoid of any income imputable to him.Â  We disagree.
Husband did not raise this issue to the family court or in any subsequent Rule 59(e) motion and, therefore, this issue is not preserved for our review. See Riggs v. Riggs, 353 S.C. 230, 237, 578 S.E.2d 3, 6 (2003) (citing Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 489 S.E.2d 212 (Ct. App. 1997) (issue must be raised to and ruled on by family court to be preserved for appellate review)).
Next, Husband contends the family court imputed an excessive amount of income to him.Â  Specifically, Husband contends the family court erred by imputing $100,000 to him as income when no evidence suggested Husbandâ€™s change in income was intentional or voluntary.Â  We disagree.
We rule that Husband failed to present this argument to the family court or make a subsequent Rule 59(e) motion and, therefore, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Hatfield, 327 S.C. at 367, 489 S.E.2d at 216 (citing Hickman v. Hickman, 301 S.C. 455, 392 S.E.2d 481 (Ct. App. 1990) (issue not presented to and passed upon by the trial court cannot be considered on appeal)).Â  
Lastly, Husband argues the family court erred in basing the award of alimony on his income of $100,000, when he earned that amount of income for only fifteen of the thirty-five years the couple was married.Â  We disagree. 
We conclude this argument, having not been raised to and ruled upon by the family court, is not preserved for our review.Â  An issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review. Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004); see also Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 102, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting it is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal). 
CONCLUSION
Because we find the Appellant did not properly preserve the issues on appeal, we affirm the family courtâ€™s order in its entirety. 
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the Court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

  v.

  
    
      
        Michael Lee Staton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
William P. Keesley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-352
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia, and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Â Â Michael Lee Staton (Staton) appeals his conviction for the unlawful possession of a controlled substance, trafficking in methamphetamine, and failure to stop for a law enforcement vehicle.Â  Staton maintains the trial judge abused his discretion in admitting evidence, arguing the chain of custody was not adequately proven by the State.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On the night of January 3, 2004, Officer Donald Ward (Ward) attempted to stop Staton because the vehicle he was driving was without a license plate.Â  At the sight of the officerâ€™s blue light, Staton sped up, leading law enforcement on a fifteen-mile car chase that ended only when the vehicle Staton was driving ceased to run.Â  He then fled his vehicle and the pursuit continued on foot.Â  With the help of fellow officer Jeffery Dennie (Dennie), Ward was able to run down and apprehend Staton.Â  On Statonâ€™s person, Ward found a bottle of pills. Â Dennie searched Statonâ€™s vehicle to find syringes, a set of weights, several bags containing a white powder, and a vial of red liquid in the glove compartment. Â Officer Ward was present during the entire time Dennie searched the vehicle, but was otherwise occupied in assisting an individual who had been a passenger in Statonâ€™s car.Â Â  
Dennie handed all of the evidence he removed from the car to Ward.Â  Before leaving the scene, Ward handed these items, along with the pill bottle he found on Staton, to investigator Michael Coats (Coats).Â  Ward completed a chain of custody form, stating he seized the bottle of pills, syringes, weights, and bags from Staton and that he subsequently gave them all to Coats.Â  In this documentation, Ward did not note that Dennie was the one who actually, physically removed the evidence from Statonâ€™s car. Â Dennie never recorded his handling of these objects.Â  
At trial, officers Ward and Dennie testified as to the above facts.Â  Dennie explained that as he was only the secondary officer on the scene and his removal of the evidence from Statonâ€™s vehicle was done in Wardâ€™s presence, he did not believe it was necessary for him to document the brief time he handled the items before passing them along to Ward.Â  
Coats then testified as to receiving the evidence from Ward.Â  He further stated he placed the objects in a tamper-evident â€œbest bag,â€ a type of bag which once sealed, must be torn in order to be reopened.Â  Coats recounted he kept this bag in his officeâ€™s safe until the time it was transferred to the South Carolina Law Enforcement Divisionâ€™s (SLED) secure drug box.Â Â  
Gregory Rock, a drug analyst with SLED, reported that although Atra Taylor, another SLED analyst, transported the evidence from SLEDâ€™s secure drug box to their departmentâ€™s drug vault, he personally removed the specimens from the locked drug vault, examined the tamper-evident bag, and noted the integrity of the bag and evidence inside. Â Rock then detailed his chemical tests, which showed the bottle of pills to be comprised of 29 tablets of hydrocodone and acetaminophen (a class III controlled substance) and 30 tablets of alprazolam (a class IV controlled substance). Â The white powder and red liquid both proved to be methamphetamine. 
The prosecution offered these substances as evidence.Â  Staton objected that the requisite chain of possession had not been presented.Â  The court overruled, finding a sufficient chain of custody to be shown and adding that any difference between the trial testimony and the forms went to the credibility of the evidence and not its admissibility.Â  
The jury found Staton guilty of the unlawful possession of controlled substances, trafficking in methamphetamine, and failure to stop for a law enforcement vehicle.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Â The admission of evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed absent a manifest abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002); State v. Funderburk, 367 S.C. 236, 239, 625 S.E.2d 248, 249-50 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Additionally, the abuse of discretion must be accompanied by probable prejudice.Â  State v. Wise, 359 S.C. 14, 21, 596 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of the trial court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error of law.Â  State v. Irick, 344 S.C. 460, 464, 545 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2001); State v. Funderburk, 367 S.C. 236, 239, 625 S.E.2d 248, 249-50 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  If there is any evidence to support the trial judge's decision, the appellate courts will affirm it. Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 7, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001); State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18, 598 S.E.2d 735 (Ct. App. 2004).
DISCUSSION
Staton claims the chain of custody presented by the State was fatally deficient and the judge erred in allowing the drugs into evidence.Â  Staton relies on the failure of Taylor to testify as to her custody of the specimens and the fact that Ward did not indicate in his documentation that it was Dennie who actually removed particular items from Statonâ€™s vehicle.
A party offering into evidence fungible items such as drugs must establish a chain of custody as far as practicable, tracing possession from the time the object is seized to the final custodian by whom it is analyzed.Â  See State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419, 424, 544 S.E.2d 835, 837 (2001).Â  Where the analyzed substance has passed through the hands of several persons, the evidence presented must not leave it to conjecture as to who had it and what was done with it in the time between the taking and the analysis.Â  State v. Taylor, 360 S.C. 18, 22-23, 598 S.E.2d 735, 737 (2004).Â  â€œ[I]f the identity of each person in the chain handling the evidence is established, and the manner of handling is reasonably demonstrated, no abuse of discretion is shown in the admission, absent proof of tampering, bad faith, or ill-motive.â€Â  Taylor, 360 S.C. at 25, 598 S.E.2d at 738.Â  However, as long as the sequence of possession is complete, sufficient proof of the chain of custody need not negate all possibility of tampering.Â  Carter, 344 S.C. at 424, 544 S.E.2d at 837; State v. Williams, 297 S.C. 290, 293, 376 S.E.2d 773, 774 (1989); State v. Johnson, 318 S.C. 194, 196, 456 S.E.2d 442, 443 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
Only where the identity of those who handled the evidence was not established far as practicable, have our appellate courts found evidence inadmissible.Â  Carter, 344 S.C. at 424, 544 S.E.2d at 837.Â  In contrast, where the evidence furnishes the identity of those who have handled the substance and the manner in which it was handled, we have found evidence regarding its care to go only the weight of the specimen as credible evidence.Â  Id.Â  â€œIn other words, where there is a weak link in the chain of custody, as opposed to a missing link, the question is only one of credibility, not admissibility.â€Â  Carter, 344 S.C. at 424, 544 S.E.2d at 837.
In the case at bar, the drugsâ€™ chain of possession was firmly established.Â  The State presented evidence sequencing each person who handled the specimens.Â  Contrary to Statonâ€™s claim, there was no missing analyst.Â  That Atra Taylor did not take the stand is of no consequence.Â  Her involvement in the chain of possession, that of carrying the drugs from SLEDâ€™s secure drug box to the chemical analysis departmentâ€™s drug vault, was presented at trial. Â Proving chain of custody does not require that all personâ€™s in the chain must testify.Â  See Williams, 297 S.C. 290, 376 S.E.2d 773 (affirming trial courtâ€™s decision to admit blood test results even though there was no testimony from the nurse who had drawn the blood of the defendant and placed it in the refrigerator); Taylor, 360 S.C. at 26, 589 S.E.2d at 738-739 (rejecting the appellantâ€™s argument that previous South Carolina Court of Appealsâ€™ cases required that all persons in the chain of custody must testify to establish admissibility).Â  Rock testified that he was the only chemist who actually touched the drugs and that the evidence bag was unbroken and unopened at the time he removed the specimen from the vault.Â  The lack of testimony from Taylor affects only the weight of the evidence, not its admissibility.Â  The chain of custody was properly presented.
The admissibility of the evidence was also unaffected by Officer Wardâ€™s omission in his chain of custody documentation, that is to say his failure to note that Officer Dennie first handled the drugs in Statonâ€™s glove compartment.Â  Both officers testified that Ward was nearby when Dennie searched the car, and even had Ward not been present, the trial testimony nonetheless firmly established the identity of those persons in possession of the evidence and the manner in which it was handled.Â  Any discrepancy between the officersâ€™ testimony and the completed forms implicated the specimensâ€™ credibility but did not render them inadmissible.Â  
CONCLUSION 
The was no abuse of discretion in the admission of the drugs into evidence.Â  Accordingly, Statonâ€™s convictions are 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Tina Jean N., Clifford S. and John Doe, Respondents,
In the interest of Abigail N., DOB 12/10/01, 
Intervenors:  Dewayne N., Sandra N. and Gena N.,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Pickens County
Â Alvin D. Johnson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-353
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. Daniel Yarborough, Jr. of Greenville, for Appellants.
Dottie C. Ingram, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dwayne N., Sandra N., and Gena N. (Appellants) appeal from a family court order denying their motion to intervene in this action for termination of parental rights (TPR).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Abigail N., the minor and subject of this termination of parental rights (TPR) action, was born December 10, 2001, to Clifford N. (Father) and Tina N. (Mother).Â  On February 12, 2005, A.N. was admitted to the hospital with at least two fractured ribs, a bruised pancreas, burns to her left arm, face, chest and abdomen, and low hemoglobin due to massive soft tissue injuries to her posterior where blood had pooled.Â  That same day, she was placed into emergency protective custody, pursuant to section 20-7-610(E) of the South Carolina Code (2003).Â  Two days later, the family court held a probable cause hearing and found the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) had probable cause to remove Abigail from her home.Â  DSS filed this action for TPR on February 17, 2005.Â  
A family meeting was held on March 3, 2005, pursuant to section 20-7-762(B) of the South Carolina Code (2003).Â  At the meeting, DSS informed Appellants, all of whom were present, that the TPR action would proceed. Â On March 14, 2005, Appellants went to DSS to speak to a case worker about obtaining custody of Abigail.Â  Appellants informed DSS that they did not want permanent custody of Abigail, and they would only care for her for a short period of time.Â  Significantly, Appellants took no action regarding custody of Abigail even after DSS informed Appellants of its decision to not recommend them for custody.Â  
By order dated March 9, 2005, the merits hearing for the abuse and neglect action was consolidated with the TPR action.Â  On May 12, 2005, the second day of the hearing, Appellants faxed a notice of motion and motion for intervention pursuant to Rule 24, SCRCP.Â  The motion for intervention was served upon the opposing parties via facsimile that same day.Â  The motion was scheduled to be heard on May 16, 2005.
At the hearing on the motion to intervene, Dewayne N. submitted an affidavit stating he believed the testimony would show that Mother had no part in injuring Abigail, and that she provided the child with prompt medical attention. Â A DSS caseworker and a DSS supervisor also submitted affidavits, in which they expressed concern that neither Dewayne N. nor Gena N. believed the abuse had occurred.Â  Because these relatives did not believe the child had been abused, DSS believed they â€œcould not be relied upon to provide adequate protection for [the minor child].â€Â Â  
The family court denied Appellantsâ€™ motion to intervene, finding they failed to provide adequate notice of the motion pursuant to Rule 6(d), SCRCP, and Rule 21(a), SCRFC.Â  Additionally, the family court found that â€œit [was] clearly not in the childâ€™s best interest to continue this case . . . .â€ Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).  However, â€œbecause the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad discretion.â€  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  The standard of
review for a motion for intervention is whether the judge abused his discretion in granting or denying the
motion.Â  See, e.g., In re Horry County State Bank, 361 S.C. 503, 507, 604 S.E.2d 723, 725 (Ct. App. 2004). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the family court erred in denying their motion to intervene. [1]Â  We disagree.
Appellants filed their motion to intervene pursuant to Rule 24 of the South Carolina Rule of Civil Procedure.Â  Rule 6(d), SCRCP, provides for a minimum of ten daysâ€™ notice for written motions and provides, in part:

Written motion(s) other than one which may be heard ex parte, and notice of the hearing thereof, shall be served not later than ten days before the time specified for the hearing . . . .

(emphasis added).Â  
Here, Appellants provided only four daysâ€™ notice of their motion to intervene to opposing parties, notwithstanding the fact they were aware of both DSSâ€™s intent to file the TPR action as early as March 3, 2005, and of DSSâ€™s decision to not recommend Appellants for custody.Â  The parties were noticed via facsimile on May 12, 2005 that the motion to intervene would be heard on May 16, 2005.Â  Therefore, the family court correctly found Appellantsâ€™ motion to intervene was untimely under Rule 6(d), SCRCP.
Additionally, in their motion to intervene, Appellants sought temporary custody of Abigail.Â  Therefore, the family court also analyzed their motion under Rule 21 of the South Carolina Rules of Family Court, finding the motion was untimely under that rule as well.Â  We agree.
Rule 21(a), SCRFC, provides, in part: â€œA written motion for temporary relief, and notice of the hearing thereof, shall be served not later than five days before the time specifiedÂ  for the hearing . . . .â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  We agree with the family court that Appellantsâ€™ motion was untimely under Rule 21(a),
SCRFC.
Moreover, all matters involving the custody and care of children must be decided in the best interests of the child.Â  Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 285, 555 S.E.2d 386, 388 (2001).Â  In a termination of parental rights case, the
best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Our General Assembly has mandated that when the interest of the child and the parental rights conflict, the interest of the child shall prevail.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2005); see also, South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 364 S.C. 621, 626-27, 614 S.E.2d 642, 645 (2005) (holding that in balancing the interests of the
child and the parent, the best interest of the child is paramount to that of the parent). Â The supreme court has held that the termination of parental rights statute must be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent child relationship. Â Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 108, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000); see also S.C. Code Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2005).
We agree with the family courtâ€™s ruling that it is not in Abigailâ€™s best interest to permit Appellants to intervene.Â  Abigail suffered injuries so severe that she was hospitalized for thirteen days.Â  The family court even took the step of consolidating the merits hearing for the abuse and neglect action with the TPR action in order to expedite the actions to benefit Abigail.[2] Â Moreover, the guardian ad litem determined that it would not be in the minor childâ€™s best interest to delay the hearing to allow Appellants to intervene.Â  Therefore, we do not believe the family court judge abused his discretion in denying the motion to intervene. 
CONCLUSION 
Based on the foregoing, the order of the family court denying Appellantsâ€™ motion to intervene is hereby
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Section 20-7-610 of the South Carolina Code (2003) provides that the family may order expedited placement of the child with a suitable relative at the probable cause hearing.Â  While Appellantsâ€™ motion to intervene states this section as a basis for their intervention, the probable cause hearing had already been held when the motion to intervene was filed.Â  Moreover, the family courtâ€™s order does not address this argument, and Appellants failed to file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion on this issue.Â  Therefore, we find this issue unpreserved for appellate review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
[2] No party challenges the family courtâ€™s consolidation of the merits hearing for the abuse and neglect action with the TPR action.
