title: Morgan v. SCDSS
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Kim Morgan, Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-354
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 19, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Lisa Richardson Mobley, of Greenville, for Appellant
Rose Mary McGregor, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Kim Morgan appeals the family courtâ€™s affirmance of the South Carolina Department of Social Servicesâ€™ (DSS) order finding an indicated case of Morganâ€™s physical neglect of a student at the childcare center at which Morgan worked.Â  She also appeals the placement of her name on the Central Registry of Child Abuse and Neglect.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This case arises from an incident in which a three-year old special needs child was left on a childcare centerâ€™s bus for approximately four hours.Â  Â Morgan worked at A Childâ€™s Haven childcare center where her primary responsibility was that of lead teacher and classroom manager of the three to four-year old classroom.Â  One day a week, she would serve as monitor on one of the centerâ€™s buses.Â  On the day of the incident, the child boarded the bus on which Morgan served as monitor at 7:56 a.m. Â Another center employee drove the bus.Â  The bus arrived at the childcare center at 8:56 a.m.Â  At approximately 1:00 p.m., the bus driver returned to the bus for the afternoon run and discovered the child still strapped in her seatbelt on the bus.Â  The driver brought the child to the director, gave her a banana and juice, and then took her home.[2]Â  
The childâ€™s aunt testified that on the night of the incident, the child was crying a lot, clingy, wanted to be held, and would not sleep in her own bed. Since then, the child has exhibited fearful behaviors such as kicking, crying, restlessness, and a continued refusal to sleep in her own bed.Â  { The child had previously been diagnosed with aggressive behavior with developmental delays.[3]Â  
The director of the childcare center immediately reported the incident to the DSS, which cited the center for lack of supervision.Â  The director of the center and DSS entered into a corrective action plan on September 29, 2004.Â Â  Â Â 
DSS also commenced an investigation of Morgan and the driver of the bus.Â  Investigator Bobby Seepersaud interviewed Morgan, the driver, the center director, and others involved. Â He concluded the incident was an indicated case of physical neglect. Morganâ€™s name was placed on the Central Registry of Child Abuse and Neglect pursuant to S.C. Code section 20-7-670(I).[4]Â  Morgan appealed this determination.Â  After a fair hearing, DSS upheld the indicated finding of physical neglect.Â  Morgan appealed to the family court, which affirmed DSSâ€™s decision.Â  Morgan filed a motion to alter or amend asking that at least her name be removed from the Central Registry.Â  The family court found it had no discretion under section 20-7-670 regarding the placement of Morganâ€™s name upon an indicated finding of physical neglect.Â  Accordingly, the court denied her motion.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the decision of DSS, the standard of review set forth in the Administrative Procedures Act applies. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-655 (Supp. 2005).Â  Thus, the reviewing court must not substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact. S.C. Code
Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  The court may not overrule an agencyâ€™s decision unless: 

substantial rights of the appellant have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions are:
(a) in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions;
(b) in excess of the statutory authority of the agency;
(c) made upon unlawful procedure;
(d) affected by other error of law;
(e) clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record;Â  or
(f) arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â Â  
â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed blindly from one side, but is evidence which, when considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the agency reached.â€Â  Tennis v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 355 S.C. 551, 558, 585 S.E.2d 312, 316 (Ct. App. 2003).
DISCUSSION
1.Â  Finding of neglect
Morgan argues the family court erred in finding that she had physically neglected the child.Â  We disagree.Â  
According to statute, â€œchild abuse or neglectâ€ occurs when a person responsible for the childâ€™s welfare â€œinflicts or allows to be inflicted upon the child physical or mental injury or engages in acts or omissions which present a substantial risk of physical or mental injury to the child . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Â§ 20-7-490(2)(a) (Supp. 2005).Â  â€œA person responsible for a childâ€™s welfareâ€ includes a caregiver at a childcare facility.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(3) (Supp. 2005).Â  
Morgan was serving as a caregiver at a childcare facility at the time of the incident.Â  In her brief, Morgan asserts that it was the bus driver rather than she who was the â€œperson responsible for the childâ€™s welfare.â€Â  However, at the hearing, Morgan acknowledged that as the bus monitor it was her responsibility to buckle the children in, monitor behavior, help the driver with any problems on the bus, and get the children off the bus.Â  In this case, she failed to unbuckle the child and left her on the bus for four hours.Â  Being left strapped in a closed vehicle for four hours certainly â€œpresent[s] a substantial risk of physical or mental injury to the child.â€Â  As DSSâ€™s Final Administrative Order notes, â€œIt was fortunate that the day this happened was overcast and not bright and sunny or the consequences to [the child] could have been severe, placing her in great risk of physical harm or death.â€Â  
Accordingly, we agree with the circuit court that DSSâ€™s finding of an indicated case of abuse or neglect is supported by substantial evidence. Â 
2.Â  Equal Protection
Morgan argues the application of South Carolina Code section 20-7-670 regarding intervention by child welfare agencies violates her rights to equal protection under the law as childcare employees are treated differently and are not afforded the same rights and privileges as individuals employed in other similarly situated facilities and institutions.Â  Morgan failed to raise this issue to the circuit court.Â  Accordingly, we find the issue is not properly before this court.Â  In re McCracken, 346 S.C. 87, 92, 551 S.E.2d 235, 238 (2001) (constitutional claim must be raised to and ruled upon by the lower court to be preserved for appellate review).
CONCLUSION
For the above stated reasons, the order of the family court is 
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ. concur.Â 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The child normally would have breakfast, lunch, and afternoon snack at the center.Â  
[3] The childâ€™s birth mother had used drugs during her pregnancy and the child was born with crack cocaine in her system.Â  When the child was four months old, her father dropped her on the floor and she fractured her skull. 
[4] This section provides:

When the investigation performed pursuant to this section results in a determination that an individual has harmed a child or threatened a child with harm, as defined in Section 20-7-490, the name of that individual must be entered immediately in the Central Registry of Child Abuse and Neglect. The department must notify the individual in writing by certified mail that his name has been entered in the registry, of his right to request an appeal of the decision to enter his name in the registry, and of the possible ramifications regarding future employment and licensing if he allows his name to remain in the registry. The procedures set forth in Section 20-7-655 apply when an individual challenges the entry of his name in the registry and challenges of the entry in the registry pursuant to this subsection must be given expedited review in the appellate process.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-670(I) (Supp. 2005).

title: J.W. Neal Construction v. Enon Missionary Baptist Church
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
J.W. Neal Construction, LLC, Respondent,
v.
Enon Missionary Baptist Church,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-355
Heard October 10, 2006 â€“ Filed October 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
M. M. Weinberg, Jr., of Sumter, for Appellant.
Thomas E. Player, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this action for breach of a construction contract, Enon Missionary Baptist Church (Church) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to J.W. Neal Construction Company (Contractor).Â  On appeal, Church argues the construction contract required Contractor to procure a performance and payment bond and Contractorâ€™s failure to obtain this bond justified Churchâ€™s rescission of the contract.[1]Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Church decided to construct a building on its property and hired Thomas R. King as its architect.[2]Â  King invited bids on the construction project from general contractors.Â  Contractor was a newly formed general contracting company, owned solely by Wilfred Neal and run by Wilfred and his father, Joshua Neal.Â  On May 10, 2002, Contractor submitted its bid to King.Â  Three days later, King informed Contractor it was the lowest bidder and awarded Contractor the job.Â  
On June 17, 2002, Joshua and the Reverend Stanley Hayes, the churchâ€™s pastor, executed a construction contract (the Contract), entitled â€œAIA Document A101 Standard Form of Agreement Between Owner and Contractor.â€Â  Section 9.1.2 of the Contract incorporates a list of conditions (the General Conditions), entitled â€œAIA Document A201 General Conditions of the Contract for Construction.â€Â  In addition, section 9.1.4 of the Contract incorporates the bidding requirements and specifications previously provided to Contractor as part of its bidding package.Â  
Section 11.4.1 of the General Conditions provides:

The Owner [Church] shall have the right to require the Contractor to furnish bonds covering faithful performance of the Contract and payment of obligations arising thereunder as stipulated in bidding requirements or specifically required in the Contract Documents on the date of execution of the Contract.

(emphasis added).Â  No other part of the Contract, either expressly or through incorporation, requires a performance or payment bond. 
On September 10, 2002, the National Bank of South Carolina (NBSC) issued a loan commitment to Church to fund the project.Â  On the same day, Contractor received a copy of this commitment.Â  The commitment requires a performance and payment bond.Â  As a result, Contractor attempted to procure a bond.Â  
Contractor had trouble obtaining the bond because it was a new company.Â  As a result, on December 10, 2002, King informed Contractor that Church decided to terminate the Contract.Â  Contractor responded, informing King and Church the Contract had no bond requirement, indicating Contractor obtained a bond on the day before, and requesting a meeting to work out the problem.Â  A letter dated December 11 shows Adams Eaddy & Associates (Bonding Company) had approved, but not issued, a bond to Contractor.Â  
On Monday, December 16, 2002, the parties met.Â  According to Churchâ€™s minutes from this meeting, King talked to Bonding Companyâ€™s agent, who informed him the bond should be issued by the end of the week.Â  The minutes also reflect Church informed Contractor it was negotiating with a different contractor and â€œthe other contractor has a legitimate chance of obtaining the project if . . . Neal failed to obtain the bond at a reasonable time.â€
On Friday, December 20, 2002, Bonding Company issued a performance and payment bond to Contractor.Â  Hayes and Budden wrote Contractor on the same day, explaining, â€œAt the meeting . . . you [Joshua] stated . . . you would have the bond by this week which would be December 18, 2002.â€Â  The letter also states â€œthe other contractor has a legitimate chance of obtaining the project if [Contractor] failed to obtain the bond at the time he stated which would have been December 19, 2002.â€Â  Hayes testified in his deposition that Joshua told him to get another contractor if he did not have the bond by December 18.Â  Despite the fact Contractor had a bond on December 20, Church rescinded the Contract.Â  As a result, Church hired a new general contractor. 
Subsequently, Contractor filed a complaint against Church for breach of the Contract.Â  After Church answered, Contractor moved for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court held a hearing and ultimately granted Contractorâ€™s motion, holding the Contract contained no performance and payment bond requirement and any modification of the Contract to include a bond requirement was not supported by consideration.Â  Alternatively, the circuit court held if the Contract did require a bond, Churchâ€™s rescission of the Contract based on this requirement was unjustified.Â  The circuit court left the issue of damages for a jury.Â  Church appealed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviews the grant of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the circuit court.Â  David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006).Â  The circuit court should grant summary judgment â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Byrd v. City of Hartsville, 365 S.C. 650, 656, 620 S.E.2d 76, 79 (2005).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Section 11.4.1 of the General Conditions
Church contends the circuit court erred in holding section 11.4.1 of the General Conditions did not require Contractor to obtain a performance and payment bond.Â  We disagree.
The construction and enforcement of an unambiguous contract is a question of law for the court, and thus can be properly disposed of at summary judgment.Â  Middleborough Horizâ€™l Prop. Regime Council of Co-Owners v. Montedison
S.p.A., 320 S.C. 470, 477, 465 S.E.2d 765, 770 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The cardinal rule of contract interpretation is to ascertain and give legal effect to the partiesâ€™ intentions as determined by the contract language.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â  â€œThe judicial function of a court of law is to enforce contracts as made by the parties and not to re-write or distort, under the guise of judicial construction, the terms of an unambiguous contract.â€Â  Dobyns v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Parks, Rec. & Tourism, 325 S.C. 97, 103, 480 S.E.2d 81, 84 (1997).Â  When the language of a written contract is clear and unambiguous, the contract shall determine the rights and obligations of the parties.Â  Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Rec. Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 8, 605 S.E.2d 744, 747 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
Section 11.4.1 of the General Conditions unambiguously requires another portion of the Contract to trigger Churchâ€™s right to require a performance and payment bond.Â  The bidding requirements provided to Contractor do not require a performance and payment bond.Â  In fact, King specifically testified he omitted the bond requirement from the specifications and bid requirements provided to Contractor.Â  Moreover, Church admitted no other provision of the Contract required such a bond at the summary judgment hearing: â€œThere is no question about it . . . itâ€™s [the bond requirementâ€™s] not on the face of the contractor papers or bid papers.â€Â  Additionally, in his deposition, Hayes explained Church would cover the cost of the bond when Contractor obtained it â€œbecause it wasnâ€™t in the initial contract.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  Under a plain reading of section 11.4.1, Church does not have a right to require Contractor to furnish a performance and payment bond.[3]
II. Kingâ€™s Deposition Testimony
Church next argues Kingâ€™s deposition testimony indicates that, prior to execution of the Contract, the parties agreed to include a bond requirement.Â  The circuit court did not rule on this issue, and Church did not make a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion to obtain a ruling on this issue.Â  Accordingly, Church failed to preserve this issue for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  Moreover, â€œ[t]he parol evidence rule prevents the introduction of extrinsic evidence of agreements or understandings contemporaneous with or prior to execution of a written instrument when the extrinsic evidence is to be used to contradict, vary, or explain the written instrument.â€Â  Gilliland v. Elmwood Props., 301 S.C. 295, 302, 391 S.E.2d 577, 581 (1990).Â  Accordingly, we refuse to consider Kingâ€™s deposition testimony in determining whether the parties included a bond requirement in the Contract.
III. Churchâ€™s Rescission
Finally, Church takes exception to the circuit courtâ€™s holding that if a performance and payment bond were required by the Contract, Contractorâ€™s failure to obtain the bond within the time specified by Church did not constitute a material breach of the Contract justifying Churchâ€™s rescission.Â  Because the Contract clearly does not require Contractor to obtain a performance and payment bond, we decline to address this issue.
CONCLUSION
The circuit court properly held the Contract did not require Contractor to obtain a performance and payment bond.Â  Moreover, Church failed to preserve the issue of the effect of a prior agreement between the parties on the Contract.Â  Furthermore, we need not address the issue of whether Contractorâ€™s failure to obtain a performance and payment bond justified Churchâ€™s rescission of the Contract.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ., concur. 

[1] Both the partiesâ€™ briefs and the circuit courtâ€™s order refer to Churchâ€™s â€œrepudiationâ€ of the contract.Â  A â€œrepudiationâ€ is â€œ[a] contracting partyâ€™s words or actions that indicate an intention not to perform the contract in the future; a threatened breach of contract.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1306 (7th ed. 1999).Â  A â€œrescissionâ€ is â€œ[a] partyâ€™s unilateral unmaking of a contract for a legally sufficient reason, such as the other partyâ€™s material breach.â€Â  Id. at 1308.Â  A review of the case reveals the issue is whether Churchâ€™s rescission of the contract is justified.
[2] In his deposition, Hazel Budden, a member of Churchâ€™s board of trustees, testified the building would be a church.Â  However, a loan commitment indicates the building would be a â€œFamily Life Center.â€ 
[3] In its appellate brief, Church does not argue that subsequent to execution the contract was modified to include the bonding requirement.Â  Therefore, this issue is not properly before this court for review.Â  See State v. Nelson, 336 S.C. 186, 192, 519 S.E.2d 786, 789 (1999).Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The Friends of McLeod, Inc., Appellant,
v.
Historic Charleston Foundation, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Diane S. Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-356
Heard October 11, 2006 â€“ Filed October 20, 2006

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Stephanie P. McDonald and O. Benjamin Peeples, Jr., both of Charleston, for Appellant.
William C. Cleveland, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The Friends of McLeod, Inc. (Friends) brought an action against the Historic Charleston Foundation (the Foundation) asserting the Foundation failed to comply with the provisions of the Last Will of William E. McLeod by selling property known as the McLeod Plantation.Â  The circuit court granted the Foundationâ€™s motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(h), SCRCP, concluding it did not have subject matter jurisdiction because an action to construe a will must first be brought in the probate court, pursuant to section 62-1-302 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  We affirm as modified.
1. The circuit court correctly held it was without subject matter jurisdiction to hear this action, which seeks to construe a will.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(a)(1) (Supp. 2005) (â€œTo the full extent permitted by the Constitution, and except as otherwise specifically provided, the probate court has exclusive original jurisdiction over all subject matter related to . . . estates of decedents, including the contest of wills, construction of wills, and determination of heirs and successors of decedents and estates of protected persons; . . . .â€)Â  (emphasis added).Â  This statute clearly states the construction of wills is within the exclusive original jurisdiction of the probate court.Â  See S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 470, 602 S.E.2d 81, 82 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œStatutory interpretation is a question of law.â€).Â  Friends relies solely on pre-1987 cases that provide the circuit court has jurisdiction to construe the terms of a will.Â  In 1987, however, the legislature amended section 62-1-302(a)(1) by adding the word â€œprobateâ€ before the word â€œcourt.â€Â  The legislatureâ€™s inclusion of the word â€œprobateâ€ clearly evinces the intent to grant the probate court â€œexclusive original jurisdictionâ€ in such matters.Â  Therefore, reliance on pre-1987 cases is misplaced.Â  The law does authorize the removal of certain actionsâ€”including an action to construe a willâ€”from the probate court to the circuit court.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(d) (Supp. 2005) (â€œNotwithstanding the exclusive jurisdiction of the probate court over the foregoing matters, any action or proceeding filed in the probate court and relating to the following subject matters, on motion of a party, or by the court on its own motion, made not later than ten days following the date on which all responsive pleadings must be filed, must be removed to the circuit
court and in these cases the circuit court shall proceed upon the matter de novo: . . . (2) construction of wills; . . . .â€).
2.Â  Because the circuit court correctly determined it lacked subject matter jurisdiction to entertain this matter in the first instance, the additional findings of the circuit court are vacated.Â  See Simmons v. Simmons, 370 S.C. 109, __, 634 S.E.2d 1, 4 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an order entered by a court without subject matter jurisdiction is utterly void.â€).Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

title: Tretola v. Summer
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Robert J. Tretola, Appellant,
v.
David Summer; Parker Poe Adams & Bernstein,
L.L.P.; David Miller; Daniel McKay; and Lancaster Hospital Corporation, d/b/a Springs Memorial Hospital,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-357
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 23, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert J. Tretola, of Lancaster, pro se.
Don S. Rushing, of Lancaster, for Respondents Daniel McKay and Lancaster Hospital Corporation, d/b/a Springs Memorial Hospital.
Pope D. Johnson, III, of Columbia, for Respondent Parker Poe Adams & Bernstein, L.L.P.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Robert J. Tretola appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Parker Poe Adams & Bernstein, L.L.P. (Law Firm), Daniel McKay, and Lancaster Hospital Corporation, d/b/a Springs Memorial Hospital (Hospital), on Tretolaâ€™s causes of action for violation of his attorney-client privilege, invasion of privacy, civil conspiracy, and breach of contract.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The present litigation arose out of a lawsuit in the federal court between Hospital and SouthCross Surgery Center, L.L.C., both of whom were vying for a certificate of need (CON) to establish an ambulatory surgery center in Lancaster County, South Carolina. Â 
SouthCross was formed in September 2002 by Tretola, a Lancaster physician working as a surgeon for Hospital, and several surgeons from the Charlotte area.Â  About the same time SouthCrossâ€™s CON application was pending, twelve investors, including Tretola and McKay, Hospitalâ€™s chief executive officer, formed SportSouth, L.L.C., a land development company.Â  SportSouth later entered into an arrangement with Hospital whereby SportSouth would build use property on which it had acquired an option to build an ambulatory surgery center that Hospital would lease.Â  By letter dated July 29, 2003, Tretola communicated to McKay his support of this endeavor.
In the spring of 2003, Tretola, on McKayâ€™s advice, had met with attorney David Summer, who was affiliated with Law Firm, and retained Law Firm to seek a withdrawal from SouthCross and a refund of his investment interest.Â  Although Law Firm initiated a lawsuit on Tretolaâ€™s behalf claiming damages for breach of contract and breach of fiduciary duty, Tretola later expressed frustration with Law Firm and hired a different attorney to take over his case.
During the course of Tretolaâ€™s lawsuit, SouthCross deposed both Tretola and McKay.Â  Apparently, their testimony conflicted about certain events leading up to DHECâ€™s review of SouthCrossâ€™s CON application.Â  Subsequently, DHEC issued a CON to Hospital and denied a CON to SouthCross.Â  SouthCross then filed a lawsuit in the federal district court against Hospital, SportSouth, McKay, and Tretola, alleging civil conspiracy.
During the federal litigation, SouthCross deposed a SportSouth partner who produced a letter dated February 19, 2004, from Summer to Hospitalâ€™s corporate attorney.[2]Â  According to the letter, it was copied to both McKay and Miller, Hospitalâ€™s president.Â  In the letter, Summer suggested Tretolaâ€™s â€œspeculative statementsâ€ during the deposition he gave in his own lawsuit against SouthCross resulted in the federal court action.Â  Summer also noted he previously represented Tretola and the two had mutually agreed to end the relationship.
Hospital and McKay asked the federal court for an order protecting the letter as a privileged attorney-client communication.Â  Although the district court held Hospital and McKay had waived their attorney-client privilege regarding information in the letter, it protected information in the letter pertaining to Tretola on the ground that he had not waived his attorney-client privilege. 
After discovering the letter, Tretola filed a complaint alleging (1) violation of his attorney-client privilege by Summer and Law Firm for disseminating information in the letter; (2) invasion of his right to privacy against Summer, Miller, and McKay for publishing the letter to SportSouth and Edwards; and (3) civil conspiracy against Hospital, Summer, Miller, and McKay for attempting to make Tretola a â€œscapegoatâ€ in the pending federal action.Â  Tretola further alleged Hospital, through McKay and Miller, breached an oral contract whereby Tretola would provide a statement in favor of granting a CON to Hospital and receive first priority to invest in the new ambulatory surgery center.Â  
McKay and Hospital answered and moved to dismiss.Â  Law Firm also filed a motion to dismiss.Â  The trial court held a hearing, at which Law Firm, McKay, and Hospital (collectively Respondents) converted their motions and asked for summary judgment.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to Respondents.[3]Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
1.Â  Tretolaâ€™s first issue on appeal concerns alleged procedural irregularities surrounding the trial courtâ€™s handling of the summary judgment motion.Â  Specifically, Tretola appears to assert (1) he lacked sufficient time and opportunity to conduct discovery; and (2) the subject of the hearing had been abruptly changed from a motion for judgment on the pleadings to one for summary judgment without allowing him to respond to newly submitted documents or to produce documents of his own.Â  Because, however, the trial court did not make any specific rulings on these issues and the record does not indicate Tretola raised them in a motion to alter or amend the appealed order, these exceptions are not preserved for appellate review.[4]
2.Â  In Tretolaâ€™s second issue on appeal, he makes the additional argument that â€œwhat little evidence we have is clearly in disputeâ€ and, based on this assertion, contends additional discovery is warranted.Â  Notwithstanding this assertion, for reasons explained below we decline to reverse the grant of summary judgment to Respondents.
3.Â  Tretola next argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on his claim for violation of attorney-client privilege through the dissemination of the February 19, 2004 letter.Â  He takes direct issue with the trial courtâ€™s determination that this State does not recognize a private cause of action for violation of an attorney-client privilege.Â  We reject this argument.Â  
In addition to holding that â€œSouth Carolina does not recognize the cause of action for violation of the attorney/client privilege,â€ the trial court further noted that â€œthere exists an order of the federal court in the underlying action which gives rise to [Tretolaâ€™s] claims in this action which order specifically finds no waiver of [Tretolaâ€™s] attorney-client privilege and which prohibits any use of the letter and of any privileged information relative to [Tretola], if any.â€Â  We view this statement, which is tantamount to a finding that Tretola was not adversely affected by the dissemination of the letter, as an independent ground for the grant of summary judgment on his claim for violation of his attorney-client privilege.[5]Â  Because Tretola does not challenge this determination on appeal, we are compelled to affirm the grant of summary judgment on this cause of action.[6]
4.Â  We find no merit to Tretolaâ€™s contention that the trial court mischaracterized one of his claims as one for fraud when it was actually one for breach of contract.Â  To the contrary, it appears that, because Tretola labeled his fourth cause of action as one for â€œFraud (Breach of Contract),â€ the trial court was willing to consider whether either fraud or breach of contract would be a viable theory for recovery in this lawsuit.Â  Having determined that, even under a liberal construction of the complaint, Tretola could not proceed on a fraud claim because he failed to allege the necessary elements, the trial court then attempted to determine if Tretola could proceed on an action for breach of contract.Â  The trial court then held there was no evidence presenting a genuine issue of material fact as to whether Tretola had a valid contract with McKay and Hospital entitling him to an opportunity to invest in Hospitalâ€™s new ambulatory surgery center.Â  We agree with this holding.Â  Tretolaâ€™s affidavit indicates only that McKay had advised him physicians practicing at Hospital would be offered â€œpreferential and first choiceâ€ to invest in the center and that, at the request of McKay and Hospital, he signed a form letter supporting the project.Â  Nowhere in the affidavit does he even suggest that his support for the center was given in exchange for the right of first refusal to invest in it.[7]Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on Tretolaâ€™s action for breach of contract.[8]
5.Â  We reject Tretolaâ€™s argument that the trial court should have held Law Firm in default because it did not file an answer.Â  The record does not indicate Tretola ever raised this issue to the trial court or otherwise attempt to obtain a ruling; therefore, Tretola did not preserve this issue for our review.[9]Â  In any event, Law Firmâ€™s timely motion under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, would have extended the time that it would have had to file an answer if the trial court had denied the motion.[10]
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The deponent testified he could not remember where he got this letter.
[3] In the appealed order, the trial court noted Miller had been served only two weeks before the hearing and Summer had not been served at all. 
[4]Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (holding an issue not explicitly ruled on by the trial court is not preserved for appellate review when the appellant fails to move to alter or amend the judgment on that ground).
[5]Â  In other words, the trial court relied on the requirement that a plaintiff must show damages to recover on a private cause of action in tort.Â  Cf. Baggerly v. CSX Transp., Op. No. 26208 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Aug. 28, 2006) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 34, at 49, 53) (noting â€œdamage proximately resulting from the breach of dutyâ€ an element of a negligence cause of action).
[6]Â  See Anderson v. Short, 323 S.C. 522, 525, 476 S.E.2d 475, 477 (1996) (affirming the trial courtâ€™s decision because it was based on two grounds, only one of which was appealed); Buckner v. Preferred Mut. Ins. Co., 255 S.C. 159, 161, 177 S.E.2d 544, 544 (1970) (recognizing an unappealed decision of the circuit court, â€œright or wrong, is the law of the case and requires affirmanceâ€), Weeks v. McMillan, 291 S.C. 287, 292, 353 S.E.2d 289, 292 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œWhere a decision is based on alternative grounds, either of which independent of the other is sufficient to support it, the decision will not be reversed even if one of the grounds is erroneous.â€).
[7]Â  See Prestwick Golf Club, Inc. v. Prestwick Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 331 S.C. 385, 390, 503 S.E.2d 184, 187 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œIn order for a contract to be binding, there must be a mutual manifestation of assent between the parties to the terms of the contract.â€).
[8]Â  In the section of his brief concerning his breach of contract claim, Tretola includes arguments that (1) the trial court misinterpreted his allegations relating to his cause of action for conspiracy; (2) the trial court treated him unfairly because he was representing himself; and (3) the trial court improperly considered statements of counsel as evidence.Â  We hold these arguments do not comply with Rule 208(b)(1), SCACR, and decline to address them for that reason.
[9] See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
[10] See Rule 12(a), SCRCP (providing that the service of certain motions alters the time allotted to a defendant to serve an answer and noting that, unless the court orders otherwise, the responsive pleading is to be served within 15 days after notice of the courtâ€™s action if the court denies the motion or postpones its disposition until the trial on the merits).

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, Barry Lee Underwood, was indicted for and convicted of trafficking in methamphetamine, possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, and possession with intent to distribute a controlled substance.Â  The trial court sentenced Underwood to thirty years on the trafficking charge, and five years each on the firearm charge and possession with intent to distribute charge.Â  Underwood appeals, asserting the trial court erred in failing to suppress evidence based on insufficient search warrants.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities: State v. Mitchell, 330 S.C. 189, 193 n.3, 498 S.E.2d 642, 644 n.3 (1998);Â  State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 42, 479 S.E.2d 57, 60 (1996);Â  State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 859, 862 (1993) (noting a ruling in limine is not a final ruling on the admissibility of evidence and thus requires an objection be made at the time the evidence is offered in order to preserve the issue for review); State v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 500, 623 S.E.2d 378, 386 (2005) (holding that in most cases, making a motion in limine to exclude evidence at the beginning of trial does not preserve the issue for review because a motion in limine is not a final determination, and the moving party must make a contemporaneous motion at the time the evidence is introduced); Â State v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 500, 623 S.E.2d 378, 386 (2005); Â State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 642, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001) (finding exception to rule requiring a contemporaneous objection occurs where the trial court makes a ruling on the admission of the evidence on the record immediately prior to the introduction of evidence in question);Â  State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, 265-66, 589 S.E.2d 6, 9 (2003)Â  (holding a motion for directed verdict challenges the sufficiency of properly admitted evidence and where evidence is not objected to when offered, it is properly admitted evidence).
AFFIRMED.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.

In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Dale C. Pfeil, II, d/b/a DP Associates, Appellant,
v.
Steven Walker Homes
Corporation; Steven Walker
Homes, L.L.C.; Steven
Walker Communities, Inc.;
Steven Berzansky and David
Peery, d/b/a Steven Walker
Homes Corporation, Steven
Walker Homes L.L.C. and
Steven Walker Communities,
Inc.; Robert W. Palmer;
Rebecca W. Palmer; Kenneth C.
Nugent; Laurese A. Nugent;
Chase Manhattan Mortgage
Corporation; First Gaston Bank
of North Carolina; Pamela
Macaluso; Daniel L. Luithele;
Melissa D. Luithele; Wachovia
Bank; Fieldstone Mortgage
Corporation; Crown Homes,
Inc.; Joanne M. Anderson;
Wachovia Mortgage Corporation;
Cooperative Mortgage Services,
Inc.; First Union National Bank;
Brian C. Wilson; John E. Peterson;
Harper Peterson & Rogers, P.A.;
Harper, Peterson, Rogers & Reno,
P.A.; and Marvin Barman, Defendants. 
Of whom Steven Walker
Homes Corporation;
Steven Walker Homes, L.L.C.,
Steve Berzansky; David Peery;
Pamela Macaluso; Fieldstone
Mortgage Corporation;
Crown Homes, Inc.; Joanne M.
Anderson; Wachovia Mortgage
Corporation; Brian C. Wilson;
Harper Peterson Rogers &
Reno, P.A.; and Marvin Barman
are Respondents.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
      
    
  


Appeal from York County
S. Jackson Kimball, Master In Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-359
Submitted September 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 23, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mitchell K. Byrd, of Hilton Head, for Appellant.Â  
Brian S. McCoy, of Rock Hill, for Respondents Steven Walker Homes Corporation, Steven Walker Homes, L.L.C., Steven Berzansky, David Peery, and Marvin Barman.
Curtis W. Dowling and Andrea C. Pope, both of Columbia, for Respondent Harper, Peterson, Rogers & Reno, P.A.
John J. Hearn, of Columbia, for Respondent Joanne M. Anderson.
Lucy L. McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondent Brian C. Wilson.
Louis H. Lang, of Columbia, for Respondents Pamela Macaluso, Crown Homes, Inc., and Fieldstone Mortgage Corporation.
Pearce W. Fleming, of Columbia, for Respondent Wachovia Mortgage Corporation.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Dale C. Pfeil, II, doing business as DP Associates, appeals the grant of partial summary judgment to Steven Walker Homes, L.L.C. and its principals (collectively Walker[1]), and the grant of summary judgment to all other defendants. Â We affirm.[2]
FACTS
Walker, a home builder, purchased property in Fort Mill, South Carolina, for development purposes and NationsBank financed the purchase.Â  This appeal focuses on two lots in the developed property: Â Lot 33 in Wentworth Subdivision, and Lot 130 in Keswick Subdivision.Â  
Pfeil was a masonry subcontractor for Walker.Â  When Walker began experiencing serious financial difficulties, Pfeil served and filed mechanicâ€™s liens on thirteen of the lots in the subdivisions on which he had performed work.Â  Pfeil then brought an action to foreclose his mechanicâ€™s liens, and John Peterson, an attorney from Harper, Peterson, Richards & Reno, P.A. (the law firm) answered on Walkerâ€™s behalf. Â After accepting partial payments from Walker, Pfeil dropped his mechanicâ€™s liens and sought the remaining monies owed to him through a debt collection action. Â He eventually obtained a confession of judgment from Walker. Â 
In the interim, NationsBank brought an action to foreclose its mortgages, and named Pfeil as a defendant.Â  Pfeil defaulted.Â  
In an effort to maximize return for Walkerâ€™s creditors, Marvin Barman, a workout specialist, was engaged to seek private buyers for several parcels instead of resorting to a public sale.Â  As a result, Lot 33, which had a partially built home, was bought by Pamela Macaluso, who completed the construction and sold the property to Daniel and Melissa Luithele.Â  Brian Wilson was the closing attorney on the sale.Â  Lot 130, undeveloped at the time, was purchased by Crown Homes, which resold it to Joanne Anderson, whose purchase was financed by Wachovia Mortgage.Â  Pfeil had yet to file his confession of judgment at the time of the transfers.Â  
In order to sell both Lot 33 and Lot 130, Walker had to obtain releases from certain creditors and use its own funds to pay closing costs.Â  Walker received no money from either closing, and all the proceeds were paid to NationsBank, the primary lienholder on the respective lots.Â  
Pfeil filed an action to enforce his judgment against Walker.Â  At the time, Walker had no assets, so Pfeil sought to pierce the corporate veil and obtain personal judgments against Berzansky and Peery. Â Pfeil later amended his complaint to set aside the conveyance of Lot 33 and Lot 130 to the Luitheles and Anderson, claiming the conveyances were fraudulent and unlawful, or both.Â  In addition he alleged breach of trust by Walker and civil conspiracy, unfair trade practices, and intentional harm against Walker, Wilson, Barman, and the law firm.Â  
Wilson, Barman, and the law firm filed motions for summary judgment, which the circuit court granted.Â  Walker also moved for summary judgment, which the circuit court partially granted.Â  The circuit court denied Walker summary judgment on Pfeilâ€™s claims to enforce the confession of judgment, for veil piercing, and for breach of trust.Â  
ISSUES

  
    
      I. 
       Did the circuit court err in granting summary judgment to all defendants on Pfeilâ€™s fraudulent conveyance claim?
        
        
    
    
      II. 
       Did the circuit court err in granting summary judgment to all defendants on Pfeilâ€™s unlawful assignment claim?
        
        
    
    
      III.
       Did the circuit court err in granting summary judgment to Walker, Wilson, Barman, and the law firm on Pfeilâ€™s unfair trade practices, civil conspiracy, and intentional harm claims?
    
  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviews the grant of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the circuit court.Â  David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006).Â  The circuit court should grant summary judgment â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Underwood v. Coponen, 367 S.C. 214, 217, 625 S.E.2d 236, 237 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Fraudulent Conveyance
Pfeil argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to all defendants on his fraudulent conveyance claim.Â  We disagree.
The Statute of Elizabeth, codified at section 27-23-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), renders void any transfer of property made with the â€œintent or purpose to delay, hinder, or
defraud creditors and others.â€Â  Carr v. Guerard, 365 S.C. 151, 153-54, 616 S.E.2d 429, 430 (2005).Â  When a transfer is supported by valuable consideration, it may be set aside as a fraudulent conveyance only if an actual intent to defraud creditors may be imputable to the grantee.Â  Royal Z Lanes, Inc. v. Collins Holding Corp., 337 S.C. 592, 594, 524 S.E.2d 621, 622 (1999). 
A creditor seeking to void a transfer need not establish actual knowledge of, or participation in, the debtorâ€™s fraudulent intention by the grantee.Â  See Coleman v. Daniel, 261 S.C. 198, 210, 199 S.E.2d 74, 80 (1973).Â  Rather, â€œ[t]he transaction is subject to attack if at the time of the transfer the transferee had notice of circumstances which would arouse the suspicion of an ordinarily prudent man and cause him to make inquiry as to the purpose for which the transfer was being made, which would disclose the fraudulent intent of the maker.â€Â  Id. at 210-11, 199 S.E.2d at 80.Â  
In this case, both transfers were supported by valuable consideration.Â  Accordingly, Pfeil must show Walkerâ€™s alleged fraudulent is imputable to the grantees.Â  Pfeil essentially alleges Walker had fraudulent intent because it preferred NationsBank over Pfeil.Â  However, â€œ[a] mere knowledge that the effect of [a] preference would be to hinder or delay other creditors is not sufficient to taint the transaction, if there be no actual intent that the preference shall have such result.â€Â  McElwee v. Kennedy, 56 S.C. 154, 172, 34 S.E. 86, 92 (1899).Â  The transfers here provided no benefit to Walker save the cancellation of a preexisting debt to NationsBank.Â  Therefore, Pfeil has only shown an intent by Walker to pay NationsBank, the priority secured lender on Lot 33 and Lot 130.Â  Because Pfeil cannot show fraudulent intent by Walker, he cannot show a similar intent by grantees.
Additionally, NationBankâ€™s status as a secured creditor with respect to Lot 33 and Lot 130 thwarts Pfeilâ€™s fraudulent conveyance theory.Â  In Owings v. Graham, 120 S.C. 408, 451, 113 S.E. 279, 293 (1922), our supreme court held that to be fraudulent, â€œthe subject-matter of [a conveyance] should be something out of which the creditor could otherwise have realized all or a portion of his claim.â€ Â 
Pfeil does not argue his claim, unsecured at the time of these transfers, took priority over the claim of NationsBank or other secured creditors.Â  Even if Pfeil had been a lien creditor at the time of the transfers, he would not have had priority over NationsBank because NationsBank had a properly recorded mortgage on both Lot 33 and Lot 130.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-7-10 (Supp. 2005) (providing mortgagee with properly recorded mortgage on real property priority over lien creditors and other creditors).Â  Pfeil does not dispute NationsBank had first priority in any proceeds from the sale of both Lot 33 and Lot 130.Â  In this case, Pfeil produced no evidence that he would have received payment of his debt had Walker not transferred Lot 33 or Lot 130.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court properly granted summary judgment to all respondents on Pfeilâ€™s fraudulent conveyance claim.[3]
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Unlawful Assignment
Pfeil contends the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to all defendants on his unlawful assignment claim.Â  We disagree.
Section 27-25-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides, in pertinent part:

Any assignment by an insolvent debtor of his property for the benefit of his creditors in which any preference or priority is given to any creditor or creditors of the debtor by the terms of the assignment over any other creditor or creditors, other than as to any debts . . . in which any provision or disposition of the property so assigned is made or directed other than that it be distributed among all creditors of the insolvent debtor equally, in proportion to the amount of their several demands and without preference or priority of any kind whatsoever . . . shall be absolutely null and void and of no effect whatsoever.

(emphasis added).
We reiterate NationsBank filed a properly recorded mortgage on both Lot 33 and Lot 130.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-7-10 (Supp. 2005).Â  The proceeds from the transfers here benefited only NationsBank and other junior, secured creditors.Â  Pfeil does not dispute that these creditors had a right to any proceeds from these transfers over any unsecured creditors or lien creditors.Â  Thus, it does not meet the emphasized condition of 27-25-10 that without the transfer, Pfeil would have taken equally from the proceeds of this sale.Â  Accordingly, we hold the circuit court properly found Pfeil failed to show a violation of section 27-25-10.
III.Â Â Â  Other Causes of Action
Pfeil argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Wilson, Barman, the law firm, and Walker on his unfair trade practice, civil conspiracy, and intentional harm claims.Â  We disagree.
To recover pursuant to the Unfair Trade Practices Act, â€œone must prove each of the following three elements by the greater weight or preponderance of the evidence: Â 1) a violation of the Act, 2) proximate cause, and 3) damages.â€ Â Charleston Lumber Co., Inc. v. Miller Housing Corp., 318 S.C. 471, 482, 458 S.E.2d 431, 438 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  In this case, Pfeil alleges Wilson, Barman, and the law firm misled grantees, neglected to inform grantees of Pfeilâ€™s pending claim, and failed to adequately disclose conflicts of interest to grantees.Â  
â€œA civil conspiracy is a combination of two or more parties joined for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff, thereby causing . . . special damages.â€Â  Angus v. Burroughs & Chapin Co., 368 S.C. 167, 170, 628 S.E.2d 261, 262 (2006).Â  In his appellate brief, Pfeil characterizes the civil conspiracy that Walker, Wilson, Barman, and the law firm engaged in a plan â€œto sell [Walkerâ€™s] property without paying creditors like Pfeil even if the claim was known to be pending on the public record.â€Â  
Based on Pfeilâ€™s appellate brief, we interpret his claim of intentional harm to be a claim for intentional deprivation of a pecuniary or protected property interest.Â  â€œA person who does any tortious act for the purpose of causing harm to another or to his things or to the pecuniary interests of another is liable to the other for such harm if it results.â€Â  Stewart v. Martin, 232 S.C. 483, 487, 102 S.E.2d 886, 888 (1958) (citation omitted).Â  
Even if the acts alleged here rose to the level of an unfair or deceptive trade practice, a civil conspiracy, or an intent to harm Pfeilâ€™s pecuniary or protected property interest, Pfeil fails to produce evidence he was damaged.Â  For the reasons stated previously, Pfeil failed to show he could have recovered even if the transfers had not occurred.Â  Accordingly, we hold the circuit court properly granted summary judgment to Wilson, Barman, the law firm, and Walker with respect to Pfeilâ€™s unfair trade practice, civil conspiracy, and intentional harm claims.
AFFIRMED.Â  
 HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]  The entity Steven Walker Homes Corporation and individuals Steven Berzansky and David Peery manage Steven Walker Homes, L.L.C.Â  
[2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  Pfeil additionally argues the circuit court erred in finding Barman, Wilson, the law firm, and Berzansky did not aid or abet the alleged fraudulent conveyances.Â  Because we find Pfeil failed to show a fraudulent conveyance, we need not address this issue.Â

PER CURIAM: In this condemnation proceeding, Ronald Paul, a lessee of condemned land, appeals the circuit courtâ€™s award of $2,450.00 for the taking of his leasehold interest.Â  We affirm[1] Â pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR, and the following authorities:

Holman, 308 S.C. 105, 107, 417 S.E.2d 107, 108 (Ct. App. 1992) (stating the acts of an attorney are directly attributable to and binding on his client).Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Patricia W. Harsey, Respondent
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Robert Mills Thomas, Appellant
      
    
  


Appeal from Lexington County
Â Jocelyn B. Cate, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-361
Heard September 14, 2006 â€“ Filed October 24, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
        Timothy G. Quinn, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Jean Perrin Derrick, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Robert Mills Thomas (Father) appeals from a family court order requiring him to (1) pay for his nineteen-year-old daughterâ€™s car expenses, (2) repay one of her student loans, and (3) pay $800 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â Â Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.Â  
FACTS
Father and Patricia W. Harsey (Mother) were married on January 16, 1982, and separated on October 24, 1985.Â  Approximately four months after their separation, the coupleâ€™s only child, Ashley Nicole Thomas (Daughter), was born. With Fatherâ€™s consent, the family court gave Mother sole custody of Daughter and ordered Father to pay $240 in child support per month. Â The order is silent on the matter of college or educational expenses. 
Shortly before Daughterâ€™s high school graduation, Father wrote a letter to Mother informing her he would cease paying child support in April of 2004, which was Daughterâ€™s last month of high school.Â  Father indicated in this letter that he would continue to send Daughter money until she graduated college, though he refused to contribute directly to the college expenses.[1] After receiving this letter, Mother filed an action in the family court, seeking continued support while Daughter attended college.Â  By the time this complaint was filed, Daughter had been accepted to Converse College beginning in the fall of 2004.Â  Because of her excellent academic record, Daughter received enough financial aid through scholarships and grants to be able to pay for her room and board.Â  However, Mother sought Fatherâ€™s help to pay for Daughterâ€™s additional expenses. 
At trial, Mother requested $8,000-10,000 per year for Daughterâ€™s miscellaneous expenses, including the car Daughterâ€™s maternal grandfather gave her. The family court found that â€œbased on the facts of this case, it is necessary for Daughter to have an automobile to enable her to attend college.â€ Â Pursuant to that ruling, the family court ordered Father to pay $252.48 per month and Mother to pay $81.16 per month to cover the Daughterâ€™s car insurance, gas, and maintenance expenses.Â  The family court also ordered both parents to repay a $2,500 student loan Daughter had taken out, and it ordered Father to pay Mother $800 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When considering an appeal from the family court, appellate courts have the authority to find the facts in accordance with their view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  However, appellate courts defer to the family court judgeâ€™s determinations of witnessesâ€™ credibility because the family court judge had the opportunity to see and hear the witnesses testify.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Car Expenses 
Father concedes that pursuant to Risinger v. Risinger, 273 S.C. 36, 39, 253 S.E.2d 652, 653-54 (1979), a family court may order a parent to contribute to higher education expenses where there is evidence that: (1) the childâ€™s characteristics indicate he or she will benefit from college; (2) the child has the ability to make satisfactory grades; (3) the child would not otherwise be able to attend college; and (4) the parent is financially able to pay for college.Â  However, Father argues the family court erred in finding that a car is necessary to enable his emancipated daughter to attend college.Â  Father contends that because this finding is flawed, the subsequent finding that he should be required by court order to share in the expenses related to the car is flawed as well. 
At the hearing, Father conceded he would support his daughter, and he even agreed to contribute $300 a month â€œas long as [Mother] is willing to under court order, too, to contribute . . . .â€ Â Because of Fatherâ€™s willingness to pay up to $300 in monthly child support, the issue of whether the family court erred in ordering him to pay a lesser amount is not preserved for appeal.Â  TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 617, 503 S.E.2d 471, 474 (1998) (â€œAn issue conceded in a lower court may not be argued on appeal.â€).Â  Therefore, we affirm the family courtâ€™s order requiring Father to pay $252.48 per month in child support.[2] 
II. Student Loan
Father next argues that the family court erred in requiring him to re-pay Daughterâ€™s student loan when she graduates from college.Â  We agree.
Initially, we note that neither Mother nor Father were a party to the loan Daughter took out.Â  According to the loan contract, Daughter received $2,500 for her tuition in exchange for her agreement to teach in a critical needs area for two years after graduation.Â  If Daughter opts not to teach in a critical needs district, she is obligated to repay the loan.Â  
This type of student loan serves an important public purpose. Because it forgives the debt of those recipients who teach in critical needs areas, the loan encourages young teachers to accept positions in school districts that might otherwise have a difficult time attracting teachers.Â  By ordering Mother and Father to repay Daughterâ€™s loan if it is not forgiven, the family court negated the incentive to teach in a critical needs area.Â  We find this was a violation of public policy.Â  See Almers v. South Carolina Nat. Bank of Charleston, 265 S.C. 48, 60, 217 S.E.2d 135, 141 (1975) (explaining that although there is no â€œfast rule or definition of public policy applicable to all cases,â€ public policy generally â€œforbids one to do that which has a tendency to be injurious to the public welfareâ€).Â  
We are aware that courts are usually reluctant to invoke public policy to void a contract because â€œthe right of private contract is no small part [of] the liberty of the citizen[, and] the usual and most important function of courts of justice is to maintain and enforce contracts.â€Â  Id., at 60, 217 S.E.2d at 141.Â  In this case, however, the parties did not engage in a voluntary contract; rather, the family court made Father liable on a contract he was not a party to.Â  Just as courts are wary to void a contract based on public policy, so too do we oppose relieving Daughter of the contractual obligation she voluntarily undertook, especially when to do so would itself be a violation of public policy.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the portion of the family courtâ€™s order requiring Father to repay Daughterâ€™s student loan.
III. Equal Protection Argument
Next, Father argues that the family court erred in requiring divorced parents to contribute to the education of an emancipated child because it violates the equal protection clause.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review, as it was not raised until Fatherâ€™s Rule 59(e) Motion.Â  See Hickman v. Hickman, 301 S.C. 455, 456, 392 S.E.2d 482, 482 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œA party cannot use Rule 59(e) to present to the court an issue the party could have raised prior to judgment but did not.â€). 
IV. Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
Father also argues that if this court reverses the family court on appeal, the underlying award of attorneyâ€™s fees ought to be reversed as well. Â Arial v. Arial, 295 S.C. 286, 369 S.E.2d 146 (Ct. App. 1988). Â Because we are not reversing the trial court on all issues, and Mother is still receiving beneficial results from this action, we find no reason to overturn the trial court on the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  See Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 415, 368 S.E.2d 903 (1988) (â€œAn award of attorneysâ€™ fees and costs is a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.â€). Â Therefore, we affirm the family courtâ€™s decision regarding attorneyâ€™s fees. 
V. Frivolous Proceedings 
Finally, Father argues the family court erred in regard to his claim under the Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â  The Act provides, in part, as follows: 

  Any person who takes part in the procurement, initiation, continuation, or defense of any civil proceeding is subject to being assessed for payment of all or a portion of the attorneyâ€™s fees and court costs of the other party if . . . the proceedings have terminated in favor of the person seeking an assessment of the fees and costs.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-36-10 (Supp. 2005)
Here, the proceedings did not terminate entirely in Fatherâ€™s favor.Â  Therefore, he is not entitled to any award under the Frivolous Proceedings Act.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we affirm the family courtâ€™s award of child support and attorneyâ€™s fees, but reverse the portion of its order requiring Father to repay Daughterâ€™s student loan.Â Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED IN PART and REVERSED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Father did cease sending child support in April; however, he continued to send Daughter $300 per month. Â 
[2] We express no opinion as to whether it was â€œnecessaryâ€ for Daughter to have a car to attend college.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Larry Smith, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-362
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Tara Shurling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Jay E. Hodge, Jr., of Cheraw, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Larry Smith appeals his convictions for second degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor and two counts of contributing to the delinquency of a minor.Â  He argues the circuit court erred in denying his motion for directed verdict.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On March 20, 2004, Victim[2] left her grandmotherâ€™s home without the knowledge or consent of her grandmother.Â  At approximately midnight, Victim, was picked up outside the home and driven to a residence on Lee State Park Road in Darlington County.Â  Accompanying Victim on this drive were the twenty-year-old driver, the driverâ€™s seventeen-year-old brother, and Victimâ€™s fourteen-year-old girl friend.Â  The driver dropped off the three passengers and returned to her home.Â  
Once at the residence, Victim and her friend joined a group of people, including Larry Smith, in the â€œpool house.â€[3]Â  Everyone then spent some time in the pool house listening to music, playing pool, and drinking alcoholic beverages.Â  At approximately 3 a.m., John Jordan agreed to drive Victim and her girl friend home.Â  Because of Jordanâ€™s young age, he was not legally permitted to drive without a licensed driver over the age of nineteen, thus Smith agreed to accompany him.Â  Jordan dropped off Victimâ€™s friend at her home, but for reasons which are in dispute, Victim was never dropped off at her grandmotherâ€™s home.[4]Â  Victim returned to the Lee State Park Road residence where she spent the night.Â  
Victimâ€™s girl friend had telephoned Victimâ€™s grandmotherâ€™s home around 4 a.m. to make sure that Victim had made it home.Â  It was at this point that Victimâ€™s grandmother realized Victim was not there, and she called the police.Â  After speaking with Victimâ€™s friend, the police were able to locate Victim at the Lee State Park Road residence, and they returned her to her grandmotherâ€™s home.Â Â Â  
Although Victim did not indicate to her family that she had been sexually assaulted, her aunt took her to the hospital for an examination, and a rape kit was taken.Â  Victimâ€™s exam produced evidence of non-consensual sex, and semen was found in her vagina.Â  At the hospital, the police were told by Victimâ€™s mother that Smith had sexually assaulted her daughter, and on March 22, 2004, Victim confirmed the assault in a conversation with a social worker.Â  Â Â 
A Darlington County grand jury indicted Smith on second degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor and two counts of contributing to the delinquency of a minor.Â  At trial, the jury convicted Smith on all charges and the trial court sentenced him to a total of twelve years imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
“When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.” State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 593, 606 S.E.2d 475, 477-78 (2004). When reviewing a denial of a directed verdict, this Court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the state. State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999). “If there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.” Cherry, 361 S.C. at 593-94, 606 S.E.2d at 478. See State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 555, 564 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2002) (finding that on an appeal from trial court’s denial of a motion for a directed verdict, appellate court may only reverse the trial court if there is no evidence to support the trial court’s ruling). “When considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.” Erickson v. Jones Street Publishers, L.L.C., 368 S.C. 444, 463, 629 S.E.2d 653, 663 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Directed Verdict
Smith contends the trial court erred in denying his motion for directed verdict.Â  Smith maintains that there was no credible evidence to support a finding that he was guilty.Â  We disagree.
A.Â  Criminal Sexual Conduct
Section 16-3-655(2) of the South Carolina Code (2003)[5] states: â€œA person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the second degree if the actor engages in sexual battery with a victim who is fourteen years of age or less but who is at least eleven years of age.â€Â  Sexual battery, in pertinent part, is defined as â€œ[s]exual intercourse . . . or any intrusion, however slight, of any part of a personâ€™s body or of any object into the genital or anal openings of another personâ€™s body . . ..â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-651(h) (Supp. 2005).Â Â Â  
In this case, the State presented evidence that would allow a reasonable jury to find Smith sexually assaulted Victim.Â  Victim testified that she was twelve years old at the time of the incident.Â  Victim further testified that Smith shoved her on the bed, removed his and her clothing, and inserted his penis into her vagina.Â  It is undisputed that the twelve-year-old Victim had sexual intercourse on the night in question, and DNA analysis, while failing to provide the typical level of certainty, did not exclude Smith.[6]Â  
Smithâ€™s argument goes to the credibility of the Victim and the weight of the DNA evidence.Â  However, the credibility and weight of evidence are issues to be decided by the trier of fact.Â  Whether or not to believe testimony and how to weigh the evidence are tasks that fall squarely within the province of the jury.Â  We do not have the authority to disturb jury decisions in these areas.Â  Under our limited standard of review, we find there was evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s denial of Smithâ€™s directed verdict motion.Â  Therefore, we find no error by the trial court.
B.Â  Contributing to the Delinquency of a Minor
Section 16-17-490 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) states in pertinent part:

  It shall be unlawful for any person over eighteen years of age to knowingly and wilfully encourage, aid or cause or to do any act which shall cause or influence a minor: (1) To violate any law or any municipal ordinance; . . . Â (10) To so deport himself or herself as to wilfully injure or endanger his or her morals or health or the morals or health of others.Â Â Â Â  

â€œAppellantâ€™s act of encouraging a minor to drink beer and smoke marijuana, conduct which is illegal, clearly endangers the morals, if not the health, of the minor.â€Â  State v. Michau, 355 S.C. 73, 77, 583 S.E.2d 756, 758-59 (2003).
Smith testified that at the time of the April 2005 trial, he was thirty one years old, thus he was certainly over the age of eighteen at the time of the alleged incident.Â  Victimâ€™s fourteen-year-old friend testified that Smith handed her a beer for her and Victim to share.Â  Although Victim testified that it was not Smith who handed her friend the beer, the conflicting statements were properly submitted to the jury to weigh. Â Â Â 
Because there is evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s denial of Smithâ€™s directed verdict motion, we find no error.
CONCLUSION
We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of the directed verdict motion.Â  Based on the foregoing, Smithâ€™s convictions are
 AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2] As used in this opinion, â€œVictimâ€ refers to the minor child who was the victim of criminal sexual conduct.Â  While Appellant maintains his innocence, both sides agree that the minor had sexual intercourse on the night in question.Â  Since this minor was twelve-years-old and could not legally consent to sexual intercourse, she is undoubtedly the victim of criminal sexual conduct.
[3] The pool house is a structure located behind the Lee State Park Road residence.Â  This structure is a small building with a pool table.Â  
[4] Jordan and Smith testified Victim refused to exit the vehicle when they brought her to her grandmotherâ€™s home because she saw that her grandmother was awake, and she did not want to be in trouble.Â  Victim testified that she was held in the vehicle and not permitted to leave.Â  
[5] This statute was amended in 2005 and what was 16-3-655 (2) at the time of this conviction is now 16-3-655 (B).
[6] Because only a partial DNA profile was attained, DNA analysis was limited and resulted in a 1 in 1,600 chance that the DNA was not that of Smith.Â Â Â Â
