THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Dennis L. Snipes, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-363
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 24, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John F. Hardaway, of Columbia, and Lorilee M. Gates, of Studio City, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia, and John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dennis L. Snipes, Jr. appeals his conviction for criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree, contending the trial court erred in failing to find Snipesâ€™ right to a speedy trial was violated and in denying his motion for a directed verdict. We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In March of 2000, Snipes was living with his then girlfriend (Mother), her two children from a previous relationship, and Motherâ€™s youngest child, who was Snipeâ€™s son.Â  On the morning of March 18, 2001, Mother took the youngest child to get a haircut, leaving Snipes home alone with Motherâ€™s two older children. Â When Mother came home, her six year-old daughter (Victim) told Mother she had been sexually assaulted by Snipes.Â  Mother took all three children to her sisterâ€™s house at which time the police were contacted.Â  
When the police arrived, they spoke to Victim and then proceeded to Snipesâ€™ home, where Victim had indicated the assault occurred.Â  Once at the home, they found Snipes, along with his mother and his father, at the residence.Â  Snipesâ€™ parents came to the house because Snipes had telephoned his mother and his parents knew he was upset. Â Having received a call regarding someone making a threat to themselves with a firearm, the officers expected there might be weapons present at the scene.Â  Officers observed Snipes sitting on the couch within reach of a loaded pistol.Â  
Snipes told the officers that he had been watching a sexually explicit videotape when Victim walked in and observed on the tape a person in a car performing a lewd act.Â  Snipes stated to the officers that he told Victim if she ever stole from her mother again, â€œhe would make her do that to him.â€Â  As a result of a conversation they had with Mother and Victim, officers seized a red t-shirt, a white t-shirt, and a blue washcloth from the scene to be sent for DNA analysis.Â  
Later, at the Sheriffâ€™s Office, Snipes gave a written statement in which he reiterated that he was watching an X-rated movie when Victim walked into the room.Â  According to Snipeâ€™s statement, Victim saw a woman performing oral sex on a man in a car.Â  When Victim said what the girl was doing was â€œnasty,â€ Snipes told Victim, if she stole from her mother again â€œI will do you like that.â€Â  
Snipes was arrested on March 18, 2000.Â  Shortly thereafter, he posted bail and was out on bond.Â  The case was dismissed at a preliminary hearing in mid-May 2000.Â  On June 15, 2000, Snipes was directly indicted. Â Snipes was not arraigned until February 2002, at which time he was not jailed. Â Instead the State consented to Snipes remaining free on bond.Â  On July 30, 2002, a hearing was held on the Stateâ€™s motion to require Snipes to submit to a blood test.Â  Snipes was ultimately brought to trial on August 3, 2004.Â  
On the day of trial, Snipes moved to dismiss the charge based on the more than four-year delay in bringing the case to trial.Â  Defense counsel argued Snipes was prejudiced by the delay inasmuch as one possible defense witness, Dr. James Foutty, was no longer employed with the local hospital. Â Defense counsel admitted he had not attempted to locate the doctor by contacting the state medical board.Â  Additionally, the State maintained the testimony Snipes sought to elicit from the doctor was not contested.[2]Â  Snipes further argued he was prejudiced by the delay because the event had occurred over four years ago, Victim was six years old at that time of the event and eleven years old at the time of trial, and her memory was therefore not reliable. Â Snipes conceded he had not made a speedy trial motion prior to the day of trial and had not brought his desire to bring the case to trial to the courtâ€™s attention prior to that day.Â  After hearing the solicitorâ€™s explanation for the delay, the trial court noted it was concerned with the delay, and the ages of the cases in general in that county.Â  However, the court found â€œit [did not] reach the point . . . where [the court would] grant [the] motion to dismiss,â€ finding Snipes failed to show enough prejudice in the delay of the case to warrant dismissal.Â  
Victim testified at trial that on the morning of the incident, Mother took her brother to get a haircut, leaving her at home with her other brother and Snipes.Â  She and her brother were folding clothes in the living room when Snipes called her into his bedroom, where Snipes was sitting on the bed.Â  Snipes told Victim to shut the door and to take off her clothes, or she would be in trouble or get spanked.Â  Victim removed her clothes, at which point Snipes pulled down his own pants and told her to â€œsuck his private part or [she] would get spanked.â€Â  Victim did as she was told.Â  As she was performing the act on Snipes, he rubbed Victimâ€™s back.Â  It ended when Victim simply stopped.Â  She did not see â€œanything come out of his private part at anytime.â€Â  Victim rolled over on her back, and Snipes instructed her to close her eyes and turn her head.Â  Snipes went into the bathroom, came out with a rag with something on it, and rubbed the rag on her stomach.Â  When he placed the rag on her, she felt a watery sensation.Â  She then opened her eyes, got up, and put on her clothes.Â  Snipes told Victim not to tell anyone what happened or she would get in trouble and be spanked.Â  When Mother came home, she asked Victim what was wrong, and Victim told her what had happened.Â  The State presented testimony from two police officers, a victimsâ€™ assistance coordinator, a childrenâ€™s advocacy coordinator, and from Mother confirming that Victim reported she had been sexually assaulted on the day in question at her home.Â  
Although a stain was found on the red t-shirt belonging to Victim, no semen was detected on that, nor on the other t-shirt or the washcloth seized from the home.Â  Neither was semen found on Victim.Â  
Snipes took the stand in his defense.Â  He testified that on March 18, 2000, Mother left the house to take their son to get a haircut.Â  After the other children finished folding clothes, he instructed them to clean their rooms.Â  Snipes began watching a sexually explicit tape.Â  He did not believe the children would see the tape because they were not allowed out of their rooms until the rooms were clean.Â  Victim walked in while a scene was playing which showed a woman performing oral sex on a man in a car.Â  Victim stated, â€œOh Daddy, thatâ€™s nasty.â€Â  This startled Snipes, and he responded by screaming at her and telling her if she ever stole money from her mother again, â€œIâ€™ll do you like that.â€Â  Snipes denied he had ever â€œdone anything of a sexual natureâ€ to Victim.Â  
At the close of the Stateâ€™s evidence, Snipes moved for a directed verdict arguing the State failed to present evidence of the crime of criminal sexual conduct.Â  The trial court denied the motion, finding there was evidence presented from which the jury could find Snipes guilty.Â  At the close of all evidence, Snipes renewed his motion for directed verdict asserting the State failed to present sufficient evidence of his guilt.Â  The court again denied the motion.Â  Thereafter, the jury found Snipes guilty of criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree, and Snipes was sentenced to ten years in prison.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Right to a Speedy Trial 
Snipes contends the trial court erred in failing to dismiss the case on the ground that his right to a speedy trial was violated.Â  We disagree.
The Sixth Amendment of the United States Constitution, as applied to the states through the Fourteenth Amendment, and Article 1, Section 14 of the South Carolina Constitution guarantee an accused the right to a speedy trial.Â  State v. Kennedy, 339 S.C. 243, 249, 528 S.E.2d 700, 703 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d 348 S.C. 32, 558 S.E.2d 527 (2002);Â  State v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 74, 480 S.E.2d 64, 70 (1997);Â  State v. Chapman, 289 S.C. 42, 44, 344 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1986).Â  The determination of whether or not an accused has been denied his constitutional right to a speedy trial depends on the circumstances of each case. Â Brazell, 325 S.C. at 75, 480 S.E.2d at 70;Â  State v. Monroe, 262 S.C. 346, 349, 204 S.E.2d 433, 435 (1974).Â  In Barker v. Wingo, 407 U.S. 514 (1972), the United States Supreme Court identified four factors to be used in determining whether a defendant has been denied the right to a speedy trial:Â  1) the length of the delay;Â  2) the reason the State asserts to justify the delay;Â  3) when and how the defendant asserted his right to a speedy trial;Â  and 4) the prejudice to the defendant. Â Id. at 530;Â  see also Brazell, 325 S.C. at 75, 480 S.E.2d at 70.Â Â  The Supreme Court noted the courts must engage in a balancing test with these â€œrelated factors,â€ which â€œmust be considered together with such other circumstances as may be relevant.â€Â  Barker, 407 U.S. at 533. Â South Carolina has recognized these factors and adopted this balancing approach to the speedy trial analysis. Â Brazell, 325 S.C. at 75, 480 S.E.2d at 70; Â Chapman, 289 S.C. at 44, 344 S.E.2d at 612.
The first factor, length of delay, acts as a threshold requirement.Â  Barker, 407 U.S. at 530.Â  Â Until there is some delay which is presumptively prejudicial, it is not necessary to inquire into the other factors.Â  Id.Â  In determining when a defendantâ€™s right to a speedy trial begins to run, we must consider the purpose of the speedy trial guarantee.Â  Chapman, 289 S.C. at 44, 344 S.E.2d at 612.Â  

  The Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial is thus not primarily intended to prevent prejudice to the defense caused by passage of time;Â  that interest is protected primarily by the due process clause and by statutes of limitations.Â  The speedy trial guarantee is designed to minimize the possibility of lengthy incarceration prior to trial, to reduce the lesser, but never the less substantial, impairment of liberty imposed on an accused while released on bail, and to shorten the disruption of life caused by arrest and the presence of unresolved criminal charges.Â  
  Once charges are dismissed, the speedy trial guarantee is no longer applicable.Â  At that point, the formerly accused is, at most, in the same position as any other subject of a criminal investigation.

Id. at 44-45, 344 S.E.2d at 612-13 (quoting United States v. McDonald, 456 U.S. 1, 8-9 (1982)).Â  Thus, the time during which an indictment is dismissed and a defendant is free of all restrictions on his liberty should be excluded from the length of delay.Â  Id. at 45, 344 S.E.2d at 613.Â Â Â Â Â  
In the case at hand, it appears Snipes was not incarcerated on this charge but for a few days. However, his liberty was clearly impaired and his life disrupted during the considerable period of time he was out on bond.Â  Snipes was arrested mid-March of 2000. While the charges were dismissed two months later, he was then indicted on June 15, 2000, only one month later, and the charge remained hanging over his head until the time of trial in early August 2004.Â  Accordingly, the length of delay in this matter is four years and three and a half months. Â Although delay alone is not dispositive in the speedy trial analysis, this substantial delay by the State in prosecuting the case is sufficient to trigger review of the remaining factors. Â See State v. Robinson, 335 S.C. 620, 625, 518 S.E.2d 269, 272 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding five-year delay between arrest and trial of defendant for computer crime was sufficient to trigger review of remaining factors to be considered in determining whether defendant was denied his right to speedy trial);Â  Brazell, 325 S.C. at 75, 480 S.E.2d at 70 (finding a three-year and five-month delay was sufficient to trigger review); Â State v. Waites, 270 S.C. 104, 108, 240 S.E.2d 651, 653 (1978) (finding a two-year and four-month delay in prosecution was sufficient to trigger speedy trial analysis).
As for the second factor of the Barker test, reason for delay, the State admitted that there were many reasons for the delay that were not going to be acceptable to the court.Â  The solicitor stated:Â  

  . . . One is we have cases that are older than this that we havenâ€™t gotten to yet.Â  We donâ€™t have enough court time to move cases in a timely fashion and thatâ€™s not a good excuse.Â  Another is that we discovered that we had in fact seized some physical items.Â  In my preparation of this case months and months â€“ actually a couple of years ago I determined that we had basically sat on those items at the sheriffâ€™s office, nothing had been done with them.Â  In fairness to everybody we felt like we needed to send them to SLED to see what they could do with it.Â  We did that - - a sample was listed by SLEDâ€™s DNA processing department from one article of clothing.Â  We now had something maybe to be compared with the blood samples from the victim and the defendant.Â  I then tried to get [the defense attorney] to see if his client would consent to the submission of his blood sample, he wouldnâ€™t.Â  We had to go through the process of a motion and doctors appointments to get all of that done.Â  So all of it is not our fault.Â  We finally got the blood sample, we sent it to SLED, the reports came back and then I scheduled it for trial.Â  

Thus, it appears the delay was due in part to an overcrowded docket and the Stateâ€™s failure to promptly have some of the evidence tested.Â  However, the record shows the solicitor took steps to have the items tested once he became aware of their existence.Â  Further, it should be noted that Snipes also contributed to the delay. Â In June 2002, after discovering further testing was needed on the red t-shirt seized by the officers, the solicitor filed a motion requesting Snipes submit to a blood test in order to speed up the process of testing.Â  Snipes opposed the motion, necessitating a hearing on July 30, 2002.Â  While Snipes was well within his rights to challenge his submission to a blood test, he cannot now claim this additional delay was attributable to the State.Â Â Â  Finally, there is simply no evidence the State purposely delayed Snipesâ€™ trial.Â  See Kennedy, 339 S.C. at 250, 528 S.E.2d at 704 (noting absence of evidence of purposeful delay by State in considering reason for delay factor in speedy trial analysis);Â  Barker, 407 U.S. at 531 (finding deliberate attempt to delay a trial in order to hamper the defense should be weighted heavily against the government while a more neutral reason such as negligence or overcrowded docket should be weighted less heavily). 
Next, we must consider when and how Snipes asserted his right to a speedy trial.Â  The record shows Snipes did not make a motion concerning the delay until the day of trial.Â  While Snipes contends he complained of the delay during the July 30, 2002 hearing, a thorough reading of the record shows Snipes never placed any objection on the record in regard to the delay prior to the day of trial.Â  Rather, as previously noted, the transcript from that hearing shows the solicitor was very concerned with the delay in bringing the matter to trial and that this prompted his motion for Snipes to submit to the blood test.Â  Snipes objected at the hearing only to the intrusion of a blood test based on the solicitorâ€™s admission the seized items had been â€œcoming back [with] negative [results].â€Â  Snipes maintained that, â€œsince itâ€™s been that long,â€ to send a blood sample in with the other items â€œcreates a possibility of suspicion as to how the analysis was conducted.â€Â  Further, Snipes conceded during his motion to dismiss based on his speedy trial violation that he had not brought the matter to the courtâ€™s attention and had not made a motion for speedy trial or to dismiss until the day of trial.Â  Accordingly, Snipes failed to assert this right until the trial was ready to start.Â  See also Robinson, 335 S.C. at 626, 518 S.E.2d at 272 (finding appellantâ€™s letters written to solicitor and Chief Administrative Judge indicating he was ready for trial were insufficient to trigger assertion of appellantâ€™s right to a speedy trial and such right was not asserted until he filed his formal motion to dismiss).Â  
While the United States Supreme Court rejected the demand-waiver rule[3] as applied to the right to a speedy trial in Barker, the manner in which the defendant asserts his right thereto is nonetheless an important factor to be considered.Â  Waites, 270 S.C. at 108, 240 S.E.2d at 653.Â  In Barker, the court considered the fact that Barker did not want a speedy trial to be â€˜[m]ore important than the absence of serious prejudice.â€Â  Barker, 407 U.S. at 534. The court noted, the more serious the deprivation, the more likely the defendant is to complain, and a defendantâ€™s assertion of his speedy trial right is entitled to strong evidentiary weight in determining whether he has been deprived of the right.Â  Id. at 531-32.Â  The court added, â€œ[w]e emphasize that failure to assert the right will make it difficult for a defendant to prove that he was denied a speedy trial.â€Â  Id. at 532. Â Accordingly, Snipesâ€™ failure to assert his right to a speedy trial until the day the trial began militates strongly against him in his argument that he was denied his right to a speedy trial.Â  
Lastly, we must examine whether Snipes suffered prejudice as a result of the delay.Â  In considering this factor, the Barker court noted it should be assessed in light of the interests of defendants the speedy trial right was designed to protect.Â  Barker, 407 U.S. at 532.Â  These interests include: (i) to prevent oppressive pretrial incarceration; (ii) to minimize anxiety and concern of the accused; and (iii) to limit the possibility that the defense will be impaired.Â  Id. Â Of these, the most serious is the impairment of the defense, because the inability of a defendant to adequately prepare his case skews the fairness of the entire system. Â Id.;Â  see also Kennedy, 339 S.C. at 250, 528 S.E.2d at 704 (quoting Barker).Â  Â 
On appeal, Snipes asserts he was prejudiced by the delay because the evidence showed Victimâ€™s memory was faulty, the only evidence against him was that of Victimâ€™s testimony, and her credibility was bolstered by the five witnesses who corroborated her allegation of sexual abuse.[4]Â  The court in Barker noted there is prejudice if defense witnesses are unable to recall accurately events of the distant past.Â  Barker, 407 U.S. at 532. Â However, Snipes does not contend he or any of his other witnesses were unable to recall the events surrounding this case. Â Rather, he claims prejudice in Victimâ€™s inability to remember the events.Â  Further, the Barker court also noted that deprivation of the right to a speedy trial may sometimes work to an accusedâ€™s advantage.Â  Id. at 521.Â  Specifically, the court discussed how, as the delay between commission of a crime and the trial increases, witnesses may become unavailable and memories may fade.Â  However, where the witnesses support the prosecution, it is the prosecutionâ€™s case that will be weakened, sometimes seriously so, as it is the prosecution that carries the burden of proof.Â  Id.Â  This is precisely what occurred in the case at hand.Â  The fact that Victim had some difficulty remembering what happened on the day in question was well explored by defense counsel, and used to Snipesâ€™ advantage in attacking Victimâ€™s credibility.Â  Thus, considering the fact that Snipes was able to attack Victimâ€™s credibility, showing little, if any, impairment to his defense, along with the fact that Snipes was incarcerated very briefly prior to his trial, we conclude there was minimal prejudice to Snipes.Â  
Although the delay of over four years is substantial, upon our review and balancing of the Barker factors, we find Snipes was not denied his constitutional right to a speedy trial and the trial court properly denied Snipesâ€™ motion to dismiss. 
II.Â  Directed Verdict
Snipes argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  He argues Victimâ€™s testimony was based on her review of papers and talking to others rather than her personal knowledge, and therefore there was no competent evidence reasonably tending to prove his guilt.Â  We disagree.
When a motion for a directed verdict is made in a criminal case, the trial court is concerned with the existence or non-existence of evidence, not with the weight of the evidence.Â  State v. Brown, 360 S.C. 581, 586, 602 S.E.2d 392, 395 (2004).Â  The accused is entitled to a directed verdict when the evidence merely raises a suspicion of guilt or when the State fails to present evidence on a material element of the offense charged.Â  Id.Â  However, if there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, an appellate court must find that the trial court properly submitted the case to the jury.Â  State v. McGowan, 347 S.C. 618, 622, 557 S.E.2d 657, 659 (2001).Â  In reviewing the denial of a motion for a directed verdict, the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Fennell, 340 S.C. 266, 270, 531 S.E.2d 512, 514 (2000).Â Â  
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, we find there was sufficient evidence presented that reasonably tended to prove Snipesâ€™ guilt.Â  Victim testified in detail about Snipesâ€™ sexual assault on her on the day in question.Â  While Victim did state she had difficulty remembering some things that occurred and she had to refresh her memory through papers and talking with other people before these matters would â€œcome back to [her],â€ she maintained that what she had testified to at trial was what had in fact happened.Â  Additionally, her testimony was corroborated by the testimony of the two investigating officers, a victimsâ€™ assistance coordinator, and a childrenâ€™s advocacy coordinator, as well as her mother, who all testified that Victim complained that she was sexually assaulted in her home on the date alleged.Â  Finally, the fact that Snipes asserts Victimâ€™s testimony should not be believed is not a basis for a directed verdict.Â  Instead, Snipesâ€™ argument is one of credibility, which is to be resolved by the jury.Â  See State v. Ham, 268 S.C. 340, 341, 233 S.E.2d 698, 698 (1977) (â€œWhere the determination of guilt is dependant upon the credibility of the witnesses, a motion for a directed verdict is properly refused.â€)Â Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly denied Snipesâ€™ motion for a directed verdict.Â  
For the foregoing reasons Snipesâ€™ conviction is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
ANDERSON, HUFF, JJ. and CURETON, A.J., concur

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] On appeal, Snipes only argues the reliability of Victimâ€™s testimony was diminished by the delay.Â  He does not assert any prejudice based on Dr. Fouttyâ€™s inaccessibility.Â  
[3] The demand-waiver doctrine, as discussed by the court in Barker, provides that a defendant would waive any consideration of his right to a speedy trial for any period prior to his demand of a trial, thus requiring prior demand as a necessary condition to consideration of the speedy trial right.Â  Barker, 407 U.S. at 525.Â Â  
[4] It should be noted that Snipes did not object to the corroboration evidence offered by the State at trial.Â  Additionally, the testimony was limited to time and place of the assault, excluding any detail of the incident.Â  See Simpkins v. State, 303 S.C. 364, 367, 401 S.E.2d 142, 143 (1991) (holding, when criminal sexual conduct victim testifies, corroborative evidence from other witnesses that victim complained of sexual assault is admissible, limited to time and place of the assault and excluding details or particulars).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Leroy A. Matthews, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-364
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 24, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh , Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Christina Theos Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Leroy Matthews claims the trial court erred in finding the State did not commit a Rule 5 discovery violation, finding no Miranda violation, finding the search of the house was voluntary, admitting the actual drug laboratory report, and admitting evidence of Matthewsâ€™s exercise of his right to remain silent.Â  We affirm[1].
FACTS
On the morning of January 18, 2005, Deputy Andrew Hyslop witnessed Matthews backing down a street at a high rate of speed.Â  Deputy Hyslop believed Matthews was backing in a dangerous manner and decided to pull him over to give him a verbal warning.Â  In the meantime, Matthews parked his car in a private parking lot.Â  Matthews exited his vehicle as Deputy Hyslop was parking next to him.
Deputy Hyslop asked Matthews for his driverâ€™s license.Â  Matthews responded by running into a nearby home and locked the door.Â  Shortly thereafter, Matthews came out through the front door.Â  Deputy Hyslop approached Matthews and asked to see his driving license.Â  Matthews became loud and boisterous with Deputy Hyslop and used profanities while speaking with him.Â  The commotion attracted a small crowd of bystanders, and at least one bystander joined Matthews in yelling obscenities at Deputy Hyslop.Â  In response to the situation, Deputy Hyslop arrested Matthews for public disorderly conduct.Â  Matthews flailed his arms and attempted to get away while Deputy Hyslop was trying to handcuff him.Â  Deputy Hyslop, with the help of a second deputy, was able to handcuff Matthews.Â  Deputy Hyslop seized $890.00 in cash and a set of keys from Matthews.
Deputy Hyslop placed Matthews in his patrol car and informed him of his Miranda rights.Â  Matthews told Deputy Hyslop to get out of his face.Â  Deputy Hyslop closed the door and walked away from the patrol car.Â  A few moments later, Deputy Hyslop went back to the car and asked Matthews if he had placed anything in the house.Â  However, Matthews did not want to talk with Deputy Hyslop. Â Deputy Hyslop closed the door and again walked away from the patrol car.Â  Shortly thereafter, Sergeant Hamby arrived on the scene.Â  
When Matthews saw Sergeant Hamby, he called him over to the patrol car. Â Matthews complained to Sergeant Hamby about being harassed by the officers on the scene. Â Sergeant Hamby asked Matthews if he had left anything in the house when he was inside.Â  Matthews said he had and offered to take Sergeant Hamby in the house and show it to him.Â  Matthews took Sergeant Hamby into the house and pointed out a hole in one of the walls which contained a plastic bag with a rock substance in it.Â  The substance was later tested and found to be crack cocaine.Â  Pursuant to an inventory search, $2,000.00 cash and an electric scale with crack cocaine residue was seized from Matthewsâ€™ car.
On April 19, 2005, Matthews was indicted for resisting arrest, public disorderly conduct, trafficking cocaine, trafficking cocaine within one-half mile of a school, and improper backing.Â  The trial court dismissed the trafficking cocaine within one-half mile of a school charge.Â  On April 18, 2005, a jury found Matthews guilty of all the remaining charged crimes.Â  Matthews was sentenced to twenty-five years for trafficking with the sentences for the other crimes running concurrent to the sentence for trafficking.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The conduct of a criminal trial and the inclusion or exclusion of evidence are matters left largely to the sound discretion of the trial court. State v. Lee, 255 S.C. 309, 178 S.E.2d 652 (1971); State v. Edens, 272 S.C. 130, 250 S.E.2d 116 (1978). The decisions of the trial judge will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion. State v. Quillien, 263 S.C. 87, 207 S.E.2d 814 (1974).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rule 5 Discovery Violation
Matthews claims the trial court should have suppressed his statements due to a violation of a discovery request made pursuant to Rule 5, SCRCrimP.Â  We disagree.
Rule 5(a)(1)(A), SCRCrimP, provides in pertinent parts upon â€œrequest by a defendant, the prosecution shall permit the defendant to inspect and copy or photographâ€¦ any oral statement which the prosecution intends to offer in evidence at trial made by the defendantâ€¦ in response to interrogationâ€¦â€ .
Deputy Hyslop informed Matthewsâ€™ of his rights pursuant to Miranda. Deputy Hyslop then asked Matthews if he understood those rights and with those rights in mind if he would like to speak with him.Â  In reply, Matthews told Deputy Hyslop to get out of his face.Â  Matthewsâ€™ attorney claimed the State should have disclosed Matthewsâ€™ statement.
Matthewsâ€™s statement was made in response to Deputy Hyslopâ€™s question about his Miranda rights.Â  The statement was not made in response to interrogation and it was not responsive to the question.Â  Deputy Hyslop was simply trying to comply with the requirements of Miranda.Â  The question did not rise to the level of interrogation; therefore, Matthewsâ€™ statement was not subject to discovery.
Matthews claims the Stateâ€™s failure to disclose his statement, the fact that he was Mirandized, and the card Deputy Hyslop read the Miranda rights from were detrimental to his defense.Â  The original defense strategy was to move to have all of the evidence excluded. Â Â Matthews claims his attorney had insufficient time to revamp his defense after the State presented evidence at the motion hearing showing he was Mirandized. Â However, his attorney did not request a continuance when the State presented the evidence showing he had been Mirandized. Â Therefore, Matthews can not show that he was prejudiced by the alleged Rule 5 violation.
Miranda Violation
Matthews claims the trial court should have suppressed his statements due to a Miranda violation.Â  We disagree.
Deputy Hyslop informed Matthews of his rights pursuant to Miranda.Â  He then asked Matthews if he understood those rights and with those rights in mind if he would like to speak with him.Â  In reply Matthews told him to get out of his face, at which point Deputy Hyslop closed the door to his patrol car and walked away.
A moment later he returned to the car and asked Matthews if he had left anything in the house when he went inside.Â  Deputy Hyslop testified that Matthews did not want to talk and continued to curse.Â  Deputy Hyslop closed the door and walked away.Â  When Sergeant Hamby arrived on the scene, Matthews called him over to the car.Â  Matthews complained to Sergeant Hamby about being harassed by the officers at the scene.Â  Sergeant Hamby asked him if had left anything in the house, and he admitted he had and offered to take Sergeant Hamby inside and show it to him.Â  When the two men went into the house, Matthews pointed out where he had left the crack.
A statement obtained as a result of custodial interrogation is inadmissible unless the suspect was advised of and voluntarily waived his rights under Miranda v. Arizona 384 U.S. 436 (1966). Â The voluntariness of a statement is determined from the totality of the circumstances. Schneckloth v. Bustamonte, 412 U.S. 218 (1973). Furthermore, the conclusion of the trial judge on issues of fact as to the voluntariness of a statement will not be disturbed on appeal unless so manifestly erroneous as to show an abuse of discretion. State v. Kennedy, 333 S.C. 426, 429, 510 S.E.2d 714, 715 (1998).
  When a suspect invokes his right to remain silent, law enforcement officers must scrupulously honor it. Michigan v. Mosley, 423 U.S. 96 (1975). However, before law enforcement officers are required to discontinue questioning, the suspect must clearly articulate his desire to end the interrogation. Davis v. United States, 512 U.S. 452 (1994); State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 42, 503 S.E.2d 747, 750 (1998).
Considering the totality of the circumstances, Matthews statement to Deputy Hyslop falls short of a clear invocation of his right to remain silent.Â  Matthews had been hostile with Deputy Hyslop since their interaction began, and stating â€œget out of my faceâ€ could have simply been a vocalization of his continuing hostility towards the Deputy.Â  This is strengthened by the fact that as soon as Sergeant Hamby arrived on the scene, Matthews initiated a conversation with him about the way he had been treated.Â  Even if Matthews statement was held to be an invocation of his right to remain silent, he chose to reinitiate the conversation by calling Sergeant Hamby over to the car and talking to him.Â  The admissibility of statements obtained after the person in custody has decided to remain silent depends under Miranda on whether his â€œright to cut off questioningâ€ was â€œscrupulously honored.â€Â  Michigan v. Mosley  423 U.S. 96,104 (1975).Â  Officers do not fail to â€œscrupulously honorâ€ an invocation of rights when they engage in conversation initiated by the suspect.Â  See State v. Aleksey  343 S.C. 20, 31, 538 S.E.2d 248, 254 (2000).
Search of the House
Matthews claims the trial court should have suppressed evidence found in the search of the house due to his consent not being voluntary.Â  Because we find Matthews failed to preserve this issue for appellate review, we do not reach the merits of this claim.Â  A ruling on a motion in limine is not sufficient to preserve a challenge on the validity of a search where trial council does not renew the objection when the drugs are introduced.Â  See State v. King 349 S.C. 142, 149, 561 S.E.2d 640, 643 (Ct. App. 2002).
Matthewsâ€™s attorney did not object when the state introduced the drugs that were found in the search.Â  During the motion hearing, the trial court instructed Matthewsâ€™s attorney to object when evidence was initially offered to preserve the record for review.Â  When the State offered the drugs for admission Matthewsâ€™ attorney failed to object.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.
The Laboratory Report
Mathews claims the laboratory report should have been excluded as hearsay.Â  We find the evidence admitted through the alleged error to be cumulative and therefore not prejudicial.Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (improper admission of hearsay evidence is reversible error only when the admission causes prejudice). Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to unsubstantial errors not affecting the result. State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 176, 399 S.E.2d 595, 597 (1991).Â  State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 577 S.E.2d 445 (2003) (admission of improper evidence is harmless where the evidence is merely cumulative to other evidence.)
Matthewsâ€™ attorney stipulated to the chain of custody for Stateâ€™s exhibit 12.Â  Matthewsâ€™ attorney also stipulated to Mr. Miller being qualified as a forensic drug analyst.Â  Mr. Miller testified, without objection, that his lab had determined Stateâ€™s exhibit 12 to be 23.38 grams of crack cocaine.Â  The lab report at issue was simply a written report stating what was already in the record: Stateâ€™s exhibit 12 was 23.38 grams of crack cocaine.Â  State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993) (any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless).
Right to Remain Silent
Matthews claims the trial court erred in admitting evidence showing he exercised his right to remain silent.Â  Because we find Matthews failed to preserve this issue for appellate review, we do not reach the merits of this claim.Â  An issue which is not properly preserved cannot be raised for the first time on appeal. Â State v. Vanderbilt, 287 S.C. 597, 340 S.E.2d 543 (1986). A contemporaneous objection is required to properly preserve an error for appellate review. Â State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).
Matthewsâ€™ attorney failed to object to either Deputy Hyslopâ€™s testimony or the Stateâ€™s comments during closing arguments.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.
For the reasons stated above, the trial courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Bertha J. Wilson, Personal Representative of the Estate of Albert Judge, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Primerica Life Insurance Company and Stephanie M. Graham, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-365
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 24, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Dennis Robert Toney, Jr., of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Robert H. Hood, Molly H. Craig, D. and Nathan Hughey, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This appeal is from the dismissal of the underlying complaint.Â  We affirm. [1]
Albert Judge died on July 19, 2000.Â  Desiree Pryor, the named beneficiary under a policy with Primerica Life Insurance, applied for the death benefit proceeds.Â  Primerica denied Pryorâ€™s claim and commenced an action in the Court of Common Pleas in Berkeley County to rescind the policy. Pryor counterclaimed on various tort and contract grounds. Â The trial court granted summary judgment to Pryor on one ground but otherwise granted summary judgment to Primerica Life.
While the summary judgment motions were pending in Pryorâ€™s action in Berkeley County, Beth Wilson, the personal representative of Albert Judgeâ€™s estate (and also Judgeâ€™s sister, the mother of Desiree Pryor, and the contingent beneficiary on the policy), brought this action in Charleston County.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to Primerica on all causes, and Wilson appeals.Â  
We affirm based on the doctrine of res judicata.Â  To establish res judicata, the following elements must be established: (1) identity of the parties; (2) identity of the subject matter; and (3) adjudication of the claim in the former suit.Â  Plum Creek Dev. Co., Inc. v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 34, 512 S.E.2d 106, 109 (1999). Here, the subject matter is absolutely identical and all relevant issues were adjudicated in the prior suit.Â  As the trial court correctly stated, â€œ[b]oth cases concern the same policy of insurance [and] nearly identical causes of action.â€Â  While Wilson contends the parties are not identical, as neither she nor Stephanie Graham were parties in the Berkeley County action, this argument fails because, under South Carolina law, the doctrine of res judicata extends to include privy parties.Â  Nunnery v. Brantley Constr. Co., Inc., 289 S.C. 205, 209, 345 S.E.2d 740, 743 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  In the context of res judicata, the term privity does not refer to â€œrelationships between persons or entities, but rather it deals with a personâ€™s relationship to the subject matter of the litigation.â€Â  Richburg v. Baughman, 290 S.C. 431, 434, 351 S.E.2d 164, 166 (1986).Â  â€œThe term can also refer to a person so identified in interest with another that he represents the same legal rights.â€Â  Wyndham v. Lewis, 292 S.C. 6, 8, 354 S.E.2d 578, 579 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  This action was properly dismissed pursuant to the doctrine of res judicata.
In view of our disposition of this issue, we need not address the remaining issues. Rule 220(c), SCACR; See also Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993).Â  Therefore, the judgment of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Donald E. Miles, Appellant
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Merit Distribution Services, Inc, Employer, and American Home Assurance/AIG, Carrier, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Chesterfield County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-366
Heard October 10, 2006 â€“ Filed October 24, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Holly Saleeby Atkins, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Jason W. Lockhart, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, Donald E. Miles appeals a circuit court order affirming the decision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Appellate Panel) finding his neck and back injuries did not arise during the course of Â his employment.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Donald Miles is a 57-year-old man who resides in McBee, South Carolina.Â  Miles worked as a professional truck driver for eighteen years, the last four of which he drove for Merit Distribution Services, Inc. (Merit).Â  On March 26, 2000, Miles finished making a delivery in Barnwell, South Carolina and was driving to Georgia to make a second delivery when he drove his tractor-trailer over railroad tracks.Â  As Milesâ€™ tractor-trailer crossed over the tracks, a train struck the trailer.Â  The back end of the trailer tore off and the mechanism for the driverâ€™s seat broke.Â  While Miles was jostled around the cab by the collision he did not believe he was seriously injured and did not seek any medical treatment at the scene of the accident.Â  
The next day, Miles spoke with Meritâ€™s Safety Manager, Frank Richardson.Â  Miles claims that when he informed Richardson he was experiencing neck and back pain Richardson told him that if he filed a claim for workersâ€™ compensation he would lose his $1,200 safety bonus.Â  Miles did not believe his injuries to be severe and decided against telling anyone he was injured in the accident.Â  Â Â 
On May 1, 2000, Miles went to see his general physician, Dr. Thomas Bell, because he had pain in his neck and shoulders, and his neck was â€œpopping.â€Â  Dr. Bell had seen Miles on March 14, twelve days before the accident, for neck pain and numbness in his fingers.Â  During the May 1 visit, Dr. Bell noticed Milesâ€™ symptoms had become acute and ordered an MRI.Â  The MRI revealed a herniated disk.Â  At this point, Miles did not disclose to Dr. Bell that he had been involved in an accident.Â  Further, Miles sought medical treatment under his health insurance rather than filing a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  
As Milesâ€™ neck and back pain progressed, Dr. Bell referred him to Dr. Willie Edwards.Â  On May 25, 2000, Dr. Edwards examined Miles and noted in his report that Miles â€œdates the onset and duration of symptoms over the past six months.Â  He denies any history of injury or antecedent event and reports no precipitating factors or other known triggers.â€Â  Dr. Edwards recommended fusion surgery.Â  After the surgery, Miles still continued to experience stiffness and pain in his neck and finally divulged to Dr. Bell and Dr. Edwards that he had been involved in an accident.Â  
On July 24, 2000, Miles filed for short-term disability benefits.Â  The application requested that Miles respond to the following question:Â  â€œIf due to an accident, give date of accident.â€Â  Miles left the space blank.Â  On January 5, 2001, Miles filed for long-term disability benefits.Â  The application asked â€œ[w]here and how did the injury occur.â€Â  Milesâ€™ written response stated â€œ[u]known as to my knowledge.â€Â  Further, the application asked â€œis your condition related to your occupation?â€Â  Miles checked the â€œNoâ€ box on the application.Â  
On July 2, 2003, Miles filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim against Merit asserting he suffered a compensable injury during his employment on March 26, 2000.Â  At the hearing on June 25, 2004, Miles sought temporary-total disability benefits alleging the accident caused his injuries.Â  Although Merit admitted that an accident occurred on March 26, 2000, Merit denied Miles suffered any injury in the accident.Â  Merit took the position that any neck and back pain Miles experienced was unrelated to the accident.Â  Â Â 
The Single Commissioner found that Miles testified that he did not initially pursue a workersâ€™ compensation claim because he feared for his job and did not want to lose his safety bonus.Â  Further, the Single Commissioner found Miles specifically denied, both to his doctors and in his applications for disability benefits, that his injury was caused by any antecedent event.Â  The Single Commissioner concluded that Milesâ€™ repeated denial of a work-related neck and back injury prevented a finding that Miles sustained a compensable injury on March 26, 2000.Â  The Single Commissioner found Miles did not carry the burden of proof required to establish his injury arose out of and occurred during the course of his employment.Â  Accordingly, the Single Commissioner denied Milesâ€™ claim for temporary-total disability benefits.Â Â  
The Full Commission affirmed the Single Commissioner, adopting the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings in full.Â  Following a hearing on the matter, the circuit court found the decision of the Appellate Panel was supported by substantial evidence in the record and affirmed that decision.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard of review for decisions by the Appellate Panel.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  This court may reverse or modify a decision of the Appellate Panel if the findings or conclusions are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) (2005).Â  Under the scope of review established by the APA, this court cannot substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000). 
The substantial evidence rule of the APA governs the standard of review in a workersâ€™ compensation decision. Lark, 276 S.C. at 134, 276 S.E.2d at 306.Â  A finding is supported by substantial evidence â€œunless there is no reasonable probability that the facts could be as related by a witness upon whose testimony the finding was based.â€Â  Id. at 136, 276 S.E.2d at 307.Â Â  Substantial evidence is that which, in viewing the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion as the Appellate Panel.Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 183, 528 S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App. 2000) (citation omitted).
In workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact-finder and is not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442. Â The final determination of witness credibility and weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Appellate Panel.Â  Id.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc.,Â  336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999).Â Â Â Â  
Generally, whether an injury arose out of and was in the scope of employment is a question of fact.Â  Id. at 159, 519 S.E.2d at 105 (citation omitted).Â  Because causation is a question of fact, the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision on the issue will be affirmed if supported by substantial evidence in the record. Id. at 160, 519 S.E.2d at 105.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

On appeal, Miles asserts the circuit court erred in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision because it was unsupported by substantial evidence and affected by legal error. He contends the Appellate Panel erroneously denied his claim for benefits due to his initial dishonesty in denying he was injured in the accident.Â  We disagree.
It is undisputed that Miles had an accident in the course of his employment.Â  Therefore, the issue in this case involves a determination of whether Milesâ€™ subsequent neck and back pain, for which he sought treatment under his health insurance, arose out of his employment.Â  For the reasons set forth below we find substantial evidence supports the finding that Milesâ€™ neck and back pain were not caused by the work-related accident and, therefore, did not arise out of and in the course of his employment.Â Â Â  
In order for an injury to be compensable under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, the injury must â€œarise out of and in the course of the employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (1976).Â  â€œThe phrase â€˜arise out ofâ€™ refers to the injuryâ€™s origin and cause.â€Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 186, 528 S.E.2d 435, 442 (Ct. App. 2000).Â Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court explained that an injury â€œarises out ofâ€ employment â€œwhen there is apparent to the rational mind upon consideration of all the circumstances, a causal connection between the conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting injury.â€Â  Id. at 187, 528 S.E.2d at 442.Â  Further, the burden of proof is on the claimant â€œto prove such facts as will render the injury compensable within the provisions of the State Workmenâ€™s Compensation Law.â€Â  Smith v. Union Bleachery/Cone Mills,  276 S.C. 454, 456, 280 S.E.2d 52, 53 (1981)Â  (citing Ellis v. Spartan Mills, et al., 277 S.E.2d 304 (1981)).
In reviewing the medical records in this case, noticeably absent is any mention of Milesâ€™ neck and back problems being caused by his work-related accident.Â  To the contrary, the records show that Miles denied that his injuries stemmed from any prior event.Â  Moreover, the medical records show that Miles sought treatment for his neck injury as far back as September of 1999.Â  Additionally, when Miles sought disability benefits, he again denied his condition was caused by any specific event or that his injuries were related to his employment.Â  
Furthermore, the Appellate Panel considered the evidence Miles submitted in favor of his position, including his testimony and the testimony of Dr. Bell, who despite not noting the accident in any of Milesâ€™ medical records testified that he thought Milesâ€™ neck and back problems were â€œmost probably relatedâ€ to the accident.Â  Therefore, Miles presented evidence before the Appellate Panel that he repeatedly denied he was injured in the work-related accident but now claims that he was untruthful and the accident caused his injuries.Â Â  
Â The Appellate Panel considered and weighed the evidence and found that Milesâ€™ injuries were not caused by the work-related accident.Â  In a workersâ€™ compensation case, â€œ[t]he final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the [Appellate Panel] and it is not the task of the court to weigh the evidence as found by the [Appellate Panel].â€ Rogers v. Kunja Knitting Mills, Inc,.  312 S.C. 377, 380-81, 440 S.E.2d 401, 403 (Ct. App. 1994) (citation omitted).Â  Therefore, we find substantial evidence exists upon which the Appellate Panel could conclude Milesâ€™ injuries were not caused by the March 26, 2000 accident.Â  See Jones. v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 418, 586 S.E.2d 111, 113-114 (2003) (â€œOur standard of review does not permit us to weigh the evidence and make our own determination. We are bound to uphold the [Appellate Panelâ€™s] decision unless its factual determination is not supported by substantial evidence.â€) (citations omitted).Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not err in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision that Milesâ€™ injuries did not arise out of and during the course of his employment.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Next, Miles argues the circuit court erred in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision because the Appellate Panel failed to recognize that his pre-existing injuries were aggravated by his work-related accident.Â  This issue, having not been raised before the Appellate Panel or the circuit court, is not preserved for review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 517, 466 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1996) (â€œArguments not raised to the workersâ€™ compensation commission or to the circuit court are not preserved for appealâ€).
CONCLUSION
Â We find substantial evidence supports the finding that Milesâ€™ injuries were not caused by his work-related motor vehicle accident, and, therefore, did not arise out of and in the course of his employment.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
ANDERSON, HUFF, and SHORT, JJ. concur.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Deborah Coon and Michael L. Coon, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Renaissance on Charleston Harbor, LLC, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-367
Heard October 11, 2006 â€“ Filed October 26, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Henry W. Brown and John W. Davidson, both of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
        Joseph Kevin Qualey and Michael S. Seekings, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Deborah and Michael L. Coon filed a motion to vacate an arbitration award.Â  The circuit court vacated the award and ordered the parties to submit to a new arbitration proceeding.Â  Renaissance on Charleston Harbor, LLC, appeals.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
The Coons entered into a contract to purchase two condominium units from Renaissance.[1]Â  The contract contained a â€œtime is of the essenceâ€ clause that provided:Â  â€œIt is expressly understood and agreed that TIME IS OF THE ESSENCE as to all obligations hereunder . . . .â€Â  The contract also included a cure provision as follows:

  If the Company defaults in the performance of any of the Companyâ€™s obligations as set forth in this Agreement and such default is not cured within 90 days after written notice of default is given by the Purchaser to the Company, the Purchaser will be entitled to rescind this Agreement and receive the immediate return of the Purchaserâ€™s earnest money deposit, as well as pursue any and all other remedies available at law or in equity; provided however, that in the event of the nonmaterial breach of any term or condition of this Agreement, the Purchaserâ€™s remedies will not include termination of this Agreement. Â 

The contract provided for binding arbitration of disputes arising under the agreement. Â 
The Coons signed the contract on May 22, 2000.Â  The contract provided for completion of the units within 24 months of the execution of the contract by the purchaser.Â  The Coons paid $109,000 in earnest money.Â  
Deborah Coon did a walk-through of the units in April of 2002 with an architect and the Renaissance realtor, Keith McCann.Â  During the walk-through, Coon complained about a â€œwavy wallâ€ and a â€œspongy floorâ€ in one of the units. Â Nevertheless, certificates of occupancy for both units were issued on April 24, 2002.Â  
Although it is unclear from the record the date the closing was originally scheduled to be held, it appears it was ultimately scheduled for June 25, 2002.Â  At the appointed time, the Coons again complained of the wall and floor in one of the units.Â  They refused to close, allegedly based on the advice of their banker and mortgage broker.Â  Coon admitted McCann kept in touch with her throughout the day about repairs and opined the problems could be fixed within twenty-four hours.Â  The following day, McCann informed Coon that if the Coons refused to close within twenty-four hours, Renaissance would consider it a breach of the contract.Â  The Coons refused to close, and Renaissance refused to return the earnest money.
The Coons filed an action for breach of contract, conversion, and unfair trade practices.Â  Pursuant to the terms of the contract, the action was heard by an arbitrator.Â  The arbitrator found the units were substantially complete, based in part on the issuance of the certificates of occupancy and â€œthe fact that the objections of the [Coons] were addressed within two days.â€Â  The arbitrator concluded the problems in the unit â€œwere nothing more than punch list items which [Renaissance] was entitled to take care of without the [Coons] walking out on the contract.â€Â  The arbitrator concluded that although the Coons would normally be entitled to rescind the contract under the â€œtime is of the essenceâ€ clause, the inclusion of a â€œcureâ€ provision entitled Renaissance to correct the units, and Renaissance â€œin fact promptly movedâ€ to do so.Â  The arbitrator accordingly denied the Coons relief and awarded attorneyâ€™s fees, costs, and arbitrator fees to Renaissance.Â  In a subsequent award, the arbitrator revised the attorneyâ€™s fee award in accordance with the applicable contract provision, awarding costs of $1,553.47, attorneyâ€™s fees of $31,818, and the arbitrator fee of $6,140.Â  In a third award, the arbitrator corrected the captions on the previous awards from â€œOrderâ€ to â€œAward.â€Â  
The Coons moved to vacate the arbitratorâ€™s award on three grounds:Â  1) the arbitrator erred by not finding the â€œtime is of the essence clauseâ€ dispositive; 2) the arbitratorâ€™s award was procured by undue means due to inappropriate comments in closing arguments before the arbitrator; and 3) the arbitrator erred by failing to limit fees and costs pursuant to the contract and under equitable principles because Renaissance was able to sell the units at a greater price than the price set in the contract.Â  
The circuit court found the arbitratorâ€™s failure to adhere strictly to the â€œtime is of the essenceâ€ clause constituted a manifest disregard of the law.Â  The court also concluded the arbitratorâ€™s award was procured by undue means based on Renaissanceâ€™s arguments â€œthat were designed to invoke passion and prejudice, and which were inflammatory in nature.â€Â  Finally, the court found the award of costs and fees was unjust based on the provision in the contract limiting fees to the arbitration proceeding.Â  The court found the arbitration proceeding lasted only two days, and fees should accordingly be limited to that time frame.Â  The court finally ordered the parties to submit to a new arbitration proceeding, and costs and fees at that proceeding were to be awarded pursuant to the courtâ€™s interpretation of the applicable provision in the contract.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  â€œArbitration is a favored method of settling disputes in South Carolina.â€ Â Pittman Mortgage Co. v. Edwards, 327 S.C. 72, 75, 488 S.E.2d 335, 337 (1997). Â â€œGenerally speaking, an arbitration award is conclusive and courts will refuse to review the merits of an award.â€ Â Batten v. Howell, 300 S.C. 545, 547, 389 S.E.2d 170, 171 (Ct. App. 1990). Â A court reviewing an arbitration award is therefore very limited in its scope of review.Â  Weimer v. Jones, 364 S.C. 78, 80, 610 S.E.2d 850, 852 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
â€œTime is of the Essenceâ€ Clause
Renaissance argues the circuit court erred in finding the arbitrator manifestly disregarded the law by considering the â€œcureâ€ provision and not strictly adhering to the â€œtime is of the essenceâ€ provision.Â  We find no manifest disregard of the law.Â  
The Uniform Arbitration Act provides statutory grounds for vacating, modifying, or correcting an arbitratorâ€™s award. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-130 (2005) (providing grounds for vacating arbitratorâ€™s award); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-140 (2005) (providing grounds for modification or correction of arbitratorâ€™s award). Â Absent one of these grounds, an arbitration award will be vacated only on the non-statutory ground of â€œmanifest disregard or perverse misconstruction of the law.â€ Â Batten, 300 S.C. at 548, 389 S.E.2d at 172.Â  
â€œ[M]anifest disregard of the law occurs when the arbitrator knew of a governing legal principle yet refused to apply it, and the law disregarded was well defined, explicit, and clearly applicable to the case.â€ Â Bazzle v. Green Tree Fin. Corp., 351 S.C. 244, 268, 569 S.E.2d 349, 361 (2002), vacated on other grounds, 539 U.S. 444 (2003).Â  To vacate an award for manifest disregard of the law requires more than a mere error in construing or applying the law.Â  Trident Technical Coll. v. Lucas & Stubbs, Ltd., 286 S.C. 98, 108, 333 S.E.2d 781, 787 (1985).Â  Even the â€œclearly erroneous interpretation of [a] contractâ€ cannot be disturbed.Â  Id.Â  It is â€œexceedingly rare, requiring circumstances far more egregious than mere errors in interpreting or applying the lawâ€ to vacate an arbitration award on the ground of manifest disregard of the law.Â  Id.Â  As long as there is at least an arguable ground for an award, an arbitrator has not manifestly disregarded the law.Â  Batten, 300 S.C. at 549, 389 S.E.2d at 172. 
In this case, the arbitrator recognized the â€œtime is of the essenceâ€ provision in the contract.Â  However, the arbitrator also applied the â€œcureâ€ provision in the contract, finding that although Renaissance failed to complete one of the two units within the time set by the contract, the â€œcureâ€ provision in the contract permitted Renaissance additional completion time.Â  There is at a minimum an arguable ground the arbitrator could interpret the contract in this manner.Â  See De Vore v. Piedmont Ins. Co., 144 S.C. 417, 430, 142 S.E. 593, 597 (1928) (Cothran, J., dissenting) (stating contradictory provisions in a contract must be harmonized); 17A Am.Jur.2d Contracts Â§ 485 (1991) (providing an express provision making time of the essence may be either expressly or impliedly waived). Â Accordingly, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s finding that the arbitrator manifestly disregarded the law in the interpretation of the contract.
Closing Argument
Renaissance also argues the circuit court erred in finding the arbitratorâ€™s award was procured by undue means due to Renaissance counselâ€™s comments during closing arguments before the arbitrator.Â  We agree.
During closing arguments, the following was stated before the arbitrator:Â  
Renaissance counsel:

  These are sophisticated business people.Â  I do not know why they would seek to attend a closing and find the fault which they found, which we believe is unjustified.Â  Under the contract itâ€™s unjustified.Â  We have two of their witness - - three of the witnesses, the three principal witnesses whose credibility I call into issue.
  And if the record that was made by them under oath today were brought to a grand jury and a solicitor - Â 

The Coonsâ€™ counsel:

  Wait a second.Â  This is inappropriate.

The Arbitrator:

  I think it goes beyond - I think your argument goes beyond - 

Renaissance counsel:

  At any rate, the credibility, I wanted to make a point - 

The Arbitrator:

  The credibility is definitely an arguable point.

Renaissance counsel continued the closing argument, commenting on the bankerâ€™s testimony regarding her advice to the Coons, which differed from the Coonsâ€™ testimony of the bankerâ€™s advice to them.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Based on Renaissance counselâ€™s comments, the circuit court found the arbitratorâ€™s award was â€œprocured through undue means and in violation of S.C. Code Ann. 15-48-130 (a)(1).â€Â  Section 15-48-130 provides the statutory grounds for vacating an arbitration award:Â  

  (a)Â Â Â Â  Upon application of a party, the court shall vacate an award where:
  (1)Â Â Â Â  The award was procured by corruption, fraud or other undue means;
  (2)Â Â Â Â  There was evident partiality by an arbitrator appointed as a neutral or corruption in any of the arbitrators or misconduct prejudicing the rights of any party;
  (3)Â Â Â Â  The arbitrators exceeded their powers;
  (4)Â Â Â Â  The arbitrators refused to postpone the hearing . . .; or
  (5)Â Â Â Â  There was no arbitration agreement . . .;
      But the fact that the relief was such that it could not or would not be granted by a court of law or equity is not ground for vacating or refusing to confirm the award.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-130 (a) (2005). 
We find the comments did not rise to the level necessary to vacate an arbitration award based on its procurement by undue means.Â  See Trident, 286 S.C. at 108, 333 S.E.2d at 787 (construing the phrase â€˜corruption, fraud, or undue meansâ€™ under the Federal Arbitration Act to â€œproscribe affirmative misconduct by the parties, such as perjury or subornation of perjury.â€); see also General Constr. Co. v. Hering Realty Co., 201 F.Supp. 487, 491 (D.S.C. 1962) (finding a party must make it â€œabundantly clearâ€ that an award was obtained through undue means).Â  
Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Finally, Renaissance argues the circuit court erred in finding the award of attorneyâ€™s fees â€œunjustâ€ based upon its own review of the contract.Â  The circuit court concluded the contract provision for attorneyâ€™s fees limited the fees to the two days encompassing the arbitration itself.Â  We find the circuit court erred in reviewing the merits of the arbitratorâ€™s award.Â  As previously noted, a court may not review the merits of an arbitration award but may vacate based only upon the statutory grounds available or on the ground of manifest disregard or perverse misconstruction of the law. Â Batten, 300 S.C. at 547-48, 389 S.E.2d at 171-72.Â  The circuit court made no finding to vacate the award of attorneyâ€™s fees on any of these grounds.Â  
In any event, we find no statutory ground to vacate the award.Â  Nor do we find manifest disregard of the law in the arbitratorâ€™s award of fees.Â  The contract provision provided for attorneyâ€™s fees, in pertinent part:

  Unless otherwise deemed appropriate by the arbitrator(s), the prevailing party shall be entitled to an award of all reasonable out-of-pocket costs and expenses (including attorneysâ€™ and arbitratorsâ€™ fees) related to the entire arbitration proceeding (including review if applicable.).

The arbitrator categorized the litigation into five phases:

  Phase One â€“ Before litigationâ€”July 26, 2002â€”September 24, 2003.
  Phase Two â€“ Beginning of lawsuit through mediationâ€”September 24, 2003â€”December 9, 2003.
  Phase Three â€“ Mediation through arbitrationâ€”December 9, 2003â€”May 29, 2004.
  Phase Four â€“ The Arbitration Hearingâ€”May 20-28, 2004.
  Phase Five â€“ Post Arbitration through current date, May 22, 2004â€”July 7, 2004.

Renaissance claimed fees for phases three ($17,572.50), four ($7,370), and five ($6,875.50) for a total claim of $31,818.Â  The arbitrator awarded costs from July 8, 2004 of $1,553.47, attorneyâ€™s fees of $31,818, and the arbitrator fee of $6,140.Â  We find no legal basis to vacate the award.
We therefore reverse the order under appeal and reinstate the arbitration award.Â  
REVERSED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] There was a separate contract for each condominium unit but the parties treated, and agreed at oral argument to continue to treat, the contracts as one. Â

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Kirsten L. Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.Â  
        Malcolm M. Crosland, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Cynthia Johnston filed this workersâ€™ compensation claim against MeadWestvaco, her employer.Â  Mead denied the claim based on Johnstonâ€™s failure to provide timely notice of her injury.Â  A single commissioner of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission found Johnstonâ€™s notice timely under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  The full commission and circuit court affirmed.Â  Mead appeals.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
Johnston asserted she sustained a work-related injury to her neck, back, and arms on September 25, 2002 as the result of a fall.Â  At the time, she noticed only a severe headache.Â  Sometime later, she realized she chipped a tooth.Â  Johnston finished working her shift the date of the accident, worked the next day, and lost no time as a result of the accident.Â  Johnston claimed she verbally notified her supervisor, Stephanie White, of the accident at a safety meeting sometime between September 25, 2002 and October 18, 2002.Â  Johnstonâ€™s first visit to a doctor was on October 18, 2002. Â 
White admitted Johnston told her about the accident in mid-October but did not report that she had been injured.Â  White further admitted she not inquire about any possible injury.Â  Johnston formally notified Mead in writing on December 27, 2002, ninety-three days after the accident. Â 
The single commissioner found Johnstonâ€™s testimony regarding verbal notice to Mead to be both credible and corroborated by Whiteâ€™s testimony.Â  Accordingly, the commissioner awarded benefits.Â  The full commission and circuit court affirmed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the commission. Â Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981). Â In an appeal from the commission, this court may not substitute its judgment for that of the commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (2005). Â The appellate court may reverse or modify the commissionâ€™s decision only if the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record. Â Id.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Mead argues the commission erred in finding Johnston properly notified Mead of her accident as required by S.C. Code Â§ 42-15-20 because Johnston did not report an injury until ninety-three days after the incident.Â  We disagree.
Under the applicable statutory and case law, Johnston provided notice to Mead.Â  The relevant statutory provision, section 42-15-20, requires an employee to notify the employer of a job-related accident within ninety days after its occurrence unless reasonable excuse is made for not giving such notice and the employer has not thereby been prejudiced.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (2005); Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 473, 617 S.E.2d 369, 379 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Section 42-15-20 provides no specific method for providing notice, and there is no requirement in the statute of notice of injury in addition to notice of accident.Â  Id. 
Furthermore, according to South Carolina case law, a supervisorâ€™s knowledge of an accident to an employee is sufficient notice to the employer to meet the statutory requirements.Â  See Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 457, 562 S.E.2d 679, 682 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 126.03(1)(b) (2001) (â€œFor adequate notice, there must be â€˜some knowledge of accompanying facts connecting the injury or illness with the employment, and indicating to a reasonably conscientious manager that the case might involve a potential compensation claim.â€™â€)).Â  The object of providing timely notice is to put the employer on notice so the incident can be timely investigated and to permit the employer to provide medical care to the employee in order to minimize the disability.Â  Hanks v. Blair Mills, 286 S.C. 378, 381, 335 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. App. 1985). Â The notice provision must be construed liberally in favor of claimants.Â  Mintz v. Fiske-Carter Constr. Co., 218 S.C. 409, 414, 63 S.E.2d 50, 52 (1951).
Applying our standard of review, we find substantial evidence to support the finding that Johnston properly notified Mead of the accident and injury. Â Johnston provided notice of the September accident to White by October.Â  This notice is imputed to Mead. Â See Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 457, 562 S.E.2d at 682.Â  We find evidence to support the commission.Â  Accordingly, the order on appeal is
AFFIRMED.Â  
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
