THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Charleston County Department of Social Services, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
         Maranda L.; Jonathan D., Charles L., and John Doe, representing the unknown biological fathers of M.; 
           and M., a child, D/O/B 02/17/01, Defendants,
         of whom Maranda L. is Appellant.
       
     
   
 
 
Appeal From Charleston County
Â Paul W. Garfinkel, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-369
Submitted October 16, 2006 â€“ Filed October 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      Stephen L. Brown and Jeffrey J. Wiseman, of Young Clement Rivers, LLP, of Charleston, for Appellant.
      Bonnie T. Brisbane, of Charleston County Department of Social Services, of N. Charleston, for Respondent.
      E. Ellen Howard, of Charleston, for Guardian Ad Litem.
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Maranda L. (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s termination of her parental rights to M. (Child).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Childâ€™s biological parents are Mother and Jonathan D (Father).Â  When Child was born, Mother and Father, a member of the armed services, resided on an Air Force Base (â€œBaseâ€).Â  In September 2002, Father left the residence and another man, Chris Gilbert, moved into it.Â  On December 5, 2002, Base personnel visited the residence to inform Mother that she had to vacate it.Â  When they arrived, they discovered Child covered in bruises.Â  The next day, North Charleston law enforcement arrived and observed Child bruised and limping.Â  Law enforcement found the residence in â€œtotal disarrayâ€: dishes were strewn across the kitchen countertop; broken glass and trash covered the kitchen floor.Â  Law enforcement also found an indentation in the wall caused by repeated blows from Childâ€™s head.Â  
The Charleston County Department of Social Services (â€œDepartmentâ€) immediately took twenty-one month old Child into emergency protective custody.Â  At the time, Child was unkempt, limped, and, as medical examination revealed, suffered from physical trauma.Â  Mother testified Gilbert caused Childâ€™s bruises.Â  She explained Gilbert would make Child stand in the corner of a room and bend over and touch the floor for twenty minutes at a time.Â  If Child was unable to do so, Gilbert â€œthumpedâ€ Childâ€™s feet.Â  Despite Gilbertâ€™s abuse of Child, Mother never called either military or civilian law enforcement about Gilbertâ€™s actions. 
 The Department and Mother entered into a treatment plan that required Mother to participate in parent effectiveness training and undergo psychiatric assessments.Â  Ultimately, Mother was unable to complete the treatment plan and on April 14, 2004, the Department brought a termination of parental rights (TPR) action against Mother.Â  After a hearing, the family court granted the Departmentâ€™s TPR action against Mother.Â  The family court found multiple statutory grounds existed to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights and TPR was in the best interests of Child.Â  Mother appealed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR case, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before parental rights can be terminated, the alleged grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v. Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 357, 296 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1982); S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we should not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court, because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
DISCUSSION
Mother argues the family court erred in granting the Departmentâ€™s TPR action against her.Â  We disagree. 
 Section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) governs TPR actions in South Carolina.Â  â€œThe family court may order TPR if it makes the twofold finding that plaintiff has proved by clear and convincing evidence the existence of at least one statutory ground enumerated in section 20-7-1572 . . . and TPR would be in the best interest of the child.â€Â  Charleston County Depâ€™t. of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 97, 627 S.E.2d 765, 771 (Ct. App. 2006). 
 The family court found Child was abused and, because of the severity or repetition of the abuse, it was unlikely the home could be made safe for Child within twelve months.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(1).[2]Â  Mother did not appeal this finding; therefore, it is the law of the case.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Seegars, 367 S.C. 623, 628 n.3, 627 S.E.2d 718, 721, n.3 (2006).Â  Accordingly, so long as TPR was also in the best interest of Child, we will uphold the family courtâ€™s order.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (family court may order TPR based on â€œone or moreâ€ statutory ground and the finding that TPR is in the best interests of the child). 
Even if Mother appealed this finding, however, the record fully supports the family courtâ€™s conclusion Child was harmed and that because of the degree of abuse the home could not be made safe within a year.Â  Under section 20-7-490(2) (Supp. 2005), â€œChild abuseâ€ occurs when the parent â€œinflicts or allows to be inflicted upon the child physical or mental injury or engages in acts or omissions which present a substantial risk of physical or mental injury to the child, including injuries sustained as a result of excessive corporal punishment . . . .â€Â  The record shows Child suffered significant physical and mental abuse at the hands of Mother and Gilbert.Â  Even if Mother did not actively abuse Child, she allowed Gilbert to do so, and did little to prevent it.Â  Further, there is no indication the home could be safe enough for Child to return to it within a year.Â  Mother testified that she was not prepared to take custody of Child at the time of hearing.Â  Motherâ€™s own witness, her therapist, testified that Motherâ€™s demeanor remained â€œchaoticâ€ and â€œincendiaryâ€ and that it would be unwise to place Child in Motherâ€™s home at this time.Â  Thus, the record supports the family courtâ€™s finding. 
 The family court also found TPR is in the best interests of Child.Â  Again, Mother did not appeal this finding, so it is the law of the case.Â  Seegars, 367 S.C. at 628 n.3, 627 S.E.2d at 721, n.3.Â  Even if Mother appealed this finding, however, the record supports the family courtâ€™s conclusion that TPR is in the best interests of Child.Â  Childâ€™s caseworker and guardian ad litem testified TPR would be in Childâ€™s best interests.Â  They both witnessed Childâ€™s positive transformation since Childâ€™s placement with her foster parents in April 2003.Â  Additionally, Childâ€™s foster parents wish to adopt Child.Â  The family court did not err in finding TPR in the best interests of Child.Â  Thus, the family courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.[3]
 HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2]Â  Section 20-7-1572(1) provides that the family court may terminate parental rights if TPR is in the best interests of the child and the child 

  has been harmed as defined in section 20-7-490, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or neglect, it is not reasonably likely that the home can be made safe within twelve months. Â In determining the likelihood that the home can be made safe, the parentâ€™s previous abuse or neglect of the child or another child in the home may be considered . . . .

[3]Â  In light of this disposition, we need not address Motherâ€™s remaining issues.Â  Â

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
BB&T of South Carolina,
Appellant,
v.
Jose & Karen Matos, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-371
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 31, 2006

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
John William Ray, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Jose C. and Karen A. Matos, of Goose Creek, pro se; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  On August 17, 2004, the circuit court granted a default judgment in favor of BB&T of South Carolina.Â  BB&T contends the circuit court erred when the court rescinded its order of August 17, 2004 and issued a subsequent order on September 28, 2004.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
In August 2001 and June 2002, Jose and Karen Matos entered into agreements with BB&T for a line of credit and credit cards.Â  Pursuant to the agreements, the Matoses contracted to pay the balance, plus interest, in a variable number of monthly installments comprised of a percentage of the balance.Â  The agreements also provide that in the event of default, BB&T has the right to declare the entire unpaid balance to be immediately due.Â  Furthermore, the agreements provide that if an attorney becomes involved, the Matoses shall pay all attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.[1]Â  
In August 2003, the Matoses failed to make a payment as required, thereby breaching the agreements.Â  BB&T brought the current action on June 29, 2004, alleging the Matoses failed to make payments pursuant to the agreement and misrepresented their ability to make the payments pursuant to the agreement.Â  BB&T alleged in its Complaint the Matoses had a past due amount of $23,982.89, plus interest at the rate of 8.75 percent.Â  BB&T further alleged the Matoses had been made aware of their default status and had been given the opportunity to become current with their payments, but they failed to do so.Â  
On August 17, 2004, with receipt of no pleading, motion, or objection and with none appearing in the circuit courtâ€™s file, BB&T filed an Affidavit of Default with further verification of debt and requested a default judgment.Â  On August 17, 2004, the circuit court issued a judgment for $29,771.39 against the Matoses.Â  The judgment confirms that there was no responsive pleading of record and provides that â€œcancellation, satisfaction, or modification be entered only upon signature of the attorney of record or Order of this court following proper notice and hearing.â€Â  (emphasis in original). Â On August 18, 2004, the Clerk of Court served notice of judgment upon both parties.Â  
Thirty-eight days later, on September 24, 2004, the circuit court issued a Form 4 order stating the August 17, 2004 judgment was â€œrescinded.â€Â  The September 24, 2004 order states as follows:Â  

Judgment order entered on August 17, 2004 will be rescinded as it was prematurely signed.Â  The Plaintiffâ€™s Motion for Default Judgment will be set on a non-jury docket to be heard at an appropriate time.Â  Defendantsâ€™ Motion for Reconsideration is now moot.Â  

BB&T maintains the second order was issued either sua sponte or based on inappropriate ex parte contact.Â  On the day BB&T received the September 24, 2004 order, it notified the circuit court of its concern and requested that the prior judgment be reinstated.Â  The circuit court declined to reinstate the prior order, and this appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
BB&T contends the circuit court erred in issuing the September 24, 2004 order.Â  We agree.Â  
In matters concerning a default judgment, Rule 55(a), SCRCP, states default may be entered â€œwhen a party against whom a judgment for affirmative relief is sought has failed to plead or otherwise defend as provided by these rules and that fact is made to appear by affidavit or otherwise.â€Â  An entry of default may be set aside â€œ[f]or good cause shown,â€ and if a â€œjudgment by default has been entered, [the court] may likewise set it aside in accordance with Rule 60(b).â€Â  See Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP, states that relief from judgment or order may be given based on the following:Â  

(b) Mistakes; Inadvertence; Excusable Neglect; Newly Discovered Evidence; Fraud, etc. On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:
    
  (1) mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect;
  
  (2) newly discovered evidence which by due diligence could not have been discovered in time to move for a new trial under Rule 59(b);

  (3) fraud, misrepresentation, or other misconduct of an adverse party;

  (4) the judgment is void;

  (5) the judgment has been satisfied, released, or discharged, or a prior judgment upon which it is based has been reversed or otherwise vacated, or it is no longer equitable that the judgment should have prospective application.

In the present case, the circuit court did not follow any of these methods.Â  Instead, the circuit court rescinded the default order thirty-eight days after it was rendered and not pursuant to a motion for reconsideration, a motion the circuit court deemed moot.Â  See Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 156, 543 S.E.2d 224, 229 (Ct. App. 2001); See also Rule 59(e), SCRCP (â€œMotion to Alter or Amend a Judgment. Â A motion to alter or amend the judgment shall be served not later than 10 days after receipt of written notice of the entry of the order.â€); Rule 59(d), SCRCP (â€œOn Initiative of Court. Not later than 10 days after entry of judgment, the court of its own initiative may order a new trial for any reason for which it might have granted a new trial on motion of a party. Â After giving the parties notice and an opportunity to be heard on the matter, the court may grant a motion for a new trial, timely served, for a reason not stated in the motion. Â In either case, the court shall specify in the order the grounds
therefor.â€).Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold the circuit court erred in issuing the September 28, 2004 order because the circuit court lacked jurisdiction.Â  Because we find the September 28, 2004 order is now void, the finding in that order that the motion to reconsider is moot has also been voided.Â  We remand for a ruling on that motion.Â  If the circuit court should find the motion was not properly served and filed or is unmeritorious, the default judgment is upheld.Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED.[2]Â 
 
 GOOLSBY,  WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

[1] The agreements are not provided in the record, and as a result, these facts are taken from the Complaint.Â  Because the Matoses failed to answer BB&Tâ€™s complaint, the allegations therein are deemed admitted and consequently relied upon by this Court.Â  (Rule 8(d), SCRCP. â€œEffect of Failure to Deny. Â Averments in a pleading to which a responsive pleading is required, other than those as to the amount of damage, are admitted when not denied in the responsive pleading.â€).Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
v.
Bobby Gibson, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
 Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-372
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed October 31, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Katherine Carruth Link, of W. Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Â Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Bobby Gibson, Jr., appeals his convictions and sentences for possession of crack cocaine, trafficking in cocaine, and trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  Gibson argues the trial court should not have admitted the drug evidence because it was seized pursuant to:Â  (1) an invalid warrantless search; (2) search warrants not issued in accordance with section 17-13-140 of the South Carolina Code; and (3) search warrants not served in accordance with section 17-13-150 of the South Carolina Code. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On the morning of September 30, 2004, Deputy Brian Duncan, employed with the Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s Office, arrested Gibson for driving under a suspended license.Â  Directly thereafter, Deputy Duncan searched Gibsonâ€™s person.Â  Attached to Gibsonâ€™s side was a cell phone case.Â  Deputy Duncan searched the cell phone case and found a small white rock, later identified as crack cocaine.Â  
Subsequently, two search warrants were issued to search Gibsonâ€™s residence and business.Â  The warrants were based on information obtained through an ongoing investigation and on Gibsonâ€™s possession of crack cocaine on the date in question. Â The warrants were signed by a judge and obtained at 2:40 p.m. on September 30, 2004.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
At 4:24 p.m. on the day the warrants were issued, officers executed the search warrant for 2015 Howard Street, Gibsonâ€™s residence.Â  The search of Gibsonâ€™s residence yielded a pill bottle containing several rocks of crack cocaine, a set of digital scales, a small bag of marijuana, and $156,000 in cash.Â  An unsigned copy of the warrant was left at the residence.Â  
At 5:45 p.m., officers executed the search warrant for 420 Farley Avenue, a commercial building owned by Gibson.Â  During this search, the officers found a bag containing a large amount of a white powder substance, which was later identified as 705.32 grams of cocaine.Â  An unsigned copy of the warrant was left at the commercial building.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
A Spartanburg County grand jury indicted Gibson for possession of crack cocaine, trafficking in cocaine, and trafficking in crack cocaine.Â  Prior to trial, Gibson moved to suppress the drug evidence.Â  He asserted the search of the cell phone case was improper.Â  Based on this assertion, Gibson contended the illegality of the search provided an illegal basis for the search warrants.Â  Specifically, he argued the search exceeded the scope of the initial traffic stop given he had been arrested and was under the complete control of Deputy Duncan.Â  In response, the State claimed the search was incident to Gibsonâ€™s lawful arrest. Â After hearing testimony from Deputy Duncan and arguments of counsel, the court denied Gibsonâ€™s motion.Â  The court ruled the search was incident to a lawful arrest.
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case and after all the evidence was introduced, Gibson moved to quash the search warrants alleging the officers failed to serve copies of the warrants as required by sections 17-13-140 and 17-13-150 of the South Carolina Code (2003).[2]Â  Because the search warrants that were left at Gibsonâ€™s residence and business were not signed, Gibson claimed the warrants were not executed in accordance with the cited statutes and, thus, the officers conducted a warrantless search. Â In response, the State showed the court certified copies of the warrants that were signed by a judge at the time they were issued.Â  The State also asserted:Â  (1) the officers acted in good faith in conducting the search; (2) any error was ministerial; and (3) Gibson was not prejudiced by the error.Â  After hearing testimony from Gibson and the arguments of counsel, the court denied Gibsonâ€™s motion.Â  The court based its decision on the fact the certified copies of the warrants indicated a judge signed the warrants prior to the searches of Gibsonâ€™s residence and business. 
After the jury convicted Gibson of all three charges, the court sentenced Gibson to fifteen years imprisonment for the possession offense and thirty years imprisonment for each trafficking offense.Â  The sentences were to be served concurrently.Â  The court also imposed fines of $15,000 for the possession charge, $50,000 for trafficking in crack cocaine, and $200,000 for trafficking in cocaine.Â  Gibson appeals.Â  Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, an appellate court reviews errors of law only and is bound by factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â 
Statev. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001). â€œThe trial judgeâ€™s factual findings on whether evidence should be suppressed due to a Fourth Amendment violation are reviewed for clear error.â€Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006).Â  â€œA courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.â€ State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).
DISCUSSION
I.
Gibson argues the trial court erred in denying his motion to quash the search warrants and suppress the seized evidence.Â  He contends the warrants were not issued in accordance with section 17-13-140 and the State failed to provide copies of the issued warrants and the affidavits as required by section 17-13-150.Â  We disagree.Â  Â 
Although Gibson raised this argument to the trial court, it was untimely given it was not presented until after the State introduced the search evidence.Â  Initially, we note that Gibson was aware of any alleged violation of the statutory requirements prior to trial.Â  During the in camera hearing the court held on this motion, Gibson testified that he brought the original, unsigned search warrants to his counselâ€™s office shortly after he was arrested.Â  Thus, we find Gibson could have presented this argument during the pre-trial hearing.Â  Furthermore, Gibson failed to timely object to the introduction of evidence on this ground during the Stateâ€™s case.Â  Significantly, the objections raised by Gibson to the admission of the evidence only referenced what was discussed in the pre-trial hearing.Â  Accordingly, we find Gibson did not preserve these issues for appellate review.Â  See State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, 265-66, 589 S.E.2d 6, 9 (2003) (finding defendant failed to preserve issue regarding the admissibility of seized evidence where he did not make a motion in limine and did not timely move to suppress the evidence); State v.
